7648 Section 199. Section 17-79-605 is renumbered and amended to read:
7650 [17-27a-512] 17-79-605. County's acquisition of billboard by eminent domain -- Removal
without providing compensation -- Limit on allowing nonconforming billboard to be rebuilt or
replaced -- Validity of county permit after issuance of state permit.
7616 (1) As used in this section:
7617 (a) "Clearly visible" means capable of being read without obstruction by an occupant of a vehicle
traveling on a street or highway within the visibility area.
7619 (b) "Highest allowable height" means:
7620 (i) if the height allowed by the county, by ordinance or consent, is higher than the height under
Subsection (1)(b)(ii), the height allowed by the county; or
7622 (ii)
(A) for a noninterstate billboard:
- 241 -
SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
7623 (I) if the height of the previous use or structure is 45 feet or higher, the height of the previous use or
structure; or
7625 (II) if the height of the previous use or structure is less than 45 feet, the height of the previous use
or structure or the height to make the entire advertising content of the billboard clearly visible,
whichever is higher, but no higher than 45 feet; and
7629 (B) for an interstate billboard:
7630 (I) if the height of the previous use or structure is at or above the interstate height, the height of the
previous use or structure; or
7632 (II) if the height of the previous use or structure is less than the interstate height, the height of the
previous use or structure or the height to make the entire advertising content of the billboard clearly
visible, whichever is higher, but no higher than the interstate height.
7636 (c) "Interstate billboard" means a billboard that is intended to be viewed from a highway that is an
interstate.
7638 (d) "Interstate height" means a height that is the higher of:
7639 (i) 65 feet above the ground; and
7640 (ii) 25 feet above the grade of the interstate.
7641 (e) "Noninterstate billboard" means a billboard that is intended to be viewed from a street or highway
that is not an interstate.
7643 (f) "Visibility area" means the area on a street or highway that is:
7644 (i) defined at one end by a line extending from the base of the billboard across all lanes of traffic of the
street or highway in a plane that is perpendicular to the street or highway; and
7647 (ii) defined on the other end by a line extending across all lanes of traffic of the street or highway in a
plane that is:
7649 (A) perpendicular to the street or highway; and
7650 (B)
(I) for an interstate billboard, 500 feet from the base of the billboard; or
7651 (II) for a noninterstate billboard, 300 feet from the base of the billboard.
7652 (2)
(a) If a billboard owner makes a written request to the county with jurisdiction over the billboard to take
an action described in Subsection (2)(b), the billboard owner may take the requested action, without
- 242 -
SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
further county land use approval, 180 days after the day on which the billboard owner makes the
written request, unless within the 180-day period the county:
7657 (i) in an attempt to acquire the billboard and associated rights through eminent domain under

Section 31:
Section [17-27a-511] 17-79-604 for the purpose of terminating the billboard and associated
rights:
7660 (A) completes the procedural steps required under Title 78B, Chapter 6, Part 5, Eminent Domain,
before the filing of an eminent domain action; and
7662 (B) files an eminent domain action in accordance with Title 78B, Chapter 6, Part 5, Eminent Domain;
7664 (ii) denies the request in accordance with Subsection (2)(d); or
7665 (iii) requires the billboard owner to remove the billboard in accordance with Subsection (3).
7667 (b) Subject to Subsection (2)(a), a billboard owner may:
7668 (i) rebuild, maintain, repair, or restore a billboard structure that is damaged by casualty, an act of God,
or vandalism;
7670 (ii) relocate or rebuild a billboard structure, or take another measure, to correct a mistake in the
placement or erection of a billboard for which the county issued a permit, if the proposed relocation,
rebuilding, or other measure is consistent with the intent of that permit;
7674 (iii) structurally modify or upgrade a billboard;
7675 (iv) relocate a billboard into any commercial, industrial, or manufacturing zone within the
unincorporated area of the county, if the relocated billboard is:
7677 (A) within 5,280 feet of the billboard's previous location; and
7678 (B) no closer than 300 feet from an off-premise sign existing on the same side of the street or highway,
or if the street or highway is an interstate or limited access highway that is subject to Title 72,
Chapter 7, Part 5, Utah Outdoor Advertising Act, the distance allowed under that act between the
relocated billboard and an off-premise sign existing on the same side of the interstate or limited
access highway; or
7684 (v) make one or more of the following modifications, as the billboard owner determines, to a billboard
that is structurally altered by modification or upgrade under Subsection (2)(b)(iii), by relocation
under Subsection (2)(b)(iv), or by any combination of these alterations:
7688 (A) erect the billboard:
7689 (I) to the highest allowable height; and
7690
- 243 -
SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
(II) as the owner determines, to an angle that makes the entire advertising content of the billboard
clearly visible; or
7692 (B) install a sign face on the billboard that is at least the same size as, but no larger than, the sign face
on the billboard before the billboard's relocation.
7694 (c) A modification under Subsection (2)(b)(v) shall comply with Title 72, Chapter 7, Part 5, Utah
Outdoor Advertising Act, to the extent applicable.
7696 (d) A county may deny a billboard owner's request to relocate or rebuild a billboard structure, or
to take other measures, in order to correct a mistake in the placement or erection of a billboard
without acquiring the billboard and associated rights through eminent domain under Section
[17-27a-511] 17-79-604, if the mistake in placement or erection of the billboard is determined
by clear and convincing evidence, in a proceeding that protects the billboard owner's due process
rights, to have resulted from an intentionally false or misleading statement:
7703 (i) by the billboard applicant in the application; and
7704 (ii) regarding the placement or erection of the billboard.
7705 (e) A county that acquires a billboard and associated rights through eminent domain under Section
[17-27a-511] 17-79-604 shall pay just compensation to the billboard owner in an amount that is:
7708 (i) the value of the existing billboard at a fair market capitalization rate, based on actual annual revenue,
less any annual rent expense;
7710 (ii) the value of any other right associated with the billboard;
7711 (iii) the cost of the sign structure; and
7712 (iv) damage to the economic unit described in Subsection 72-7-510(3)(b), of which the billboard
owner's interest is a part.
7714 (f) If a county commences an eminent domain action under Subsection (2)(a)(i):
7715 (i) the provisions of Section 78B-6-510 do not apply; and
7716 (ii) the county may not take possession of the billboard or the billboard's associated rights until:
7718 (A) completion of all appeals of a judgment allowing the county to acquire the billboard and associated
rights; and
7720 (B) the billboard owner receives payment of just compensation, described in Subsection (2)(e).
7722 (g) Unless the eminent domain action is dismissed under Subsection (2)(h)(ii), a billboard owner may
proceed, without further county land use approval, to take an action requested under Subsection
- 244 -
SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
(2)(a), if the county's eminent domain action commenced under Subsection (2)(a)(i) is dismissed
without an order allowing the county to acquire the billboard and associated rights.
7727 (h)
(i) A billboard owner may withdraw a request made under Subsection (2)(a) at any time before the
county takes possession of the billboard or the billboard's associated rights in accordance with
Subsection (2)(f)(ii).
7730 (ii) If a billboard owner withdraws a request in accordance with Subsection (2)(h)(i), the court shall
dismiss the county's eminent domain action to acquire the billboard or associated rights.
7733 (3) Notwithstanding Section [17-27a-511] 17-79-604, a county may require an owner of a billboard to
remove the billboard without acquiring a billboard and associated rights through eminent domain if:
7736 (a) the county determines:
7737 (i) by clear and convincing evidence that the applicant for a permit intentionally made a false or
misleading statement in the applicant's application regarding the placement or erection of the
billboard; or
7740 (ii) by substantial evidence that the billboard:
7741 (A) is structurally unsafe;
7742 (B) is in an unreasonable state of repair; or
7743 (C) has been abandoned for at least 12 months;
7744 (b) the county notifies the billboard owner in writing that the billboard owner's billboard meets one or
more of the conditions listed in Subsections (3)(a)(i) and (ii);
7746 (c) the billboard owner fails to remedy the condition or conditions within:
7747 (i) 180 days after the day on which the billboard owner receives written notice under Subsection (3)(b);
or
7749 (ii) if the condition forming the basis of the county's intention to remove the billboard is that it is
structurally unsafe, 10 business days, or a longer period if necessary because of a natural disaster,
after the day on which the billboard owner receives written notice under Subsection (3)(b); and
7753 (d) following the expiration of the applicable period under Subsection (3)(c) and after providing the
billboard owner with reasonable notice of proceedings and an opportunity for a hearing, the county
finds:
7756 (i) by clear and convincing evidence, that the applicant for a permit intentionally made a false or
misleading statement in the application regarding the placement or erection of the billboard; or
- 245 -
SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
7759 (ii) by substantial evidence that the billboard is structurally unsafe, is in an unreasonable state of repair,
or has been abandoned for at least 12 months.
7761 (4) A county may not allow a nonconforming billboard to be rebuilt or replaced by anyone other than
the billboard's owner, or the billboard's owner acting through a contractor, within 500 feet of the
nonconforming location.
7764 (5) A permit that a county issues, extends, or renews for a billboard remains valid beginning on the
day on which the county issues, extends, or renews the permit and ending 180 days after the day on
which a required state permit is issued for the billboard if:
7768 (a) the billboard requires a state permit; and
7769 (b) an application for the state permit is filed within 30 days after the day on which the county issues,
extends, or renews a permit for the billboard.
7809 Section 200. Section 17-79-606 is renumbered and amended to read:
7811 [17-27a-514] 17-79-606. Regulation of amateur radio antennas.
7775 (1) A county may not enact or enforce an ordinance that does not comply with the ruling of the Federal
Communications Commission in "Amateur Radio Preemption, 101 FCC 2nd 952 (1985)" or a
regulation related to amateur radio service adopted under 47 C.F.R. Part 97.
7779 (2) If a county adopts an ordinance involving the placement, screening, or height of an amateur radio
antenna based on health, safety, or aesthetic conditions, the ordinance shall:
7782 (a) reasonably accommodate amateur radio communications; and
7783 (b) represent the minimal practicable regulation to accomplish the county's purpose.
7822 Section 201. Section 17-79-607 is renumbered and amended to read:
7824 [17-27a-515] 17-79-607. Regulation of residential facilities for persons with disabilities.
A county may only regulate a residential facility for persons with a disability to the
extent allowed by:
7790 (1) Title 57, Chapter 21, Utah Fair Housing Act, and applicable jurisprudence;
7791 (2) the Fair Housing Amendments Act of 1988, 42 U.S.C. Sec. 3601 et seq., and applicable
jurisprudence; and
7793 (3) Section 504, Rehabilitation Act of 1973, and applicable jurisprudence.
7832 Section 202. Section 17-79-608 is renumbered and amended to read:
7834 [17-27a-520] 17-79-608. Wetlands.
7797
- 246 -
SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
(1) A county may not designate or treat any land as wetlands unless the United States Army Corps of
Engineers or other agency of the federal government has designated the land as wetlands.
7800 (2) A land use authority that issues a land use permit that affects land designated as wetlands by the
United States Army Corps of Engineers or another agency of the federal government shall provide a
copy of the land use permit to the Utah Geological Survey established in Section 79-3-201.
7842 Section 203. Section 17-79-609 is renumbered and amended to read:
7844 [17-27a-521] 17-79-609. Refineries.
7807 (1) As used in this section, "develop" or "development" means:
7808 (a) the construction, alteration, or improvement of land, including any related moving, demolition, or
excavation outside of a refinery property boundary;
7810 (b) the subdivision of land for a non-industrial use; or
7811 (c) the construction of a non-industrial structure on a parcel that is not subject to the subdivision
process.
7813 (2) Before a legislative body may adopt a non-industrial zoning change to permit development within
500 feet of a refinery boundary, the legislative body shall consult with the refinery to determine
whether the proposed change is compatible with the refinery.
7817 (3) Before a land use authority may approve an application to develop within 500 feet of a refinery
boundary, the land use authority shall consult with the refinery to determine whether the
development is compatible with the refinery.
7820 (4) A legislative body described in Subsection (2), or a land use authority described in Subsection (3),
may not request from the refinery:
7822 (a) proprietary information;
7823 (b) information, if made public, that would create a security or safety risk to the refinery or the public;
7825 (c) information that is restricted from public disclosure under federal or state law; or
7826 (d) information that is available in public record.
7827 (5)
(a) This section does not grant authority to a legislative body described in Subsection (2), or a land use
authority described in Subsection (3), to require a refinery to undertake or cease an action.
7830 (b) This section does not create a cause of action against a refinery.
7831 (c) Except as expressly provided in this section, this section does not alter or remove any legal right or
obligation of a refinery.
- 247 -
SB1007 compared with SB1007S01

7906 Section 205. Section 17-79-611 is renumbered and amended to read:
7908 [17-27a-510.5] 17-79-611. Changes to rental dwelling units -- Egress windows.
7872 (1) As used in this section:
7873 (a) "Internal accessory dwelling unit" means an accessory dwelling unit created:
7874 (i) within a primary dwelling;
7875 (ii) within the footprint of the primary dwelling described in Subsection (1)(a)(i) at the time the internal
accessory dwelling unit is created; and
7877 (iii) for the purpose of offering a long-term rental of 30 consecutive days or longer.
7878 (b) "Primary dwelling" means a single-family dwelling that:
7879 (i) is detached; and
7880 (ii) is occupied as the primary residence of the owner of record.
7881 (c) "Rental dwelling" means the same as that term is defined in Section 10-8-85.5.
7882 (2) A county ordinance [adopted under Section 10-1-203.5 ]may not:
7883 (a) require physical changes in a structure with a legal nonconforming rental dwelling use unless the
change is for:
7885 (i) the reasonable installation of:
7886 (A) a smoke detector that is plugged in or battery operated;
7887 (B) a ground fault circuit interrupter protected outlet on existing wiring;
7888 (C) street addressing;
7889 (D) except as provided in Subsection (3), an egress bedroom window if the existing bedroom window is
smaller than that required by current State Construction Code;
7892 (E) an electrical system or a plumbing system, if the existing system is not functioning or is unsafe as
determined by an independent electrical or plumbing professional who is licensed in accordance
with Title 58, Occupations and Professions;
7896 (F) hand or guard rails; or
7897 (G) occupancy separation doors as required by the International Residential Code; or
7899 (ii) the abatement of a structure; or
7900 (b) be enforced to terminate a legal nonconforming rental dwelling use.
7901 (3)
- 249 -
SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
(a) A county may not require physical changes to install an egress or emergency escape window in an
existing bedroom that complied with the State Construction Code in effect at the time the bedroom
was finished if:
7904 (i) the dwelling is an owner-occupied dwelling or a rental dwelling that is:
7905 (A) a detached one-, two-, three-, or four-family dwelling; or
7906 (B) a town home that is not more than three stories above grade with a separate means of egress; and
7908 (ii)
(A) the window in the existing bedroom is smaller than that required by current State Construction
Code; and
7910 (B) the change would compromise the structural integrity of the structure or could not be completed
in accordance with current State Construction Code, including set-back and window well
requirements.
7913 (b) Subsection (3)(a) does not apply to an internal accessory dwelling unit.
7914 (4) Nothing in this section prohibits a county from:
7915 (a) regulating the style of window that is required or allowed in a bedroom;
7916 (b) requiring that a window in an existing bedroom be fully openable if the openable area is less than
required by current State Construction Code; or
7918 (c) requiring that an existing window not be reduced in size if the openable area is smaller than required
by current State Construction Code.

7967 Section 207. Section 17-79-613 is renumbered and amended to read:
7969 [17-27a-529] 17-79-613. Infrastructure improvements involving roadways.
7933 (1) As used in this section:
7934 (a) "Low impact development" means the same as that term is defined in Section 19-5-108.5.
- 250 -
SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
7936 (b)
(i) "Pavement" means the bituminous or concrete surface of a roadway.
7937 (ii) "Pavement" does not include a curb or gutter.
7938 (c) "Residential street" means a public or private roadway that:
7939 (i) currently serves or is projected to serve an area designated primarily for single-family residential
use;
7941 (ii) requires at least two off-site parking spaces for each single-family residential property abutting the
roadway; and
7943 (iii) has or is projected to have, on average, traffic of no more than 1,000 trips per day, based on
findings contained in:
7945 (A) a traffic impact study;
7946 (B) the county's general plan under Section [17-27a-401] 17-79-401;

7949 (2)
(a) Except as provided in Subsection (2)(b), a county may not, as part of an infrastructure improvement,
require the installation of pavement on a residential street at a width in excess of 32 feet if the
county requires low impact development for the area in which the residential street is located.
7953 (b) Subsection (2)(a) does not apply if a county requires the installation of pavement:
7954 (i) in a vehicle turnaround area; or
7955 (ii) to address specific traffic flow constraints at an intersection or other area.
7956 (3)
(a) A county shall, by ordinance, establish any standards that the county requires, as part of an
infrastructure improvement, for fire department vehicle access and turnaround on roadways.
7959 (b) The county shall ensure that the standards established under Subsection (3)(a) are consistent with
the State Fire Code as defined in Section 15A-1-102.
7999 Section 208. Section 17-79-614 is renumbered and amended to read:
8001 [17-27a-530] 17-79-614. Regulation of building design elements prohibited -- Regulation of
parking spaces prohibited -- Exceptions.
7965 (1) As used in this section:
7966
- 251 -
SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
(a) "Affordable housing" means housing occupied or reserved for occupancy that is priced at 80% of the
county median home price.
7968 (b) "Building design element" means:
7969 (i) exterior color;
7970 (ii) type or style of exterior cladding material;
7971 (iii) style, dimensions, or materials of a roof structure, roof pitch, or porch;
7972 (iv) exterior nonstructural architectural ornamentation;
7973 (v) location, design, placement, or architectural styling of a window or door;
7974 (vi) location, design, placement, or architectural styling of a garage door, not including a rear-loading
garage door;
7976 (vii) number or type of rooms;
7977 (viii) interior layout of a room;
7978 (ix) minimum square footage over 1,000 square feet, not including a garage;
7979 (x) rear yard landscaping requirements;
7980 (xi) minimum building dimensions; or
7981 (xii) a requirement to install front yard fencing.
7982 (c) "Owner-occupied" means a housing unit in which the individual who owns the housing unit, solely
or jointly, lives as the individual's primary residence for no less than five years.
7985 (d) "Specified county" means the same as that term is defined in Section [17-27a-408] 17-80-101.
7987 (e) "Unobstructed" means a parking space that has no permanent barriers that would unreasonably
reduce the size of an available parking space described in Subsection (4).

7995 (iii) a local historic district or area, or a site designated as a local landmark, created by ordinance before
January 1, 2021, except as provided under Subsection (3)(b);

administered by the Federal Emergency Management Agency;
- 252 -
SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
7999 (c) an ordinance enacted to implement the requirements of the Utah Wildland Urban Interface Code
adopted under Section 15A-2-103;

8004 (ii) was substantially developed before calendar year 1950;
8005 (f) an ordinance enacted to implement water efficient landscaping in a rear yard;
8006 (g) an ordinance enacted to regulate type of cladding, in response to findings or evidence from the
construction industry of:
8008 (i) defects in the material of existing cladding; or
8009 (ii) consistent defects in the installation of existing cladding;

requests:
8012 (i) the county to apply to the owner's property; and
8013 (ii) in exchange for an increase in density or other benefit not otherwise available as a permitted use in
the zoning area or district; or

8016 (i) in excess of 20,000 pounds of trinitrotoluene equivalent;

8018 (iii) that would pose a risk of damage to a window, garage door, or carport of a facility located within

home be:
8023 (i) for unobstructed, enclosed, or covered parking:

8025 (B) more than 20 feet long; or

8027 (A) more than nine feet wide; or
8028 (B) more than 20 feet long;
8029

SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
(b) restrict an unobstructed tandem parking space from satisfying two parking spaces as part of a
minimum parking space requirement; and
8031 (c) restrict a two-car garage from satisfying two parking spaces as part of a minimum parking space
requirement.
8033 (5) A county may not require a garage for a single-family attached or detached dwelling that is owner-
occupied affordable housing.
8035 (6) If a county requires a garage, the county shall count each parking space within the garage as part of
the county's minimum parking space requirement as described in Section [17-27a-526] 17-80-303.
8038 (7) Nothing in this section prohibits a county from requiring on-site parking for owner-occupied
affordable housing.
8078 Section 209. Section 17-79-615 is renumbered and amended to read:
8080 [17-27a-532] 17-79-615. Water wise landscaping -- County landscaping regulations.
8044 (1) As used in this section:
8045 (a) "Lawn or turf" means nonagricultural land planted in closely mowed, managed grasses.
8047 (b) "Mulch" means material such as rock, bark, wood chips, or other materials left loose and applied to
the soil.
8049 (c) "Overhead spray irrigation" means above ground irrigation heads that spray water through a nozzle.
8051 (d) "Private landscaping plan" means the same as that term is defined in Section
[17-27a-604.5] 17-79-707.
8053 (e)
(i) "Vegetative coverage" means the ground level surface area covered by the exposed leaf area of a
plant or group of plants at full maturity.
8055 (ii) "Vegetative coverage" does not mean the ground level surface area covered by the exposed leaf area
of a tree or trees.
8057 (f) "Water wise landscaping" means any or all of the following:
8058 (i) installation of plant materials suited to the microclimate and soil conditions that can:
8060 (A) remain healthy with minimal irrigation once established; or
8061 (B) be maintained without the use of overhead spray irrigation;
8062 (ii) use of water for outdoor irrigation through proper and efficient irrigation design and water
application; or
8064 (iii) the use of other landscape design features that:
- 254 -
SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
8065 (A) minimize the need of the landscape for supplemental water from irrigation; or
8066 (B) reduce the landscape area dedicated to lawn or turf.
8067 (2) A county may not enact or enforce an ordinance, resolution, or policy that prohibits, or has the effect
of prohibiting, a property owner from incorporating water wise landscaping on the property owner's
property.
8070 (3)
(a) Subject to Subsection (3)(b), Subsection (2) does not prohibit a county from requiring a property
owner to:
8072 (i) comply with a site plan review, private landscaping plan review, or other review process before
installing water wise landscaping;
8074 (ii) maintain plant material in a healthy condition; and
8075 (iii) follow specific water wise landscaping design requirements adopted by the county, including a
requirement that:
8077 (A) restricts or clarifies the use of mulches considered detrimental to county operations;
8079 (B) imposes minimum or maximum vegetative coverage standards; or
8080 (C) restricts or prohibits the use of specific plant materials.
8081 (b) A county may not require a property owner to install or keep in place lawn or turf in an area with a
width less than eight feet.
8083 (4) A county may require a seller of a newly constructed residence within the unincorporated area of the
county to inform the first buyer of the newly constructed residence of a county ordinance requiring
water wise landscaping.
8086 (5) A county shall report to the Division of Water Resources the existence, enactment, or modification
of an ordinance, resolution, or policy that implements regional-based water use efficiency standards
established by the Division of Water Resources by rule under Section 73-10-37.
8090 (6) A county may enforce a county landscaping ordinance in compliance with this section.
8129 Section 210. Section 17-79-616 is renumbered and amended to read:
8131 [17-27a-533] 17-79-616. Land use compatibility with military use.
8095 (1) As used in this section:
8096 (a) "Department" means the Department of Veterans and Military Affairs.
8097 (b) "Military" means a branch of the armed forces of the United States, including the Utah National
Guard.
- 255 -
SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
8099 (c) "Military land" means the following land or facilities:
8100 (i) Camp Williams;
8101 (ii) Hill Air Force Base;
8102 (iii) Dugway Proving Ground;
8103 (iv) Tooele Army Depot;
8104 (v) Utah Test and Training Range;
8105 (vi) Nephi Readiness Center;
8106 (vii) Cedar City Alternate Flight Facility; or
8107 (viii) Little Mountain Test Facility.
8108 (2)
(a) Except as provided in Subsection (2)(b), on or before July 1, 2025, for any area in a county within
5,000 feet of a boundary of military land, a county shall, in consultation with the department,
develop and maintain a compatible use plan to ensure permitted uses and conditional uses relevant
to the military land are compatible with the military operations on military land.
8113 (b) A county that has a compatible use plan as of January 1, 2023, is not required to develop a new
compatible use plan.
8115 (3) If a county receives a land use application related to land within 5,000 feet of a boundary of military
land, before the county may approve the land use application, the county shall notify the department
in writing.
8118 (4)
(a) If the department receives the notice described in Subsection (3), the executive director of the
department shall:
8120 (i) determine whether the proposed land use is compatible with the military use of the relevant
military land; and
8122 (ii) within 90 days after the receipt of the notice described in Subsection (3), respond in writing to
the county regarding the determination of compatibility described in Subsection (4)(a)(i).
8125 (b)
(i) For a land use application pertaining to a parcel within 5,000 feet of military land that may have an
adverse effect on the operations of the military installation, except as provided in Subsection (4)(b)
(ii), the county shall consider the compatible use plan in processing the land use application.
8129
- 256 -
SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
(ii) For a land use application pertaining to a parcel within 5,000 feet of military land that may have
an adverse effect on the operations of the military installation, if the applicant has a vested right,
the county is not required to consider the compatible land use plan in consideration of the land use
application.
8133 (5) If the department receives the notice described in Subsection (3) before the county has completed
the compatible use plan as described in this section, the department shall consult with the county
and representatives of the relevant military land to determine whether the use proposed in the land
use application is a compatible use.
8175 Section 211. Section 17-79-617 is renumbered and amended to read:
8177 [17-27a-534] 17-79-617. Residential rear setback limitations.
8140 (1) As used in this section:
8141 (a) "Allowable feature" means:
8142 (i) a landing or walkout porch that:
8143 (A) is no more than 32 square feet in size; and
8144 (B) is used for ingress to and egress from the rear of the residential dwelling; or
8145 (ii) a window well.
8146 (b) "Landing" means an uncovered, above-ground platform, with or without stairs, connected to the rear
of a residential dwelling.
8148 (c) "Setback" means the required distance between the property line of a lot or parcel and the location
where a structure is allowed to be placed under an adopted land use regulation.
8151 (d) "Walkout porch" means an uncovered platform that is on the ground and connected to the rear of a
residential dwelling.
8153 (e) "Window well" means a recess in the ground around a residential dwelling to allow for ingress and
egress through a window installed in a basement that is fully or partially below ground.
8156 (2) A county may not enact or enforce an ordinance, resolution, or policy that prohibits or has the effect
of prohibiting an allowable feature within the rear setback of a residential building lot or parcel.
8159 (3) Subsection (2) does not apply to a historic district located within the unincorporated area of a
county.
8199 Section 212. Section 17-79-618 is renumbered and amended to read:
8201 [17-27a-535] 17-79-618. Operation of a tower crane.
8164 (1) As used in this section:
- 257 -
SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
8165 (a) "Affected land" means the same as that term is defined in Section 10-9a-539.
8166 (b) "Airspace approval" means the same as that term is defined in Section 10-9a-539.
8167 (c) "Live load" means the same as that term is defined in Section 10-9a-539.
8168 (d) "Permit period" means the same as that term is defined in Section 10-9a-539.
8169 (e) "Tower crane" means the same as that term is defined in Section 10-9a-539.
8170 (2) Except as provided in Subsection (3), a county may not require airspace approval as a condition for
the county's:
8172 (a) approval of a building permit; or
8173 (b) authorization of a development activity.
8174 (3) A county may require airspace approval relating to affected land as a condition for the county's
approval of a building permit or for the county's authorization of a development activity if:
8177 (a) the tower crane will, during the permit period or development activity, carry a live load over the
affected land; or
8179 (b) the affected land is within:
8180 (i) an airport overlay zone; or
8181 (ii) another zone designated to protect the airspace around an airport.
8220 Section 213. Section 17-79-619 is renumbered and amended to read:
8222 [17-27a-539] 17-79-619. Digital asset mining -- Zoning restrictions.
8186 (1) As used in this section:
8187 (a) "Digital asset" means the same as that term is defined in Section 7-29-101.
8188 (b) "Digital asset mining" means using computer hardware and software specifically designed or
utilized for validating data and securing a blockchain network.
8190 (c) "Digital asset mining business" means a group of computers working at a single site that:
8192 (i) consumes more than one megawatt of energy on an average annual basis; and
8193 (ii) operates for the purpose of generating blockchain tokens by securing a blockchain network.
8195 (2) A [political subdivision of the state] county may not enact an ordinance, resolution, or rule that:
8197 (a) for digital asset mining businesses located in unincorporated areas zoned for industrial use, imposes
sound restrictions on digital asset mining businesses that are more stringent than the generally
applicable limits set for industrial-zoned areas; or
8200 (b) prevents a digital asset mining business from operating in an unincorporated area zoned for
industrial use if the digital asset mining business meets other requirements for industrial use.
- 258 -
SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
8241 Section 214. Section 17-79-620 is renumbered and amended to read:
8243 [17-27a-540] 17-79-620. High tunnels -- Exemption from county regulation.
8207 (1) As used in this section, "high tunnel" means a structure that:
8208 (a) is not a permanent structure;
8209 (b) is used for the growing, keeping, storing, sale, or shelter of an agricultural commodity; and
8211 (c) has a:
8212 (i) metal, wood, or plastic frame;
8213 (ii) plastic, woven textile, or other flexible covering; and
8214 (iii) floor made of soil, crushed stone, matting, pavers, or a floating concrete slab.
8215 (2) A county building code does not apply to a high tunnel.
8216 (3) No building permit shall be required for the construction of a high tunnel.
8255 Section 215. Section 17-79-701 is renumbered and amended to read:
8219
Part 7. Subdivisions
8258 [17-27a-601] 17-79-701. Enactment of subdivision ordinance.
8221 (1) The legislative body of a county may enact ordinances requiring that a subdivision plat comply with
the provisions of the county's ordinances and this part before:
8223 (a) the subdivision plat may be filed and recorded in the county recorder's office; and
8224 (b) lots may be sold.
8225 (2) If the legislative body fails to enact a subdivision ordinance, the county may regulate subdivisions
only as provided in this part.
8227 (3) The joining of a lot or lots to a parcel does not constitute a subdivision as to the parcel or subject the
parcel to the county's subdivision ordinance.
8229 (4) A legislative body may adopt a land use regulation that specifies that combining lots does not
require a subdivision plat amendment.

8289 Section 217. Section 17-79-703 is renumbered and amended to read:

acknowledgment, surveyor certification, and verification of plat -- Recording plat.
8256 (1) As used in this section:
8257 (a)
(i) "Facility owner" means the same as that term is defined in Section 73-1-15.5.
8258 (ii) "Facility owner" includes a canal owner or associated canal operator contact described in:

8265 (c) "State engineer's inventory of canals" means the state engineer's inventory of water conveyance
systems established in Section 73-5-7.
8267 (d) "Underground facility" means the same as that term is defined in Section 54-8a-2.
8268 (e) "Water conveyance facility" means the same as that term is defined in Section 73-1-15.5.
8270 (2) Unless exempt under Section [17-27a-605] 17-79-708 or excluded from the definition of subdivision
under Section [17-27a-103] 17-79-102, whenever any land is laid out and platted, the owner of
the land shall provide to the county in which the land is located an accurate plat that describes or
specifies:
- 260 -
SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
8274 (a) a subdivision name that is distinct from any subdivision name on a plat recorded in the county
recorder's office;
8276 (b) the boundaries, course, and dimensions of all of the parcels of ground divided, by their boundaries,
course, and extent, whether the owner proposes that any parcel of ground is intended to be used as a

for a public purpose;
8280 (c) the lot or unit reference, block or building reference, street or site address, street name or coordinate
address, acreage or square footage for all parcels, units, or lots, and length and width of the blocks
and lots intended for sale;
8283 (d) every existing right-of-way and recorded easement located within the plat for:
8284 (i) an underground facility;
8285 (ii) a water conveyance facility; or
8286 (iii) any other utility facility; and

8288 (i) is not recorded; and

made available to the owner of the land:
8291 (A) in the state engineer's inventory of canals; or
8292 (B) from a surveyor under Subsection (6)(c).
8293 (3)
(a) Subject to Subsections (4), (6), and (7), if the plat conforms to the county's ordinances and this
part and has been approved by the culinary water authority, the sanitary sewer authority, and the
local health department, if the local health department and the county consider the local health
department's approval necessary, the county shall approve the plat.
8298 (b) Counties are encouraged to receive a recommendation from the fire authority and the public safety
answering point before approving a plat.
8300 (c) A county may not require that a plat be approved or signed by a person or entity who:
8301 (i) is not an employee or agent of the county; or
8302 (ii) does not:
8303 (A) have a legal or equitable interest in the property within the proposed subdivision;
8305 (B) provide a utility or other service directly to a lot within the subdivision;
- 261 -
SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
8306 (C) own an easement or right-of-way adjacent to the proposed subdivision who signs for the purpose of
confirming the accuracy of the location of the easement or right-of-way in relation to the plat; or
8309 (D) provide culinary public water service whose source protection zone designated as provided in

Section 32:
Section 19-4-113 is included, in whole or in part, within the proposed subdivision.
8312 (d) A county shall:
8313 (i) within 20 days after the day on which an owner of land submits to the county a complete subdivision
plat land use application, mail written notice of the proposed subdivision to the facility owner of any
water conveyance facility located, entirely or partially, within 100 feet of the subdivision plat, as
determined using information made available to the county:
8318 (A) from the facility owner under Section [10-9a-211] 17-79-211, using mapping-grade global
positioning satellite units or digitized data from the most recent aerial photo available to the facility
owner;
8321 (B) in the state engineer's inventory of canals; or
8322 (C) from a surveyor under Subsection (6)(c); and
8323 (ii) not approve the subdivision plat for at least 20 days after the day on which the county mails to each
facility owner the notice under Subsection (3)(d)(i) in order to receive any comments from each
facility owner regarding:
8326 (A) access to the water conveyance facility;
8327 (B) maintenance of the water conveyance facility;
8328 (C) protection of the water conveyance facility integrity;
8329 (D) safety of the water conveyance facility; or
8330 (E) any other issue related to water conveyance facility operations.
8331 (e) When applicable, the owner of the land seeking subdivision plat approval shall comply with Section
73-1-15.5.
8333 (f) A facility owner's failure to provide comments to a county in accordance with Subsection (3)(d)(ii)
does not affect or impair the county's authority to approve the subdivision plat.
8336 (4) The county may withhold an otherwise valid plat approval until the owner of the land provides the
legislative body with a tax clearance indicating that all taxes, interest, and penalties owing on the
land have been paid.
8339 (5)
- 262 -
SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
(a) Within 30 days after approving a final plat under this section, a county shall submit to the Utah

8353 (6)
(a) A county recorder may not record a plat unless, subject to Subsection [17-27a-604(1)] 17-79-704(1):
8355 (i) [prior to] before recordation, the county has approved and signed the plat;
8356 (ii) each owner of record of land described on the plat has signed the owner's dedication as shown
on the plat; and
8358 (iii) the signature of each owner described in Subsection (6)(a)(ii) is acknowledged as provided by
law.
8360 (b) A surveyor who prepares the plat shall certify that the surveyor:
8361 (i) holds a license in accordance with Title 58, Chapter 22, Professional Engineers and Professional
Land Surveyors Licensing Act;
8363 (ii)
(A) has completed a survey of the property described on the plat in accordance with Section
[17-23-17] 17-73-504 and has verified all measurements; or
8365 (B) has referenced a record of survey map of the existing property boundaries shown on the plat and
verified the locations of the boundaries; and
8367 (iii) has placed monuments as represented on the plat.
8368 (c)
- 263 -
SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
(i) To the extent possible, the surveyor shall consult with the owner or operator, or a representative
designated by the owner or operator, of an existing water conveyance facility located within the
proposed subdivision, or an existing or proposed underground facility or utility facility located
within the proposed subdivision, to verify the accuracy of the surveyor's depiction of the:
8373 (A) boundary, course, dimensions, and intended use of the public rights-of-way, a public or private
easement, or grants of record;
8375 (B) location of the existing water conveyance facility, or the existing or proposed underground
facility or utility facility; and
8377 (C) physical restrictions governing the location of the existing or proposed underground facility or
utility facility.
8379 (ii) The cooperation of an owner or operator of a water conveyance facility, underground facility, or
utility facility under Subsection (6)(c)(i):
8381 (A) indicates only that the plat approximates the location of the existing facilities but does not warrant
or verify their precise location; and
8383 (B) does not affect a right that the owner or operator has under Title 54, Chapter 8a, Damage to
Underground Utility Facilities, a recorded easement or right-of-way, the law applicable to
prescriptive rights, or any other provision of law.
8387 (7)
(a) Except as provided in Subsection (6)(c), after the plat has been acknowledged, certified, and
approved, the owner of the land seeking to record the plat shall, within the time period and manner
designated by ordinance, record the plat in the county recorder's office in the county in which the
lands platted and laid out are situated.
8391 (b) A failure to record a plat within the time period designated by ordinance renders the plat voidable by
the county.
8393 (8) A county acting as a land use authority shall approve a condominium plat that complies with the
requirements of Section 57-8-13 unless the condominium plat violates a land use regulation of the
county.
8434 Section 218. Section 17-79-704 is renumbered and amended to read:

8400 (1) A person may not submit a subdivision plat to the county recorder's office for recording unless:

- 264 -
SB1007 compared with SB1007S01

8405 (i) the land use authority of the:

8411 (c) all approvals described in Subsection (1)(b) are entered in writing on the plat by designated officers;
and
8413 (d) if the person submitting the plat intends the plat to be or if the plat is part of a community
association subject to Title 57, Chapter 8a, Community Association Act, the plat includes language
conveying to the association, as that term is defined in Section 57-8a-102, all common areas, as that
term is defined in Section 57-8a-102.
8417 (2) An owner of a platted lot is the owner of record sufficient to re-subdivide the lot if the owner's
platted lot is not part of a community association subject to Title 57, Chapter 8a, Community
Association Act.
8420 (3) A plat recorded without the signatures required under this section is void.
8421 (4) A transfer of land pursuant to a void plat is voidable by the land use authority.
8460 Section 219. Section 17-79-705 is renumbered and amended to read:
8462 [17-27a-604.1] 17-79-705. Process for subdivision review and approval.
8426 (1)
(a) As used in this section, an "administrative land use authority" means an individual, board, or
commission, appointed or employed by a county, including county staff or a county planning
commission.
8429 (b) "Administrative land use authority" does not include a county legislative body or a member of a
county legislative body.
8431 (2)
(a) This section applies to land use decisions arising from subdivision applications for single-family
dwellings, two-family dwellings, or townhomes.
8433 (b) This section does not apply to land use regulations adopted, approved, or agreed upon by a
legislative body exercising land use authority in the review of land use applications for zoning or
other land use regulation approvals.
8436 (3) A county ordinance governing the subdivision of land shall:
- 265 -
SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
8437 (a) comply with this section and establish a standard method and form of application for preliminary
subdivision applications and final subdivision applications; and
8439 (b)
(i) designate a single administrative land use authority for the review of preliminary applications to
subdivide land; or
8441 (ii) if the county has adopted an ordinance that establishes a separate procedure for the review and
approval of subdivisions under Section [17-27a-605] 17-79-708, the county may designate a
different and separate administrative land use authority for the approval of subdivisions under

Section 34:
Section [17-27a-605] 17-79-708.
8445 (4)
(a) If an applicant requests a pre-application meeting, the county shall, within 15 business days after the
request, schedule the meeting to review the concept plan and give initial feedback.
8448 (b) At the pre-application meeting, the county staff shall provide or have available on the county
website the following:
8450 (i) copies of applicable land use regulations;
8451 (ii) a complete list of standards required for the project;
8452 (iii) preliminary and final application checklists; and
8453 (iv) feedback on the concept plan.
8454 (5) A preliminary subdivision application shall comply with all applicable county ordinances and
requirements of this section.
8456 (6) An administrative land use authority may complete a preliminary subdivision application review in
a public meeting or at a county staff level.
8458 (7) With respect to a preliminary application to subdivide land, an administrative land use authority
may:
8460 (a) receive public comment; and
8461 (b) hold no more than one public hearing.
8462 (8) If a preliminary subdivision application complies with the applicable county ordinances and the
requirements of this section, the administrative land use authority shall approve the preliminary
subdivision application.
8465 (9) A county shall review and approve or deny a final subdivision plat application in accordance with
the provisions of this section and county ordinances, which:
- 266 -
SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
8467 (a) may permit concurrent processing of the final subdivision plat application with the preliminary
subdivision plat application; and
8469 (b) may not require planning commission or county legislative body approval.
8470 (10) If a final subdivision application complies with the requirements of this section, the applicable
county ordinances, and the preliminary subdivision approval granted under Subsection (9)(a), a
county shall approve the final subdivision application.
8511 Section 220. Section 17-79-706 is renumbered and amended to read:
8513 [17-27a-604.2] 17-79-706. Review of subdivision applications and subdivision improvement
plans.
8477 (1) As used in this section:
8478 (a) "Review cycle" means the occurrence of:
8479 (i) the applicant's submittal of a complete subdivision application;
8480 (ii) the county's review of that subdivision application;
8481 (iii) the county's response to that subdivision application, in accordance with this section; and
8483 (iv) the applicant's reply to the county's response that addresses each of the county's required
modifications or requests for additional information.
8485 (b) "Subdivision application" means a land use application for the subdivision of land located within the
unincorporated area of a county.
8487 (c) "Subdivision improvement plans" means the civil engineering plans associated with required
infrastructure improvements and county-controlled utilities required for a subdivision.
8490 (d) "Subdivision ordinance review" means review by a county to verify that a subdivision application
meets the criteria of the county's ordinances.
8492 (e) "Subdivision plan review" means a review of the applicant's subdivision improvement plans and
other aspects of the subdivision application to verify that the application complies with county
ordinances and applicable installation standards and inspection specifications for infrastructure
improvements.
8496 (2) The review cycle restrictions and requirements of this section do not apply to the review of
subdivision applications affecting property within identified geological hazard areas.
8498 (3)
(a) A county may require a subdivision improvement plan to be submitted with a subdivision
application.
- 267 -
SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
8500 (b) A county may not require a subdivision improvement plan to be submitted with both a preliminary
subdivision application and a final subdivision application.
8502 (4)
(a) The review cycle requirements of this section apply:
8503 (i) to the review of a preliminary subdivision application, if the county requires a subdivision
improvement plan to be submitted with a preliminary subdivision application; or
8506 (ii) to the review of a final subdivision application, if the county requires a subdivision
improvement plan to be submitted with a final subdivision application.
8508 (b) A county may not, outside the review cycle, engage in a substantive review of required
infrastructure improvements or a county controlled utility.
8510 (5)
(a) A county shall complete the initial review of a complete subdivision application submitted for
ordinance review for a residential subdivision for single-family dwellings, two-family dwellings, or
town homes:
8513 (i) no later than 15 business days after the complete subdivision application is submitted, if the
county has a population over 5,000; or
8515 (ii) no later than 30 business days after the complete subdivision application is submitted, if the
county has a population of 5,000 or less.
8517 (b) A county shall maintain and publish a list of the items comprising the complete subdivision
application, including:
8519 (i) the application;
8520 (ii) the owner's affidavit;
8521 (iii) an electronic copy of all plans in PDF format;
8522 (iv) the preliminary subdivision plat drawings; and
8523 (v) a breakdown of fees due upon approval of the application.
8524 (6) A county shall publish a list of the items that comprise a complete subdivision land use application.
8526 (7) A county shall complete a subdivision plan review of a subdivision improvement plan that is
submitted with a complete subdivision application for a residential subdivision for single-family
dwellings, two-family dwellings, or town homes:
8529 (a) within 20 business days after the complete subdivision application is submitted, if the county has a
population over 5,000; or
- 268 -
SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
8531 (b) within 40 business days after the complete subdivision application is submitted, if the county has a
population of 5,000 or less.
8533 (8)
(a) In reviewing a subdivision application, a county may require:
8534 (i) additional information relating to an applicant's plans to ensure compliance with county
ordinances and approved standards and specifications for construction of public improvements;
and
8537 (ii) modifications to plans that do not meet current ordinances, applicable standards, or
specifications or do not contain complete information.
8539 (b) A county's request for additional information or modifications to plans under Subsection (8)(a)(i)
or (ii) shall be specific and include citations to ordinances, standards, or specifications that require
the modifications to subdivision improvement plans, and shall be logged in an index of requested
modifications or additions.
8544 (c) A county may not require more than four review cycles for a subdivision improvement plan review.
8546 (d)
(i) Subject to Subsection (8)(d)(ii), unless the change or correction is necessitated by the applicant's
adjustment to a subdivision improvement plan or an update to a phasing plan that adjusts the
infrastructure needed for the specific development, a change or correction not addressed or
referenced in a county's subdivision improvement plan review is waived.
8551 (ii) A modification or correction necessary to protect public health and safety or to enforce state or
federal law may not be waived.
8553 (iii) If an applicant makes a material change to a subdivision improvement plan, the county has the
discretion to restart the review process at the first review of the subdivision improvement plan
review, but only with respect to the portion of the subdivision improvement plan that the material
change substantively affects.
8557 (e)
(i) This Subsection (8) applies if an applicant does not submit a revised subdivision improvement plan
within:
8559 (A) 20 business days after the county requires a modification or correction, if the county has a
population over 5,000; or
8561
- 269 -
SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
(B) 40 business days after the county requires a modification or correction, if the county has a
population of 5,000 or less.
8563 (ii) If an applicant does not submit a revised subdivision improvement plan within the time specified
in Subsection (8)(e)(i), a county has an additional 20 business days after the time specified in
Subsection (7) to respond to a revised subdivision improvement plan.
8567 (9) After the applicant has responded to the final review cycle, and the applicant has complied with
each modification requested in the county's previous review cycle, the county may not require
additional revisions if the applicant has not materially changed the plan, other than changes that
were in response to requested modifications or corrections.
8572 (10)
(a) In addition to revised plans, an applicant shall provide a written explanation in response to the
county's review comments, identifying and explaining the applicant's revisions and reasons for
declining to make revisions, if any.
8575 (b) The applicant's written explanation shall be comprehensive and specific, including citations to
applicable standards and ordinances for the design and an index of requested revisions or additions
for each required correction.
8578 (c) If an applicant fails to address a review comment in the response, the review cycle is not complete
and the subsequent review cycle may not begin until all comments are addressed.
8581 (11)
(a) If, on the fourth or final review, a county fails to respond within 20 business days, the county shall,
upon request of the property owner, and within 10 business days after the day on which the request
is received:
8584 (i) for a dispute arising from the subdivision improvement plans, assemble an appeal panel in
accordance with Subsection [17-27a-507(5)(d)] 17-79-812(5)(d) to review and approve or deny
the final revised set of plans; or
8587 (ii) for a dispute arising from the subdivision ordinance review, advise the applicant, in writing,
of the deficiency in the application and of the right to appeal the determination to a designated
appeal authority.
8628 Section 221. Section 17-79-707 is renumbered and amended to read:
8630
- 270 -
SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
[17-27a-604.5] 17-79-707. Subdivision plat recording or development activity before

8595 (1) As used in this section:
8596 (a) "Private landscaping plan" means a proposal:
8597 (i) to install landscaping on a lot owned by a private individual or entity; and
8598 (ii) submitted to a county by the private individual or entity, or on behalf of a private individual or
entity, that owns the lot.
8600 (b) "Public landscaping improvement" means landscaping that an applicant is required to install to
comply with published installation and inspection specifications for public improvements that:
8603 (i) will be dedicated to and maintained by the county; or
8604 (ii) are associated with and proximate to trail improvements that connect to planned or existing public
infrastructure.
8606 (2) A land use authority shall establish objective inspection standards for acceptance of a required
public landscaping improvement or infrastructure improvement.

or infrastructure improvements.

accordance with Subsection (5) provide completion assurance for:

improvements; or
