1 2622 [17-55-101] 17E-2-101. Definitions.
As used in this [part] chapter:
1 2586 (1) "Commission" means the State Commission on Criminal and Juvenile Justice created in Section
63M-7-201.
1 2588 (2) "Criminal justice agency" means an agency or institution directly involved in the apprehension,
prosecution, or incarceration of a person involved in criminal activity.
1 2590 (3) "Criminal justice coordinating council" or "council" means a council created by a county or counties
in accordance with Section [17-55-201] 17E-2-201.
1 2592 (4) "Criminal justice system" means the continuum of criminal justice agencies and post-incarceration
services that an individual may encounter as a result of the individual's criminal activity.
1 2595 (5)
(a) "Post-incarceration services" means services that may assist an individual who is leaving
incarceration to reintegrate into the community.
1 2597 (b) "Post-incarceration services" includes:
- 388 -
SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
1 2598 (i) educational services;
1 2599 (ii) housing services;
1 2600 (iii) health care services;
1 2601 (iv) workforce services; and
1 2602 (v) human services programs.
1 2641 Section 302. Section 17E-2-201 is renumbered and amended to read:
1 2605
Part 2. Governor and Governor's Programs
1 2644 [17-55-201] 17E-2-201. Criminal justice coordinating councils -- Creation -- Strategic plan --
Reporting requirements.
1 2608 (1)
(a) Beginning January 1, 2023, a county shall:
1 2609 (i) create a criminal justice coordinating council; or
1 2610 (ii) jointly with another county or counties, create a criminal justice coordinating council.
1 2612 (b) The purpose of a council is to coordinate and improve components of the criminal justice system in
the county or counties.
1 2614 (2)
(a) A council shall include:
1 2615 (i) one county commissioner or county council member;
1 2616 (ii) the county sheriff or the sheriff's designee;
1 2617 (iii) one chief of police of a municipality within the county or the chief's designee;
1 2618 (iv) the county attorney or the attorney's designee;
1 2619 (v) one public defender or attorney who provides public defense within the county;
1 2620 (vi) one district court judge;
1 2621 (vii) one justice court judge;
1 2622 (viii) one representative from the Division of Adult Probation and Parole created in Section
64-14-202;
1 2624 (ix) one representative from the local mental health authority within the county; and
1 2625 (x) one individual who is:
1 2626 (A) a crime victim; or
1 2627 (B) a victim advocate, as defined in Section 77-38-403.
1 2628 (b) A council may include:
- 389 -
SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
1 2629 (i) an individual representing:
1 2630 (A) local government;
1 2631 (B) human services programs;
1 2632 (C) higher education;
1 2633 (D) peer support services;
1 2634 (E) workforce services;
1 2635 (F) local housing services;
1 2636 (G) mental health or substance use disorder providers;
1 2637 (H) a health care organization within the county;
1 2638 (I) a local homeless council;
1 2639 (J) family counseling and support groups; or
1 2640 (K) organizations that work with families of incarcerated individuals; or
1 2641 (ii) an individual with lived experiences in the criminal justice system.
1 2642 (3)
(a) A member who is an elected county official shall serve as chair of the council.
1 2643 (b) The council shall elect the member to serve as chair under Subsection (3)(a).
1 2644 (4)
(a) A council shall develop and implement a strategic plan for the county's or counties' criminal justice
system that includes:
1 2646 (i) mapping of all systems, resources, assets, and services within the county's or counties' criminal
justice system;
1 2648 (ii) a plan for data sharing across the county's or counties' criminal justice system;
1 2649 (iii) recidivism reduction objectives; and
1 2650 (iv) community reintegration goals, including identifying strategies for connecting county residents
who are on probation, parole, or leaving jail or prison, including those under the custody of
the Division of Juvenile Justice and Youth Services, with county-based housing, employment,
mental health services, substance use treatment, and related resources.
1 2655 (b) The commission may assist a council in the development of a strategic plan.
1 2656 (5) As part of the council's duties described in Subsection (4)(a)(i), the council shall prepare a list of
private probation providers for a court to provide to defendants as described in Section 77-18-105.
1 2659
- 390 -
SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
(6) Before November 30 of each year, a council shall provide a written report to the commission
regarding:
1 2661 (a) the implementation of a strategic plan described in Subsection (4); and
1 2662 (b) any data on the impact of the council on the criminal justice system in the county or counties.

Section 58:
3. Office of the Lieutenant Governor
1 2668 (1) The office of the lieutenant governor shall maintain the official county boundaries for the counties
of the state and update those boundaries upon the lieutenant governor's issuance, under Section
67-1a-6.5, of an applicable certificate, as defined in that section.

the lieutenant governor shall receive the notice and map showing the true location of the county
boundary.
1 2674 (b) Nothing in Section 17-61-102 gives a county surveyor or any other individual the authority to
modify official records maintained by the office of the lieutenant governor.

1 2780
CHAPTER 4. Counties and the State Tax Commission and Division of Finance
1 2781
Part 1. General Provisions
1 2820 [17-56-101] 17E-4-101. Definitions.
As used in this chapter:
1 2784 (1) "Commission" means the State Tax Commission.
1 2785 (2) "Contributing business" means a person who is centrally assessed and owns a qualifying
transmission line.
1 2787 (3) "Division" means the Division of Finance created in Section 63A-3-101.
1 2788 [(3)] (4) "Qualifying transmission line" means an electrical transmission line that first transmits
electrical current within the state on or after January 1, 2026, and operates at a nominal voltage of at
least 340,000 volts, including structures, equipment, plant, or fixtures associated with the electrical
transmission line.

1 2875 [17-22-34] 17E-6-201. Suicide Deterrence Grant Program -- Rulemaking.
1 2839 (1) As used in this section:
1 2840 (a) "Department" means the Department of Public Safety.
1 2841 (b) "Grant" means a grant awarded under this section.
1 2842 (c) "Program" means the Suicide Deterrence Grant Program created in this section.
1 2843 (d) "Suicide barrier" means a barrier installed on an upper level of a building to prevent an individual
from falling.
1 2845 (2)
(a) There is created within the department the Suicide Deterrence Grant Program.
1 2846 (b) The purpose of the program is to award grants to county jails for materials to construct and install
suicide barriers.
1 2848 (3)
(a) A county jail that submits a proposal for a grant to the department shall include in the proposal:
1 2850 (i) a statement describing the need for suicide barriers in the county jail;
1 2851 (ii) the amount and type of material to be used in constructing the suicide barriers;
1 2852 (iii) a plan for installation of the suicide barriers;
1 2853 (iv) any funding sources in addition to the grant for the proposal;
1 2854 (v) any existing or planned partnerships between the county jail and another entity to implement the
proposal; and
1 2856 (vi) other information the department determines necessary to evaluate the proposal.
1 2857 (b) When evaluating a proposal for a grant, the department shall consider:
1 2858 (i) the likelihood the proposal will accomplish the purpose described in Subsection (2);
1 2859 (ii) the cost of the proposal;
1 2860 (iii) the extent to which additional funding sources or existing or planned partnerships may benefit the
proposal; and
- 396 -
SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
1 2862 (iv) the viability and sustainability of the proposal.
1 2863 (4) Subject to Subsection (3), the department may, in accordance with Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah
Administrative Rulemaking Act, make rules to establish:
1 2865 (a) eligibility criteria for a grant;
1 2866 (b) the form and process for submitting a proposal to the department for a grant;
1 2867 (c) the method and formula for determining a grant amount; and
1 2868 (d) reporting requirements for a grant recipient.

1 2879 (c) "Correctional facility administrator" means the same as that term is defined in Section 77-16b-102.
1 2881 [(c)] (d) "Correctional facility telephone service" means a public telecommunications service provided
to a correctional facility for inmate use.
1 2883 [(d)] (e) "Inmate" means an individual who is committed to the custody of or housed in a correctional
facility.
1 2885 [(e)] (f) "Inmate telephone rate" means any amount a correctional facility or a service provider charges
an inmate for use of a correctional facility telephone service, including each per-minute rate or
surcharge for:
1 2888 (i) a collect call, a prepaid phone card, or any other method by which a correctional facility allows an
inmate to access a correctional facility telephone service; or
1 2890 (ii) a local or a long-distance phone call.
1 2891 [(f)] (g) "Service provider" means a public entity or a private entity that provides a correctional facility
telephone service.
1 2893 (2)
- 397 -
SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
(a) A correctional facility administrator shall consider the importance of inmate access to telephones in
preserving family connections and reducing recidivism when proposing an inmate telephone rate in
a new or renewed contract for correctional facility telephone service.
1 2897 (b) A correctional facility or other state entity may not enter into or renew a contract for a correctional
facility telephone service, unless the contract is approved by the civil counsel for the county in
which the correctional facility is located.
1 2900 (c) To obtain approval of a contract described in Subsection (2)(b), a correctional facility or other state
entity shall submit to the civil counsel:
1 2902 (i) the proposed contract;
1 2903 (ii) documentation that the correctional facility or other state entity has confirmed that:
1 2905 (A) the provisions of the contract, other than the rates described in Subsection (3)(a), are consistent with
correctional facility telephone service contracts throughout the state; and
1 2908 (B) the contract provides for adequate services that meet the needs of the correctional facility; and
1 2910 (iii) any additional information the civil counsel requires to analyze the contract.
1 2911 (3)
(a) The civil counsel shall review a contract and any additional information described in Subsection [(2)
(b)] (2)(c) to determine whether:
1 2913 (i) each inmate telephone rate for interstate calls provided in the contract exceeds the corresponding
inmate telephone service monetary cap per-use rate established and published by the Federal
Communications Commission; and
1 2916 (ii) each inmate telephone rate for intrastate calls provided in the contract exceeds the greater of:
1 2918 (A) 25% higher than the corresponding inmate telephone service monetary cap per-use rate established
and published by the Federal Communications Commission; or
1 2921 (B) the corresponding inmate telephone system rate established and published by the Utah Department
of Corrections.
1 2923 (b)
(i) After receiving and reviewing the proposed contract and additional information, the civil counsel
shall approve the contract if the proposed contract meets the requirements described in Subsection
(3)(a).
1 2926 (ii) The civil counsel shall inform the correctional facility or other state entity of the civil counsel's
determination.

SB1007 compared with SB1007S01

1 2970 Section 320. Section 17E-7-101 is renumbered and amended to read:
1 2934
CHAPTER 7. Counties and Other Executive Branch Entities
1 2935
Part 1. Department of Environmental Quality
1 2974 [17-15-23] 17E-7-101. County solid waste management plans submitted to the Waste
Management and Radiation Control Board.
1 2938 (1)
(a) Each county, or entity created or designated by a county for [this] the purpose of fulfilling the
duties of this section, shall submit to the Waste Management and Radiation Control Board,
[organized in] created in Section 19-6-103, a county solid waste management plan providing solid
waste management information as reasonably required by the board and according to a timetable
established by the board.
1 2944 (b) Each county shall review and modify [its] the county solid waste management plan no less
frequently than every five years.
1 2946 (2) Each county solid waste management plan shall:
1 2947 (a) be consistent with Title 19, Chapter 6, Part 5, Solid Waste Management Act[,] ; and
1 2948 (b) [shall ]establish the county's solid waste management plan for the next 20 years.
1 2949 (3) Each county solid waste management plan shall include an estimate of the solid waste capacity
needed in the county for the next 20 years and the county's program to ensure that the county will
have sufficient solid waste disposal capacity for the next 20 years.
1 2952 (4)
(a) The solid waste management plan mandated by this section is contingent upon the adoption and
implementation of a funding mechanism.
1 2954 (b) Nothing contained in this section precludes a political subdivision, local health department, or
district from undertaking comprehensive solid waste planning.
1 2994 Section 321. Section 17E-7-201 is renumbered and amended to read:
1 2958
- 399 -
SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
Part 2. Department of Health and Human Services
1 2997 [17-27a-519] 17E-7-201. Licensing of residences for persons with a disability.
1 2962 (1) As used in this section, "residential facility for persons with a disability" means the same as that
term is defined in Section 17-79-102.
1 2964 (2) The responsibility to license local programs or entities that operate [facilities] a residential facility
for persons with a disability, as well as to require and monitor the provision of adequate services to
persons residing in those facilities, shall rest with the Department of Health and Human Services as
provided in:
1 2968 [(1)] (a) Title 26B, Chapter 2, Part 2, Health Care Facility Licensing and Inspection; and

1 3014 Section 323. Section 17E-7-401 is renumbered and amended to read:
1 2978
Part 4. Department of Natural Resources
1 3017 [17-16-22] 17E-7-401. Wildland urban interface evaluation and fees.
1 2981 (1) As used in this section:
1 2982 (a) "County officer" means the same as that term is defined in Section [17-16-21] 17-66-101.
1 2984 (b) "High risk wildland urban interface property" means the same as that term is defined in Section
65A-8-401.
1 2986 (c) "Wildland urban interface" means the same as that term is defined in Section 65A-8-401.
1 2988 (d) "Wildland urban interface coordinator" means the same as that term is defined in Section
65A-8-401.
1 2990 (2) If evaluation of high risk wildland urban interface property is assigned to a county under Section
65A-8-402:
1 2992 (a) the county shall enter into a cooperative agreement with the Division of Forestry, Fire, and State
Lands, in accordance with Subsection 65A-8-203(2)(a), which agreement shall address compliance
- 400 -
SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
with this Subsection (2) for evaluation and classification of high risk wildland urban interface
property; and
1 2996 (b) a county officer shall require that a wildland urban interface coordinator representing the county
annually evaluate high risk wildland urban interface property within the county in accordance with

Section 70:
Section 65A-8-402.
1 2999 (3) Beginning January 1, 2026, a county officer shall:
1 3000 (a) annually assess a fee:
1 3001 (i) against the property owner of high risk wildland urban interface property within the incorporated and
unincorporated portions of the county; and
1 3003 (ii) in the amount set by the Division of Forestry, Fire, and State Lands under Section 65A-8-402; and
1 3005 (b)
(i) after retaining a portion of the fee under Subsection (3)(b)(ii), transmit the fee assessed under
Subsection (3)(a) to the Division of Forestry, Fire, and State Lands for deposit into the Utah
Wildfire Fund created in Section 65A-8-217; and
1 3008 (ii) retain that portion of the fee assessed under Subsection (3)(a) necessary to pay costs incurred by
the county in implementing this section, which the county may include in the county's annual
accounting of wildfire prevention, preparedness, mitigation actions, and associated costs for
purposes of Subsection 65A-8-203(4)(c).
1 3013 (4) A county may hold a political subdivision lien on high risk wildland urban interface property for a
fee that is past due by following the procedures in Sections 17B-1-902 and 17B-1-902.1, as if the
county is a special district.

1 3073 (1) Except as provided in Subsection (2), this bill takes effect:
1 3074 (a) except as provided in Subsection (1)(b), December 6, 2025; or

Constitution, Article VII, Section 8; or

28, 2026.

1 Title 17 Recodification County Programs and Related Provisions
2025 FIRST SPECIAL SESSION
STATE OF UTAH
Chief Sponsor: Don L. Ipson
House Sponsor:James A. Dunnigan
2
3 LONG TITLE
4 General Description:
5 This bill reorganizes and renumbers provisions of the state code related to counties.
6 Highlighted Provisions:
7 This bill:
8 ▸ reorganizes and renumbers certain provisions of Title 17, Counties;
9 ▸ defines terms and modifies definitions;
1 0 ▸ enacts provisions related to counties for organizational purposes;
1 1 ▸ amends provisions related to counties for organizational purposes;
1 2 ▸ repeals provisions related to counties for organizational purposes; and
1 3 ▸ makes technical and conforming changes.
14 Money Appropriated in this Bill:
15 None
16 Other Special Clauses:
17 This bill provides a special effective date.

672
673 Be it enacted by the Legislature of the state of Utah:
674 Section 1. Section 1 is enacted to read:
675 10-7-87. Cities authorized to appoint, contract with constables.
675 (1) A city may appoint or contract with a constable to provide services described in Title 17, Chapter
78, Part 6, Constables, the same as if the city were a county.
677 (2) A constable that is appointed or contracted with a city shall comply with the provisions of Title 17,
Chapter 78, Part 6, Constables, in regard to the city the same as if the city were a county.
682 Section 2. Section 2 is enacted to read:
xref
683 10-7-88. Municipalities to approve, protect certain protection areas.
A municipality shall comply with the following provisions of Title 17, Chapter 81,
Agriculture, Industrial, and Critical Infrastructure Materials, the same as if the municipality
- 35 -

SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
were a county:
686 (1) Section 17-81-101, Definitions;
687 (2) Part 2, Proposal and Approval of Protection Area;
688 (3) Part 3, Protection of Land in a Protection Area;
689 (4) Part 4, Vested Mining Use; and
690 (5) Part 5, Open Land and Working Agricultural Land Use.
693 Section 3. Section 17-75-101 is renumbered and amended to read:
693
CHAPTER 75. General County Personnel Management
694
Part 1. General Provisions
697 [17-33-2] 17-75-101. Definitions.
As used in this chapter:
697 (1)
(a) "Appointed officer" means an individual appointed to:
698 (i) a statutory office or position; or
699 (ii) a position of employment with a county, except a special employee.
700 (b) "Appointed officer" includes an individual serving on a special, regular or full-time committee,
agency, or board, regardless of whether the individual is compensated for the individual's services.
703 (c) "Appointed officer" does not include an elected officer.
704 (2) "Assist" means to act, or offer or agree to act:
705 (a) to help, represent, aid, advise, furnish information to, or otherwise provide assistance to an
individual or business entity;
707 (b) believing that the action is of help, aid, advice, or assistance to the individual or business entity; and
709 (c) with the intent to assist the individual or business entity.
710 (3) "Authorized legislative day" means:
711 (a) a day on which the Legislature convenes for:
712 (i) the annual general session;
713 (ii) a special session;
714 (iii) a veto override session; or
715 (iv) an interim day, designated by the Legislative Management Committee described in Section
36-12-6;
- 36 -

SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
717 (b) an authorized legislative training day; or
718 (c) any other day on which a meeting of a committee, subcommittee, commission, task force, or other
entity is held, if:
720 (i) the committee, subcommittee, commission, task force, or other entity is created by statute or joint
resolution;
722 (ii) the legislator's attendance at the meeting is approved by the Legislative Management Committee
described in Section 36-12-6; and
724 (iii) service and payment for service by the legislator is not in violation of the Utah Constitution,
including Article V and Article VI, Sections 6 and 7.
726 (4) "Authorized legislative training day" means a day that a Legislative Expenses Oversight Committee,
described in Legislative Joint Rule 5-1-102 or any successor provision, designates as an authorized
legislative day for training or informational purposes, including:
730 (a) chair training;
731 (b) an issue briefing;
732 (c) legislative leadership instruction;
733 (d) legislative process training;
734 (e) legislative rules training;
735 (f) new legislator orientation; or
736 (g) another meeting to brief, instruct, orient, or train a legislator in relation to the legislator's official
duties.
738 (5) "Business entity" means to conduct business as a:
739 (a) sole proprietorship;
740 (b) partnership;
741 (c) association;
742 (d) joint venture;
743 (e) corporation;
744 (f) firm;
745 (g) trust;
746 (h) foundation;
747 (i) organization; or
748 (j) entity.
- 37 -

SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
749 (6) "Career service position" means any position in the county service except those exempted under
Section [17-33-8] 17-75-502.
751 (7) "Compensation" means anything of economic value, however designated, which is paid, loaned,
granted, given, donated or transferred to any person or business entity for or in consideration of
personal services, materials, property, or any other thing whatsoever.
754 [(2)] (8) "Council" means the career service council, a bipartisan, three-member appeals and personnel
advisory board.
756 [(3)] (9) "Director" means the director of personnel management.
757 (10) "Elected officer" means an individual elected or appointed to an office in the county.
758 [(4)] (11) "Eligible applicant" means any applicant for employment that meets the job related minimum
requirements established for a position in the career service.
760 [(5)] (12) "Eligible list" means a list of eligible applicants for employment ranked in order of relative
knowledge, skill, ability and merit.
762 [(6)] (13) "Exempt positions" means those positions which are not in the career service as specified in
Section [17-33-8] 17-75-502.
764 (14) "Governmental action" means an action on the part of a county including:
765 (a) a decision, determination, finding, ruling, or order;
766 (b) a grant, payment, award, license, contract, subcontract, transaction, decision, sanction, or approval;
or
768 (c) the denial of, or failure to act upon, a matter described in Subsection (14)(a) or (b).
769 (15) "Legislator" means:
770 (a) a member of the Utah Senate;
771 (b) a member of the Utah House of Representatives; or
772 (c) an individual who has been elected as a member described in Subsection (15)(a) or (b), but has not
yet been sworn in or begun the individual's term of office.
774 [(7)] (16) "Merit system" means a system of personnel administration based on the principles set forth
in Section [17-33-3] 17-75-402.
776 (17) "Miscarriage" means the spontaneous or accidental loss of a fetus, regardless of gestational age or
the duration of the pregnancy.
778 (18) "Officer" means an appointed officer or an elected officer.
779 [(8)] (19) "Personnel rules" means the rules the county adopts in accordance with Section 17-75-602.
- 38 -

SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
781 (20) "Position classification" means a grouping of positions under the same title which are sufficiently
similar to be compensated at the same salary range and to which the same tests of ability can be
applied.
784 [(9)] (21) "Provisional appointment" means an appointment to fill a position pending the establishment
of a register for such position.
786 (22) "Retaliatory action" means to:
787 (a) dismiss the employee;
788 (b) reduce the employee's compensation;
789 (c) fail to increase the employee's compensation by an amount that the employee is otherwise entitled to
or was promised;
791 (d) fail to promote the employee if the employee would have otherwise been promoted; or
793 (e) threaten to take an action described in Subsections (22)(a) through (d).
794 (23) "Special employee" means an individual hired on the basis of a contract to perform a special
service for the county in accordance with an award of a contract following a public bid.
797 (24) "Substantial interest" means the ownership, either legally or equitably, by an individual, the
individual's spouse, and the individual's minor children, of at least 10% of the outstanding shares of
a corporation or 10% interest in any other business entity.
802 Section 4. Section 17-75-102 is renumbered and amended to read:
804 [17-33-11.5] 17-75-102. Compliance with Labor Code requirements.
Each county shall comply with the requirements of Section 34-32-1.1.
807 Section 5. Section 17-75-102 is renumbered and amended to read:
809 [17-33-11.5] 17-75-102. Compliance with Labor Code requirements.
Each county shall comply with the requirements of Section 34-32-102.
812 Section 6. Section 17-75-103 is renumbered and amended to read:
814 [17-50-108] 17-75-103. Training requirements.
A county shall ensure that any training that the county requires of a county officer or
employee complies with Title 63G, Chapter 22, State Training and Certification Requirements.
817 Section 7. Section 17-75-201 is renumbered and amended to read:
819
Part 2. County Officer Deputies
820 [17-16-7] . Deputies and employees -- Appointments -- County legislative body consent
power -- Liability of principal -- Deputy may serve despite vacancy in office of appointing officer.
- 39 -

SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
823 (1)
(a) A county or precinct officer, including an elected county executive, except a county commissioner
or county council member, may, with the consent of the county legislative body, appoint deputies
and employees as necessary for the discharge of the duties of the county officer's office.
827 (b) The county legislative body's consent power under Subsection (1)(a) shall be defined in county
ordinance and may include consent by:
829 (i) the budget approval process;
830 (ii) approval of an allocation of a certain number of positions; or
831 (iii) approval or disapproval of the hiring of individual applicants for employment.
832 (c) A county legislative body may by ordinance delegate to the county executive the authority to
consent to the appointment of deputies and employees under this Subsection (1).
835 (2) If [the] a county clerk performs district court clerk functions, the legislative body of [that] the
county shall provide the county clerk with deputies and employees for the business of the district
[courts] court:
838 (a) as [considered necessary and advisable by ]the district court judge or judges [of the district court,
] consider necessary and advisable; and
840 (b) consistent with the level of funding for clerk services from the court administrator's office.
842 (3)
(a) Each county officer appointing a deputy shall, for each deputy appointed[, file a signed writing with
the county clerk that memorializes the appointment.] :
844 (i) sign a document that states that the county officer appointed the deputy; and
845 (ii) file the signed document with the county clerk.
846 (b) The county officer appointing the deputy is liable for all the deputy's official acts[ of the deputy].
848 (c) If the office of the county officer who appointed the deputy becomes vacant, the deputy may
continue to serve despite the vacancy.
850 (4) A sheriff in a county employing more than 100 full-time uniformed peace officers may, with the
consent of the council and the county legislative body, appoint more than one chief deputy or
undersheriff.
853 Section 8. Section 8 is enacted to read:
854 17-75-202. Compensation for deputies.
{2. County Officer Deputies}
- 40 -

SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
If a county officer has a deputy or other assistant, the salary of the deputy or assistant
shall be:
820 (1) fixed by the county legislative body; and
821 (2) a county charge.
859 Section 9. Section 17-75-301 is renumbered and amended to read:
824
Part 3. Specific Employee Benefits and Protections
862 [17-50-325] 17-75-301. Counties authorized to make benefits generally available to
employees, employee dependents, or an employee's adult designee -- Registry authorized --
Limitations.
828 (1) A county may, by ordinance enacted by the county legislative body, make benefits generally
available to:
830 (a) [all ]county employees[,] ;
831 (b) [their] the dependents[,] of county employees; and
832 (c) an unmarried employee's financially dependent or interdependent adult designee.
833 (2)
(a) Subject to Subsection (2)(b), a county may, by ordinance enacted by the county legislative body,
create a registry for adult relationships of financial dependence or interdependence.
836 (b) A county may not create or maintain a registry or other means that defines, identifies, or recognizes
and gives legal status or effect to a domestic partnership, civil union, or domestic cohabitation
relationship other than marriage.
839 (3) The [county's] following county actions are not and may not be treated the same as or substantially
equivalent to marriage:
841 (a) the county's recognition of an adult designee[,] ;
842 (b) the county's creation and maintenance of a registry under Subsection (2)(a)[,] ; and
843 (c) any certificate issued to or other designation of a person on the county's registry [are not and may
not be treated the same as or substantially equivalent to marriage] under Subsection (2)(a).
846 (4) Neither an ordinance under Subsection (1) or (2)(a) nor a registry created under Subsection (2)(a)
making an employee benefit available to an adult designee may create, modify, or affect a spousal,
marital, or parental status, duty, or right.
849 (5) An ordinance, executive order, rule, or regulation adopted or other action taken before, on, or after
May 5, 2008, that is inconsistent with this section is void.
- 41 -

SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
888 Section 10. Section 10 is enacted to read:
889 17-75-302. Bereavement leave following miscarriage or stillbirth.
Personnel rules shall provide for at least three work days of paid bereavement leave for a
county employee:
856 (1) following the end of the county employee's pregnancy by way of miscarriage or stillbirth; or
858 (2) following the end of another individual's pregnancy by way of a miscarriage or stillbirth, if:
860 (a) the county employee is the individual's spouse or partner;
861 (b)
(i) the county employee is the individual's former spouse or partner; and
862 (ii) the county employee would have been a biological parent of a child born as a result of the
pregnancy;
864 (c) the county employee provides documentation to show that the individual intended for the employee
to be an adoptive parent, as that term is defined in Section 81-13-101, of a child born as a result of
the pregnancy; or
867 (d) under a valid gestational agreement in accordance with Title 81, Chapter 5, Part 8, Gestational
Agreement, the county employee would have been a parent of a child born as a result of the
pregnancy.
907 Section 11. Section 17-75-303 is renumbered and amended to read:
909 [17-33-11] 17-75-303. Political activities of employees.
Except as otherwise provided by law or by personnel rules [and regulations promulgated]
made under this chapter for federally aided programs, county employees may voluntarily
participate in political activity subject to the following provisions:
876 (1) [No person shall be denied ] A county may not deny an individual the opportunity to become
an applicant for a position under the merit system in any covered county department [by
virtue] because of the individual's political [opinion]{s} opinions or affiliation.
879 (2) [No person employed by the ] A county may not dismiss a county employee that is employed under
the merit system [may be dismissed from service as a result] because of the county employee's
political [opinion]{s} opinions or affiliation.
882 (3) A county career service employee may:
883 (a) voluntarily contribute funds to political groups; and
884 (b) become a candidate for public office.
- 42 -

SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
885 (4) [No] A county officer or employee, whether elected or appointed, may not directly or indirectly
coerce, command, or advise any officer or employee covered under the merit system to pay, lend,
or contribute part of his or her salary or compensation or anything else of value to any party,
committee, organization, agency, or person for political purposes.
890 (5) [No] A county officer or employee, whether elected or appointed, may not attempt to make any
county officer's or employee's personnel status dependent upon the county officer's or employee's
support or lack of support for any political party, committee, organization, agency, or person
engaged in a political activity.
894 [(5)] (6) [No ] A county officer or employee may not engage in[ any] political activity during the hours
of employment.
896 (7) [nor shall any] A person may not solicit political contributions from county employees during hours
of employment for political purposes[,] .
898 (8) [but nothing] Nothing in this section [shall preclude] prohibits a county officer or employee
from voluntary contribution [by a county employee ]to [the] a political party or candidate[ of the
employee's choice].
901 [(6)] (9) Nothing contained in this chapter [shall] may be construed to permit partisan political activity

1003 Section 13. Section 17-75-305 is renumbered and amended to read:
1005 [17-15-26] 17-75-305. Leave of absence for county employee seeking election to county office.
969 (1) A county employee who has filed a declaration of candidacy under Section 20A-9-202 for a
county office may, at the county employee's discretion, take an unpaid leave of absence, subject to
applicable employee policies on giving notice before taking leave, for some or all of the period from
the filing of the declaration of candidacy until the earliest of:
974 (a) the county employee's defeat at a primary election;
975 (b) the county employee's withdrawal as a candidate for the county office; or
976 (c) the day after the regular general election for which the county employee is a candidate.
978 (2) Neither the filing of a declaration of candidacy under Section 20A-9-202 nor a leave of absence
under Subsection (1) may be used as the basis for any adverse employment action against the
employee, including discipline or termination.

1054 Section 15. Section 17-75-402 is renumbered and amended to read:
1056 [17-33-3] 17-75-402. Merit principles.
It is the policy of this state that each county may establish a personnel system
administered in a manner that will provide for the effective implementation of the following
merit principles:
1022
- 46 -

SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
(1) recruiting, selecting, and advancing county employees on the basis of [their{]} ]relative ability,
knowledge, and skills, including open consideration of qualified applicants for employment for
initial appointment;
1025 (2) [provision of equitable] providing equitable and adequate compensation to county employees{[;]}
1027 (3) training [of ] county employees as needed to assure high-quality performance;
1028 (4) [retention of] retaining county employees on the basis of the adequacy of [their] the county
employee's performance[, and] ;
1030 (5) [separation of] separating from county employees whose inadequate performance cannot be
corrected;
1032 [(5)] (6) [fair treatment of] treating applicants for employment and county employees fairly in all
aspects of personnel administration without regard to:
1034 (a) race[,] ;
1035 (b) color[,] ;
1036 (c) religion[,] ;
1037 (d) sex[,] ;
1038 (e) national origin[,] ;
1039 (f) political affiliation[,] ;
1040 (g) age[,] ; or
1041 (h) disability[, and] ;
1042 (7) [with] having proper regard for [their] each county employee's privacy and constitutional rights as
citizens;
1044 [(6)] (8) [provision of information to] providing county employees information regarding [their] a
county employee's political rights and prohibited practices under the Hatch Act; and
1047 [(7)] (9) [provision of] providing a formal procedure for processing [the] a county employee's appeals
and grievances[ of employees] without:
1049 (a) discrimination[,] ;
1050 (b) coercion[,] ;
1051 (c) restraint[,] ; or
1052 (d) [reprisal] retaliation.

1295 Section 20. Section 20 is enacted to read:
1297 17-75-601. County executive creates office of personnel management and appoints the
director
6. Office of Personnel Management
1261 (1)
(a) A county executive shall:
1262 (i) create an office of personnel management, administered by a director of personnel management;
and
1264 (ii) ensure that the director is an individual with proven experience in personnel management.
1266 (b) Except as provided in Subsection (2), the director position shall be:
1267 (i) a merit position; and
1268 (ii) filled as provided in Subsection (1)(c).
1269 (c) Except as provided in Subsection (2), the council shall:
1270 (i) advertise and recruit for the director position in the same manner as for other merit positions;
1272 (ii) select three names from an eligible list; and
1273 (iii) submit those names as recommendations to the county legislative body.
1274 (d) Except as provided in Subsection (1)(b), the county legislative body shall select an individual to
serve as director from the names submitted to it by the council.
1276 (2)
(a) As an alternative to the procedure under Subsections (1)(b), (c), and (d), and at the county
executive's discretion, the county executive may appoint a director with the advice and consent of
the county legislative body.
- 54 -

SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
1279 (b) The position of a director appointed under this Subsection (2) shall be a merit exempt position.
1281 (c) A director appointed under this Subsection (2) may be terminated by the county executive with the
consent of the county legislative body.

1604 (1) If any section or provision of this [act] chapter is declared unconstitutional or void, the fact of

and which can be retained in effect without the provision declared unconstitutional and void[,
- 64 -

SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
and it shall be the duty of the merit service commission to provide by rule for the operation and
functioning of any activity within the purpose and spirit of the act which may be or may become

1611 (2)
(a) If any provision of this chapter or the application of this chapter is found to be in conflict with any
state or federal law, conflict with which would impair funding otherwise receivable from the state
or federal government, the conflicting provision is hereby declared to be inoperative solely to the
extent of the conflict and with respect to the department, agency, or institution of the county directly
affected.
1616 (b) A conflict with state or federal law described in Subsection (2)(a) does not affect the operation of
the remainder of this chapter.

1897 Section 38. Section 17-76-209 is renumbered and amended to read:
1899 [17-30-9] 17-76-209. Preparation and expiration of eligible register -- Appointments from
eligible register -- Failure to accept appointment -- Probationary period.
1864 (1)
(a) Upon completion of an examination, the commission shall [prepare] make an eligible register
[containing] that contains the names of all [persons receiving] applicants that received a passing
grade in the order of grades earned, beginning with the highest.
1868 [(2)] (b) An eligible register [shall expire] expires not later than two years after the date of the
examination unless the commission, for good reason, [shall extend] extends the time not to exceed
one additional year.
1871 (c) [The promulgation of] When the commission makes a new eligible register[ shall automatically
cancel all ] , previous eligible registers for the same class or position are automatically canceled.
1874 (2)
(a) When a peace officer is to be appointed, the appointing authority shall request that the commission
certify three eligible applicants for the position.
1876 (b) After the appointing authority makes a request described in Subsection (2)(a):
1877 (i) the commission shall certify to the appointing authority the names of the three applicants standing
highest on the eligible register; and
1879 (ii) the appointing authority shall select and appoint one of the three applicants the commission
certifies.
1881 (c) If an applicant described in Subsection (2)(b)(ii) does not accept the appointing authority's offer of
appointment, the applicant may, in writing:
1883 (i) request that the applicant retain the applicant's place on the eligible register; and
1884 (ii) provide reasons sufficient, in the judgment of the commission, to justify the applicant's rejection of
the appointing authority's offer of appointment.
- 72 -

SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
1886 (3)
(a) A peace officer appointed under Subsection (2) shall serve a probationary period of 12 consecutive
months, during which time the appointing authority may discharge the peace officer.
1889 (b) The probationary period shall be extended as necessary for a peace officer who has not yet
satisfactorily completed an approved peace officer training program and received a certificate of
completion under Title 53, Chapter 6, Peace Officer Standards and Training Act.
1893 (c) If a peace officer remains in the position to which the peace officer was appointed after the
expiration of the probationary period, the peace officer's retention constitutes appointment to merit
status.
1896 (d) Service as a peace officer under a temporary or emergency appointment is not considered as part of
the probationary period.
1898 (e) A peace officer removed during the peace officer's probationary period may not be placed on the
eligible register again without having passed another regular examination.

2005 Section 42. Section 17-76-213 is renumbered and amended to read:
2007 [17-30-13] 17-76-213. Transfer of merit system officer.

similar position in the same class and grade in the same governmental unit.

SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
1993 (1) A merit system officer holding a permanent appointment may be demoted, reduced in pay,
suspended, or discharged for:
1995 (a) neglect of duty;

1997 (c) misconduct;
1998 (d) inefficiency, or inability to satisfactorily perform assigned duties; or
1999 (e) any act inimical to the public service.
2000 (2) No merit system officer shall be suspended for more than 30 days at one time, nor more than 60
days in one year.
2002 (3) Demotion, reduction in pay, suspension, or discharge shall be made upon order of the appointing
authority.

2107 Section 47. Section 17-76-301 is renumbered and amended to read:
2071
Part 3. Peace Officer Merit System in Counties of the First Class
2110 [17-30a-102] 17-76-301. Definitions.
As used in this part:
2074 (1) "Appointing authority" means the county sheriff or the chief executive officer of a police interlocal
entity.
2076 (2) "Commission" means the merit system commission consisting of three [persons] individuals
appointed in accordance with Section [17-30a-202] 17-76-304.
2078 (3) "Department" means a county sheriff's office or a police interlocal entity.
2079 (4) "Eligible appointment register" means the list made by a commission described in Section
17-76-310 that contains the names of all applicants that took the examination and that received a
passing grade.
2082 (5) "Examination" means the competitive examination to determine the qualification of an applicant for
a position as a peace officer described in Section 17-76-307.
- 78 -

SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
2084 [(4)] (6) "Legislative body" means the county legislative body or the governing body of the police
interlocal entity.
2086 [(5)] (7) "Merit system officer" means a peace officer who has merit status as defined in this
[chapter] part.
2088 [(6)] (8) "Peace officer" means a paid deputy sheriff or law enforcement officer, other than a chief
deputy or other exempt appointed officer designated by the appointing authority, who is in the
continuous employ of the appointing authority.
2091 [(7)] (9) "Police interlocal entity" means an interlocal entity, as defined in Section 11-13-103, created:
2093 (a) under Title 11, Chapter 13, Interlocal Cooperation Act, by an agreement to which a county of the
first class is a party; and
2095 (b) to provide law enforcement service to an area that includes the unincorporated part of the county.

This [chapter] part applies to a county of the first class or a police interlocal entity in
which a county of the first class is a party to an interlocal agreement to provide law
enforcement service.

2325 Section 56. Section 17-76-310 is renumbered and amended to read:
2327 [17-30a-305] 17-76-310. Preparation and expiration of eligible appointment register --
Appointments from eligible appointment register -- Failure to accept appointment -- Probationary
period.
2292 (1) Upon completion of an examination, the commission shall prepare and adopt an eligible
appointment register containing the names of applicants receiving a passing grade ranked in the
order of grades earned, beginning with the highest.
2295 (2)
(a) An eligible appointment register shall expire not later than two years after the date of the
examination unless the commission, for good reason, extends the time not to exceed one additional
year.
2298 (b) If the commission adopts a new eligible appointment register, a previous eligible appointment
register for the same class or position is cancelled.
2300 (3) If the appointment of a peace officer is an appointment based on an examination, the appointing
authority shall request that the commission certify eligible applicants for each position.
2303 (4)
(a) The commission shall certify, to the appointing authority, a number of names equal to three times
the number of allocations being filled.
2305 (b) The names of the applicants shall be ranked in order of examination score, beginning with the name
of the applicant standing highest on the eligible appointment register.
2307 (5) The appointing authority shall select a person described in Subsection (4)(b) and appoint one person
to each open position.
2309 (6) If a certified applicant fails to accept a proffered appointment, the applicant:
2310 (a) may request in writing that the applicant be able to retain the applicant's place on the eligible
appointment register; and
2312 (b) shall provide reasons sufficient, in the judgment of the commission, to justify the applicant's failure
to accept.
2314
- 85 -

SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
(7) A peace officer appointed under Subsection (5) shall serve a probationary period of 12 consecutive
months, during which time the officer may be discharged at the appointing authority's sole
discretion.
2317 (8)
(a) At the request of the appointing authority, and with the approval of the commission, the
probationary period may be extended beyond 12 months for a peace officer who has not yet
satisfactorily completed an approved peace officer training program and received a certificate of
completion under Title 53, Chapter 6, Peace Officer Standards and Training Act.
2322 (b) At the request of the appointing authority, and with the approval of the commission, the
probationary period of a peace officer may be extended beyond 12 months for good cause shown.
2325 (c) Service under a temporary or part-time appointment is not considered a part of the probationary
period.
2327 (9) If a peace officer is retained in a position after the expiration of the probationary period, the peace
officer's retention constitutes appointment to merit status.
2329 (10) A person removed from employment during the probationary period may not be placed on the
eligible appointment register again without having passed another regular examination.
2332 (11) The commission may make or adopt policies governing probationary periods for other
appointments, including the appointing or transfer of a peace officer from another jurisdiction.
2373 Section 57. Section 17-76-311 is renumbered and amended to read:
2375 [17-30a-308] 17-76-311. Vacancies -- Positions requiring special qualifications -- Competition
suspended -- Promotion -- Promotion register.
2339 (1) [In case of] When there is a vacancy in a position requiring peculiar and exceptional qualifications
of a scientific, professional, or expert character, [and] the commission may, after a public hearing
and unanimous vote by the commission, suspend competition regarding the position upon
satisfactory evidence that:
2343 (a) [competition] competitive hiring is impracticable; and
2344 (b) the position can best be filled by the selection of [some designated person] an individual of
recognized attainments[, the commission may, after a public hearing and by unanimous vote,
suspend competition regarding that position].
2347 (2) The commission shall report a suspension under Subsection (1) in the commission minutes, together
with the reason for suspension.
- 86 -

SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
2349 (3) With the exception of an appointment made in accordance with a commission rule adopted under
[Subsection 17-30a-203(1)(b)(i)(H)] Subsection 17-76-305(1)(b)(i)(H), a department shall fill a
supervisor vacancy in the merit system classification by promotion insofar as possible.
2353 (4)
(a) A department shall make a promotion only after an open competitive examination, admission to
which shall be limited to merit system officers.
2355 (b) [An] A promotion examination process described in Subsection (4)(a) shall include consideration
of the seniority and competence of the [peace] merit system officer to perform the duties required in
the position for which application is made.
2358 (c) The seniority element of the promotion examination may not exceed 40% of the entire examination
score.
2360 (5)
(a) After a promotional examination, the commission shall prepare a promotional eligible appointment
register that shall take precedence over any previously existing eligible appointment register.
2363 (b) The certified promotional eligible appointment register shall consist of three names for the initial
vacancy and one more name for each additional vacancy, ranked in the order of the examination
score, beginning with the highest scoring applicant.
2404 Section 58. Section 17-76-312 is renumbered and amended to read:
2406 [17-30a-310] 17-76-312. Temporary and part-time appointment.
2370 (1) A department may appoint an employee to a temporary appointment for a period not exceeding 120
days within any [12 month] 12-month period.
2372 (2) A temporary employee is not a merit system officer and may be appointed without examination.
2374 (3) A department may appoint an employee to a part-time appointment for a period not to exceed 29
hours per week.
2376 (4) A part-time employee is not a merit system officer and may be appointed without examination.
2416 Section 59. Section 17-76-313 is renumbered and amended to read:
2418 [17-30a-311] 17-76-313. Temporary layoffs -- Reappointment register.
2382 (1) Subject to Subsections (2) and (3), and if necessary, because of lack of funds or work, a department
may temporarily lay off a merit system officer.
2384
- 87 -

SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
(2) A department that lays off a merit system officer under Subsection (1) shall lay off the merit system
officer according to the seniority of the merit system officers of the class of positions affected,
following the process prescribed by commission rule.
2387 (3) A department shall lay off [a person] an individual serving under temporary or part-time
appointment before a merit system officer.
2389 (4)
(a) If a merit system officer is laid off, the department shall place the merit system officer on [a] an
eligible reappointment register to be reappointed in the inverse order in which the officer is laid off.
2392 (b) The eligible reappointment register described in Subsection (4)(a) takes precedence over all other
eligible reappointment registers.

position in the same class and grade within the department.
2399 (2) A merit system officer may be voluntarily reassigned, including to another class and grade, in
accordance with rules adopted by the commission.

2417 (b) Leave granted under Subsection (1)(a) is without pay and for a period not to exceed one year.

(c) In accordance with applicable law or ordinance, the appointing authority may reappoint the merit

2421 (2)

the period of time the officer remains sheriff or in a merit-exempt appointment.
2425 (b) At the end of the period of election to sheriff or suspension of merit status under Subsection (2)(a),

2467 Section 63. Section 17-76-317 is renumbered and amended to read:
2469 [17-30a-402] 17-76-317. Disciplinary charges and merit system officer grievances -- Appeal
to commission -- Hearings -- Findings -- Appeal to district court -- Scope of review.
2434 (1) An appointing authority may demote, suspend, discharge, or reduce a merit system officer's pay for:
2436 (a) neglect of duty;
2437 (b) disobedience of a reasonable order;
2438 (c) misconduct;
2439 (d) inefficiency or inability to satisfactorily perform assigned duties; or
2440 (e) an act inimical to public service.
2441 (2) A department may not suspend a merit system officer for more than 176 work hours at one time, or
for more than 352 work hours in one year.
2443 (3) The appointing authority shall order the demotion, reduction in pay, suspension, or discharge of a
merit system officer.
2445 (4) The appointing authority:
2446 (a) may impose disciplinary charges in accordance with a rule, policy, ordinance, or law; and
2448 (b) shall serve the merit system officer to be disciplined with a copy of the written charges.
2450 (5)
(a) A disciplined merit system officer may file an appeal of the disciplinary charges with the
department, which shall conduct the appeal internally.
2452 (b) The department shall conduct an appeal in accordance with policies made by the appointing
authority.
- 89 -

SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
2454 (6) If the disciplinary charges are sustained on internal appeal, the merit system officer may appeal to
the commission in accordance with the provisions of this section and commission policy.
2457 (7)
(a) A merit system officer disciplined in accordance with Subsection (1) may, within 10 calendar days
after the day on which the department makes the appeal decision described in Subsection (5), make
an appeal in writing to the commission.
2460 (b) If the merit system officer fails to make an internal appeal of the disciplinary action, the merit
system officer may not appeal to the commission.
2462 (8) The commission may hear appeals regarding demotion, reduction in pay, suspension, or discharge of
a merit system officer for any cause provided in Subsection (1).
2464 (9)
(a) The commission shall:
2465 (i) fix a time and place for a hearing on the appeal; and
2466 (ii) give notice of the hearing to the parties.
2467 (b)
(i) Except as provided in Subsection (9)(b)(ii), the commission shall hold a hearing under this
Subsection (9) no less than 10 and no more than 90 days after the day on which an appeal is filed.
2470 (ii) The commission may hold a hearing more than 90 days after the day on which an appeal is filed if:
2472 (A) the parties agree; or
2473 (B) the commission finds that the delay is for good cause.
2474 (c)
(i) The commission shall hold the hearing in accordance with Title 52, Chapter 4, Open and Public
Meetings Act.
2476 (ii) Notwithstanding Subsection (9)(c)(i), if the commission proposes to and is authorized to close the
hearing to the public in accordance with Title 52, Chapter 4, Open and Public Meetings Act, the
commission shall open the meeting to the public if the aggrieved merit system officer requests that
the commission open the hearing.
2481 (d) The parties may be represented by counsel at the hearing.
2482 (10) The commission, on the commission's own motion or at the request of the appointing authority,
may dismiss an appeal for unjustified delay, removal to a court or other venue, or for other good
cause shown.
- 90 -

SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
2485 (11) In resolving an appeal, the commission may sustain, modify, or vacate a decision of the appointing
authority.
2487 (12) After the hearing described in Subsection (9), the commission shall publish a written decision,
including findings of fact and conclusions of law, and shall notify each party.
2489 (13) A person may appeal a final action or order of the commission to the Court of Appeals for review.
2491 (a) A person shall file a notice of appeal within 30 days of the issuance of the final action or order of the
commission.
2493 (b) The Court of Appeals shall base the court's review on the record of the commission and for the
purpose of determining if the commission has abused the commission's discretion or exceeded the
commission's authority.
2534 Section 64. Section 17-76-318 is renumbered and amended to read:
2536 [17-30a-314] 17-76-318. Prohibitions against political activities -- Penalties.
2500 (1)
(a) An officer, employee, or member of a governing body of a county or a police interlocal entity,
whether elected or appointed, may not directly or indirectly coerce, command, or advise a merit
system officer to pay, lend, or contribute part of the merit system officer's salary or compensation or
anything else of value to a party, committee, organization, agency, or person for political purpose.
2505 (b) A county or police interlocal entity officer, employee, or member of a governing body, whether
elected or appointed, may not make or attempt to make a merit system officer's personnel status
dependent upon the merit system officer's support or lack of support for a political party, committee,
organization, agency, or person engaged in a political activity.
2510 (2) Subsection (1) does not apply to political speeches or use of mass communications media for
political purposes by [a person] an individual where a merit system officer is present, unless the
purpose and intent of the speaker is to violate this section with direct respect to those merit system
officers.
2514 (3)
(a) Except as provided in Subsection (3)(b), a merit system officer may not engage in a political activity
or solicit political contributions from merit system officers during the hours of employment, or use
employer resources at any time for political purposes.
2518 (b) Subsection (3)(a) does not preclude a voluntary contribution by a merit system officer to the party or
candidate of the merit system officer's choice.

SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
2558 Section 65. Section 65 is enacted to read:
2560 17-76-401. Definitions.
4. Provisions Unique to Law Enforcement Officers
As used in this section:
2524 (1) "Commission" means the same as that term is defined in Sections 17-76-201 and 17-76-301.
2526 (2) "Nonexempt employee" means a county employee who is nonexempt under the requirements of the
Fair Labor Standards Act of 1978, 29 U.S.C. Sec. 201 et seq.
2528 (3) "Overtime" means hours worked in excess of a nonexempt employee's work period.
2529 (4) "Regular hourly rate" means the hourly rate of pay a nonexempt employee receives for hours
worked during a work period.
2531 (5) "Work period" means the maximum number of hours, within a specified number of consecutive
days, that a nonexempt employee may work before the nonexempt employee is compensated for
overtime.

2542 [(c) "Regular hourly rate" means the hourly rate of pay a nonexempt employee receives for hours
worked during a work period.]
2544 [(d) "Work period" means the maximum number of hours, within a specified number of consecutive
days, that a nonexempt employee may work before the nonexempt employee is compensated for
overtime.]
2547 [(2)] (1) This section does not apply to a county subject to [Chapter 30a, Peace Officer Merit System in
Counties of the First Class Act] Part 3, Peace Officer Merit System in Counties of the First Class.

2612 Section 69. Section 17-76-502 is renumbered and amended to read:
2614 [17-28-1] 17-76-502. County fire civil service councils created.
2577 (1) There is created in each of the counties of this state having and maintaining a regularly organized
fire department in which there are regularly employed four or more paid firefighters, a [County Fire
Civil Service Council] county fire civil service council consisting of three members to be appointed
by the county executive.
2581 (2) Each member of the council shall serve for a term of three years except that the county executive
shall appoint the original council members as follows:
2583 (a) one member for a period of one year;
2584 (b) one member for a period of two years; and
2585 (c) one member for a period of three years.
2624 Section 70. Section 17-76-503 is renumbered and amended to read:
2626 [17-28-2] 17-76-503. Vacancies -- Compensation -- Removal from office.
- 93 -

SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
2590 (1) Any vacancy occurring on the [County Fire Civil Service Council] council shall be filled by
appointment by the county executive for the unexpired term.
2592 (2) A council member[ of the council] may not hold, during the term of the council member's office,
any other public office or be a candidate for any other public office.
2594 (3)
(a) Each council member shall receive $50 for each meeting of the council attended by the council
member.
2596 (b) The county legislative body may raise the compensation of a council member as the county
legislative body considers appropriate.
2598 (c) The compensation and allowance described in Subsections (3)(a) and (b) shall be a charge against
the county and paid monthly.
2600 (4)
(a) In case of misconduct, willful neglect, or an inability to perform the duties of the council member's
office, a council member may be removed from office by the county legislative body upon a
majority vote of the county legislative body.
2603 (b) A county legislative body that moves to remove a council member from office under Subsection (4)
(a) shall provide the council member with the opportunity to be heard in the council member's own
defense.

2704 Section 73. Section 17-76-506 is renumbered and amended to read:
2706 [17-28-2.4] 17-76-506. County Fire Civil Service System rules and policies.
2670 (1) The executive director shall recommend[ rules and] policies for the County Fire Civil Service
System, which shall be subject to approval by the county legislative body.
2672 (2) The County Fire Civil Service System [rules] policies shall provide for recruiting activities,
including the recruiting of minorities and women, job-related minimum requirements, selection
procedures, certification procedures, appointments, probationary periods, promotion, position
classification, recordkeeping, reductions in force, grievances and complaints, disciplinary action,
work hours, holidays, and other necessary and proper requirements not inconsistent with this
[chapter] part.
2678 (3) The executive director shall publish or cause to be published [these rules and ]policies made or
adopted under this section in a manual form, to be updated regularly and made available to fire
department employees.
2681 (4) The County Fire Civil Service System shall be established and administered in a manner that will
provide for the effective implementation of the following merit principles:
2683 (a) recruiting, selecting, and advancing employees on the basis of the employee's relative ability,
knowledge, and skills, including open consideration of qualified applicants for initial appointment;
2686 (b) provision of equitable and adequate job classification and compensation systems, including pay and
benefits programs;
2688 (c) training of employees as needed to assure high-quality performance;
- 96 -

SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
2689 (d) retention of employees on the basis of the adequacy of the employee's performance and separation
of employees whose inadequate performance cannot be corrected;
2691 (e) fair treatment of applicants and employees in all aspects of personal administration without regard
to race, color, religion, sex, national origin, political affiliation, age, or disability, and with proper
regard for their privacy and constitutional rights as citizens;
2695 (f) provision of information to employees regarding the employee's political rights and prohibited
practices under the Hatch Act; and
2697 (g) provision of a formal procedure for processing the appeals and grievances of employees without
discrimination, coercion, restraint, or reprisal.

2703 (1)

2801 (3)

may appoint an administrative law judge, trained and experienced in personnel matters, to initially
hear the matter.
2804 (b) Upon hearing, the administrative law judge shall make findings of fact and a recommendation to the
council.
2806 (c) The council may:
2807 (i) adopt or reject the recommendation of the administrative law judge; or
2808 (ii) request that the administrative law judge hold further factual hearings prior to the council's decision.
2810 (4) The council may then affirm, modify, vacate, or set aside the order for disciplinary action.
2812 (5) The aggrieved party shall, upon demand, be granted a public hearing, at which [he] the aggrieved
party may appear in person or by counsel or both.

shall be certified to the head of the county fire department from whose order the appeal is taken.
2817 (b) Notice in writing of the determination of the council shall be served upon the [person] individual
affected.
2819 (7) The council determination shall be enforced and followed by the head of the fire department until an
appeal is taken to the district court by any affected [person] individual.
2821 (8)
- 100 -

SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
(a) An individual aggrieved by a determination of the council described in Subsection (6) may, within
30 days after notice of the council's determination, file an action in the district court of the county
or in the county of the aggrieved individual's residence, against the council in the council's official
capacity, setting out the individual's grievance and right to complain.
2826 (b) In the council's answer to the complaint described in Subsection (8)(a), the council may set out any
matter in justification.
2828 (9) The court shall determine the issues of both questions of law and fact and may affirm, set aside, or
modify the council ruling.

CHAPTER 77. Local Health and Human Service

Part 1. General Provisions
2872 [17-43-102] 17-77-101. Definitions.

2836 (1) "Assisted outpatient treatment" means the same as that term is defined in Section 26B-5-301.
2838 (2) "Crisis worker" means the same as that term is defined in Section 26B-5-610.
2839 (3) "Department" means the Department of Health and Human Services created in Section 26B-1-201.
2841 [(2)] (4) "Division" means the Division of Integrated Healthcare within the department.
2842 [(3)] (5) "First responder" means:
2843 (a) a law enforcement officer, as that term is defined in Section 53-13-103;
2844 (b) emergency medical service personnel, as that term is defined in Section 53-2d-101;
2845 (c) an emergency medical technician, as that term is defined in Section 53-2e-101;
2846 (d) an advanced emergency medical technician, as that term is defined in Section 53-2e-101;
2848 (e) a firefighter, as that term is defined in Section 53B-8c-102;
2849 (f) a dispatcher, as that term is defined in Section 53-6-102; or
2850 (g) a mobile outreach social worker.
2851 (6) "Local mental health crisis line" means the same as that term is defined in Section 26B-5-610.
2853 (7) "Mental health therapist" means the same as that term is defined in Section 58-60-102.
2854 (8) "Public funds":
2855 (a) means:
2856 (i) federal money received from the department;
- 101 -

SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
2857 (ii) state money appropriated by the Legislature to the department, a county governing body, or a local
substance abuse authority for the purposes of providing substance abuse programs or services; and

mental health authority for the purposes of providing mental health programs or services; and

Mental Health;
3315 (ix) comply with all applicable state and federal:

3319 (D) contract requirements[,] ; and
3320 (E) any directives resulting from those audits and contract requirements;

described in the plan;

3325 (B) Title 17B, Chapter 1, Part 6, Fiscal Procedures for Special Districts[,] ; and
3326 (C) Title 51, Chapter 2a, Accounting Reports from Political Subdivisions, Interlocal Organizations, and
Other Local Entities Act;
3328 (xii) take and retain physical custody of minors committed to the physical custody of local mental
health authorities by a judicial proceeding under Title 26B, Chapter 5, Part 4, Commitment of
Persons Under Age 18; and
3331 (xiii) cooperate with the Department of Corrections to complete the requirements described in
[Subsection 64-13-21(8)] Section 64-14-204.

3633 Section 96. Section 96 is enacted to read:
3636 17-78-101. Definitions.
78. County Property, Programs, and Entities
1. County Property - General Provisions
As used in this chapter:
3600 (1) "Adjusted present value" means:
3601 (a) the disposition price; plus
3602 (b) the anticipated future value.
3603 (2)
(a) "Anticipated future value" means the total value of all reasonably anticipated future benefits to a
county from the disposal of a significant parcel of real property, including:
3606 (i) increased tax revenues; and
3607 (ii) job creation or maintenance.
3608 (b) "Anticipated future value" does not include the present fair market value of the significant parcel of
real property.
3610 (3) "Dispose" means to sell or lease.
3611
- 123 -

SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
(4) "Disposition price" means the price a potential purchaser or lessee offers to pay in exchange for the
sale or lease of a significant parcel of real property.
3613 (5) "Federal agency" means any department of the executive branch of the federal government.
3615 (6) "Flood plain" means the land along the course of a river or stream which is periodically flooded and
for which flood control protective works would normally be provided or desirable.

3658 [17-50-310] 17-78-102. County powers regarding property, water rights, and water facilities
-- Retainage.
3622 (1) A county may:
3623 (a) purchase, receive by donation, or lease any real or personal property or water rights necessary for
the use of the county;
3625 (b)
(i) purchase or otherwise acquire the necessary real estate upon which to sink wells to obtain water for
sprinkling roads and for other county purposes;
3627 (ii) [ and erect thereon] erect pumping apparatus, tanks, and reservoirs on county-owned property for
obtaining and storing water for such purposes; and
3629 (iii) preserve, take care of, manage, and control [that] real estate described in Subsection (1)(b)(i) and
[those] facilities described in Subsection (1)(b)(ii);
3631 (c) purchase, receive by donation, or lease any water rights or stock or rights in reservoirs or storage
companies or associations for the use of citizens of the county;
3633 (d) construct dams and canals for the storage and distribution of waters [referred to] described in
Subsection (1)(c); and
3635 (e) fix the price for and sell water, water rights, stock, or rights in reservoir or storage companies or
associations, with the dams and canals, as are not required for public use to citizens of the county.

section is retained or withheld, it shall be retained or withheld and released as provided in Section
13-8-5.

3681 [17-50-312] 17-78-103. Acquisition, management, and disposal of property.
3645 [(1) As used in this section:]

- 124 -

SB1007 compared with SB1007S01

3654 [(ii) "Anticipated future value" does not include the present fair market value of the significant parcel of
real property.]
3656 [(c) "Dispose" means to sell or lease.]
3657 [(d) "Disposition price" means the price a potential purchaser or lessee offers to pay in exchange for the
sale or lease of a significant parcel of real property.]
3659 [(2)] (1) Subject to Subsection [(5)] (4), a county may purchase, receive, hold, sell, lease, convey, or
otherwise acquire and dispose of any real or personal property or any interest in such property if the
action is in the public interest and complies with other law.
3662 [(3)] (2) Any property interest acquired by the county shall be held in the name of the county unless
specifically otherwise provided by law.
3664 [(4)] (3) The county legislative body shall provide by ordinance, resolution, rule, or regulation for the
manner in which property shall be acquired, managed, and disposed of.
3666 [(5)] (4)
(a) Before a county may dispose of a significant parcel of real property, the county shall:
3668 (i) provide reasonable notice of the proposed disposition at least 14 days before the opportunity for
public comment under Subsection [(5)(a)(ii)] (4)(a)(ii); and
3670 (ii) allow an opportunity for public comment on the proposed disposition.
3671 (b) Each county shall, by ordinance, define what constitutes:
3672 (i) a significant parcel of real property for purposes of Subsection [(5)(a)] (4)(a); and
3673 (ii) reasonable notice for purposes of Subsection [(5)(a)(i)] (4)(a)(i).
3674 [(6)] (5)
(a) A county may dispose of a significant parcel of real property in exchange for less than the present
fair market value of the significant parcel of real property if the adjusted present value of the
- 125 -

SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
significant parcel of real property is equal to or greater than the present fair market value of the
significant parcel of real property.
3678 (b) Subsection [(6)(a)] (5)(a) does not affect a county's authority to dispose of a significant parcel of
real property in a manner different from Subsection [(6)(a)] (5)(a) and in accordance with applicable
law.
3681 [(7)] (6) Before a county agrees to dispose of a significant parcel of real property, the county may
require the potential purchaser or lessee to provide evidence that:
3683 (a) the potential purchaser's or lessee's offer is bona fide;
3684 (b) the potential purchaser or lessee has the ability to pay the disposition price; or
3685 (c) any future benefits to the county from the disposal of the significant parcel of real property are
reasonably anticipated.
3687 [(8)] (7) If a county receives an unsolicited offer to purchase or lease a significant parcel of real
property:
3689 (a) the county is not required to consider the offer; and
3690 (b) a person may not consider the offer in determining the present fair market value of the significant
parcel of real property, unless considering the offer is warranted under generally accepted standards
of professional appraisal practice.
3693 [(9)] (8) A county may presume that the present fair market value of a significant parcel of real property
is equal to the average of two appraised values each of which is based upon fair market value and
calculated by a unique, independent appraiser who is licensed or certified in accordance with Title
61, Chapter 2g, Real Estate Appraiser Licensing and Certification Act.

[17-8-1] 17-78-301. Powers of county -- Contracts with United States -- Construction of flood
control project.

, for the construction of any flood control project within the county designed to:
3753 (1) abate or control flood waters or any excessive or unusual accumulation of water in any natural or
artificial basin, stream, or body of water; or
3755 (2) for the protection of life and property against the danger, menace, injury, or damage resulting from
[said waters] any natural or artificial basin, stream, or body of water.

shall be borne by the county entering into the cooperative contract with the United States of

channels.
3800 (2) The county may cause [such] channels, storm sewers, and drains described in Subsection (1)(b)
to be surveyed, and the county legislative body may, by ordinance, establish their location and
dimensions.
3803 (3)
(a) The county legislative body may promulgate regulations to prevent the destruction or obstruction
of [these] channels, storm sewers, and drains, and may provide for the enforcement of those
regulations.
3806 (b) The county legislative body may also provide for the maintenance, improvement, and fencing of all
such channels, including covering or replacement with buried conduits.
3809 (c) To implement the establishment, clearing, protection, and continued use of such channels, storm
sewers, and drains, the county may acquire, by right of eminent domain necessary easements and
[rights of way] rights-of-way.
3812 (4) All laws and sanitary regulations against the pollution of water in natural streams, canals, and lakes
shall be enforced by:
3814 (a) the county [executives in their respective counties,] officers;
3815 (b) [or, by ]the state, through the attorney general and in co-operation with the state board of health,
state fish and game commission[,] ; and
3817 (c) the several county legislative bodies.

and present flood plains.[ Flood plain as used herein means the lands along the course of the river or
stream which is periodically flooded and for which flood control protective works would normally
be provided or desirable.]

3910 [17-50-306] 17-78-402. Granting franchises over public roads -- Limitation.
3874 (1) A county may grant franchises along and over the public roads and highways for all lawful
purposes, upon such terms, conditions, and restrictions as in the judgment of the county legislative
body are necessary and proper, to be exercised in such manner as to present the least possible
obstruction and inconvenience to the traveling public.
3878 (2) A franchise under Subsection (1) may not be granted for a period longer than 50 years.
3917 Section 113. Section 17-78-403 is renumbered and amended to read:

3882 (1) Subject to Subsection (2), a county may grant, on such terms, conditions, and restrictions as in

tolls on public roads or highways whenever in the judgment of the county executive the expense of
operating or maintaining the roads or highways as free public highways is too great to justify the
