6135 Section 174. Section 17-79-302 is renumbered and amended to read:
6137 [17-27a-302] 17-79-302. Planning commission powers and duties -- Training requirements.
6101 (1) Each countywide, planning advisory area, or mountainous planning district planning commission
shall, with respect to the unincorporated area of the county, the planning advisory area, or the
mountainous planning district, review and make a recommendation to the county legislative body
for:
6105 (a) a general plan and amendments to the general plan;
6106 (b) land use regulations, including:
6107 (i) ordinances regarding the subdivision of land within the county; and
6108 (ii) amendments to existing land use regulations;
6109 (c) an appropriate delegation of power to at least one designated land use authority to hear and act on a
land use application;
6111 (d) an appropriate delegation of power to at least one appeal authority to hear and act on an appeal from
a decision of the land use authority; and
- 196 -

SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
6113 (e) application processes that:
6114 (i) may include a designation of routine land use matters that, upon application and proper notice, will
receive informal streamlined review and action if the application is uncontested; and
6117 (ii) shall protect the right of each:
6118 (A) land use applicant and adversely affected party to require formal consideration of any application
by a land use authority;
6120 (B) land use applicant or adversely affected party to appeal a land use authority's decision to a separate
appeal authority; and
6122 (C) participant to be heard in each public hearing on a contested application.
6123 (2) Before making a recommendation to a legislative body on an item described in Subsection
(1)(a) or (b), the planning commission shall hold a public hearing in accordance with Section
[17-27a-404] 17-79-404.
6126 (3) A legislative body may adopt, modify, or reject a planning commission's recommendation to the
legislative body under this section.
6128 (4) A legislative body may consider a planning commission's failure to make a timely recommendation
as a negative recommendation.
6130 (5) Nothing in this section limits the right of a county to initiate or propose the actions described in this
section.
6132 (6)
(a)
(i) This Subsection (6) applies to a county that:
6133 (A) is a county of the first, second, or third class; and
6134 (B) has a population in the county's unincorporated areas of 5,000 or more.
6135 (ii) The population for each county described in Subsection (6)(a)(i) shall be derived from:
6137 (A) an estimate of the Utah Population Committee created in Section 63C-20-103; or
6139 (B) if the Utah Population Committee estimate is not available, the most recent official census or census
estimate of the United States Bureau of the Census.
6141 (b) A county described in Subsection (6)(a)(i) shall ensure that each member of the county's planning
commission completes four hours of annual land use training as follows:
6144 (i) one hour of annual training on general powers and duties under Title 17, Chapter 27a, County Land
Use, Development, and Management Act; and
- 197 -

SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
6146 (ii) three hours of annual training on land use, which may include:
6147 (A) appeals and variances;
6148 (B) conditional use permits;
6149 (C) exactions;
6150 (D) impact fees;
6151 (E) vested rights;
6152 (F) subdivision regulations and improvement guarantees;
6153 (G) land use referenda;
6154 (H) property rights;
6155 (I) real estate procedures and financing;
6156 (J) zoning, including use-based and form-based; and
6157 (K) drafting ordinances and code that complies with statute.
6158 (c) A newly appointed planning commission member may not participate in a public meeting as an
appointed member until the member completes the training described in Subsection (6)(b)(i).
6161 (d) A planning commission member may qualify for one completed hour of training required under
Subsection (6)(b)(ii) if the member attends, as an appointed member, 12 public meetings of the
planning commission within a calendar year.
6164 (e) A county shall provide the training described in Subsection (6)(b) through:
6165 (i) county staff;
6166 (ii) the Utah Association of Counties; or
6167 (iii) a list of training courses selected by:
6168 (A) the Utah Association of Counties; or
6169 (B) the Division of Real Estate created in Section 61-2-201.
6170 (f) A county shall, for each planning commission member:
6171 (i) monitor compliance with the training requirements in Subsection (6)(b); and
6172 (ii) maintain a record of training completion at the end of each calendar year.
6211 Section 175. Section 17-79-303 is renumbered and amended to read:
6213 [17-27a-306] 17-79-303. Planning advisory areas -- Notice of hearings.
6177 (1)
(a) A planning advisory area may be established as provided in this Subsection (1).
6178
- 198 -

SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
(b) A planning advisory area may not be established unless the area to be included within the proposed
planning advisory area:
6180 (i) is unincorporated;
6181 (ii) is contiguous; and
6182 (iii)
(A) contains:
6183 (I) at least 20% but not more than 80% of:
6184 (Aa) the total private land area in the unincorporated county; or
6185 (Bb) the total value of locally assessed taxable property in the unincorporated county; or
6187 (II)
(Aa) in a county of the second or third class, at least 5% of the total population of the unincorporated
county, but not less than 300 residents; or
6190 (Bb) in a county of the fourth, fifth, or sixth class, at least 25% of the total population of the
unincorporated county; or
6192 (B) has been declared by the United States Census Bureau as a census designated place.
6194 (c)
(i) The process to establish a planning advisory area is initiated by the filing of a petition with the clerk
of the county in which the proposed planning advisory area is located.
6197 (ii) A petition to establish a planning advisory area may not be filed if it proposes the establishment of
a planning advisory area that includes an area within a proposed planning advisory area in a petition
that has previously been certified under Subsection (1)(g), until after the canvass of an election on
the proposed planning advisory area under Subsection (1)(j).
6202 (d) A petition under Subsection (1)(c) to establish a planning advisory area shall:
6203 (i) be signed by the owners of private real property that:
6204 (A) is located within the proposed planning advisory area;
6205 (B) covers at least 10% of the total private land area within the proposed planning advisory area; and
6207 (C) is equal in value to at least 10% of the value of all private real property within the proposed
planning advisory area;
6209 (ii) be accompanied by an accurate plat or map showing the boundary of the contiguous area proposed
to be established as a planning advisory area;
6211 (iii) indicate the typed or printed name and current residence address of each owner signing the petition;
- 199 -

SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
6213 (iv) designate up to five signers of the petition as petition sponsors, one of whom shall be designated as
the contact sponsor, with the mailing address and telephone number of each petition sponsor;
6216 (v) authorize the petition sponsor or sponsors to act on behalf of all owners signing the petition for
purposes of the petition; and
6218 (vi) request the county legislative body to provide notice of the petition and of a public hearing, hold a
public hearing, and conduct an election on the proposal to establish a planning advisory area.
6221 (e) Subsection 10-2a-102(3) applies to a petition to establish a planning advisory area to the same extent
as if it were an incorporation petition under Title 10, Chapter 2a, Municipal Incorporation.
6224 (f)
(i) Within seven days after the filing of a petition under Subsection (1)(c) proposing the establishment
of a planning advisory area in a county of the second class, the county clerk shall provide notice of
the filing of the petition to:
6227 (A) each owner of real property owning more than 1% of the assessed value of all real property
within the proposed planning advisory area; and
6229 (B) each owner of real property owning more than 850 acres of real property within the proposed
planning advisory area.
6231 (ii) A property owner may exclude all or part of the property owner's property from a proposed
planning advisory area in a county of the second class:
6233 (A) if:
6234 (I)
(Aa)
(Ii) the property owner owns more than 1% of the assessed value of all property within the
proposed planning advisory area;
6236 (IIii) the property is nonurban; and
6237 (IIIiii) the property does not or will not require municipal provision of municipal-type services; or
6239 (Bb) the property owner owns more than 850 acres of real property within the proposed planning
advisory area; and
6241 (II) exclusion of the property will not leave within the planning advisory area an island of property that
is not part of the planning advisory area; and
6243 (B) by filing a notice of exclusion within 10 days after receiving the clerk's notice under Subsection (1)
(f)(i).
- 200 -

SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
6245 (iii)
(A) The county legislative body shall exclude from the proposed planning advisory area the property
identified in a notice of exclusion timely filed under Subsection (1)(f)(ii)(B) if the property meets
the applicable requirements of Subsection (1)(f)(ii)(A).
6249 (B) If the county legislative body excludes property from a proposed planning advisory area under
Subsection (1)(f)(iii), the county legislative body shall, within five days after the exclusion, send
written notice of its action to the contact sponsor.
6253 (g)
(i) Within 45 days after the filing of a petition under Subsection (1)(c), the county clerk shall:
6255 (A) with the assistance of other county officers from whom the clerk requests assistance, determine
whether the petition complies with the requirements of Subsection (1)(d); and
6258 (B)
(I) if the clerk determines that the petition complies with the requirements of Subsection (1)(d):
6260 (Aa) certify the petition and deliver the certified petition to the county legislative body; and
6262 (Bb) mail or deliver written notification of the certification to the contact sponsor; or
6264 (II) if the clerk determines that the petition fails to comply with any of the requirements of Subsection
(1)(d), reject the petition and notify the contact sponsor in writing of the rejection and the reasons
for the rejection.
6267 (ii) If the county clerk rejects a petition under Subsection (1)(g)(i)(B)(II), the petition may be amended
to correct the deficiencies for which it was rejected and then refiled with the county clerk.
6270 (h)
(i) Within 90 days after a petition to establish a planning advisory area is certified, the county
legislative body shall hold a public hearing on the proposal to establish a planning advisory area.
6273 (ii) A public hearing under Subsection (1)(h)(i) shall be:
6274 (A) within the boundary of the proposed planning advisory area; or
6275 (B) if holding a public hearing in that area is not practicable, as close to that area as practicable.
6277 (iii) At least one week before holding a public hearing under Subsection (1)(h)(i), the county legislative
body shall publish notice of the petition and the time, date, and place of the public hearing for the
county, as a class A notice under Section 63G-30-102, for at least one week.
6281 (i) Following the public hearing under Subsection (1)(h)(i), the county legislative body shall arrange
for the proposal to establish a planning advisory area to be submitted to voters residing within the
- 201 -

SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
proposed planning advisory area at the next regular general election that is more than 90 days after
the public hearing.
6285 (j) A planning advisory area is established at the time of the canvass of the results of an election under
Subsection (1)(i) if the canvass indicates that a majority of voters voting on the proposal to establish
a planning advisory area voted in favor of the proposal.
6289 (k) An area that is an established township before May 12, 2015:
6290 (i) is, as of May 12, 2015, a planning advisory area; and
6291 (ii)
(A) shall change its name, if applicable, to no longer include the word "township"; and
6293 (B) may use the word "planning advisory area" in its name.
6294 (2) The county legislative body may:
6295 (a) assign to the countywide planning commission the duties established in this part that would have
been assumed by a planning advisory area planning commission designated under Subsection (2)(b);
or
6298 (b) designate and appoint a planning commission for the planning advisory area.
6299 (3)
(a) An area within the boundary of a planning advisory area may be withdrawn from the planning
advisory area as provided in this Subsection (3) or in accordance with Subsection (5)(a).
6302 (b) The process to withdraw an area from a planning advisory area is initiated by the filing of a petition
with the clerk of the county in which the planning advisory area is located.
6305 (c) A petition under Subsection (3)(b) shall:
6306 (i) be signed by the owners of private real property that:
6307 (A) is located within the area proposed to be withdrawn from the planning advisory area;
6309 (B) covers at least 50% of the total private land area within the area proposed to be withdrawn from the
planning advisory area; and
6311 (C) is equal in value to at least 33% of the value of all private real property within the area proposed to
be withdrawn from the planning advisory area;
6313 (ii) state the reason or reasons for the proposed withdrawal;
6314 (iii) be accompanied by an accurate plat or map showing the boundary of the contiguous area proposed
to be withdrawn from the planning advisory area;
6316 (iv) indicate the typed or printed name and current residence address of each owner signing the petition;
- 202 -

SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
6318 (v) designate up to five signers of the petition as petition sponsors, one of whom shall be designated as
the contact sponsor, with the mailing address and telephone number of each petition sponsor;
6321 (vi) authorize the petition sponsor or sponsors to act on behalf of all owners signing the petition for
purposes of the petition; and
6323 (vii) request the county legislative body to withdraw the area from the planning advisory area.
6325 (d) Subsection 10-2a-102(3) applies to a petition to withdraw an area from a planning advisory area
to the same extent as if it were an incorporation petition under Title 10, Chapter 2a, Municipal
Incorporation.
6328 (e)
(i) Within 45 days after the filing of a petition under Subsection (3)(b), the county clerk shall:
6330 (A) with the assistance of other county officers from whom the clerk requests assistance, determine
whether the petition complies with the requirements of Subsection (3)(c); and
6333 (B)
(I) if the clerk determines that the petition complies with the requirements of Subsection (3)(c):
6335 (Aa) certify the petition and deliver the certified petition to the county legislative body; and
6337 (Bb) mail or deliver written notification of the certification to the contact sponsor; or
6339 (II) if the clerk determines that the petition fails to comply with any of the requirements of Subsection
(3)(c), reject the petition and notify the contact sponsor in writing of the rejection and the reasons
for the rejection.
6342 (ii) If the county clerk rejects a petition under Subsection (3)(e)(i)(B)(II), the petition may be amended
to correct the deficiencies for which it was rejected and then refiled with the county clerk.
6345 (f)
(i) Within 60 days after a petition to withdraw an area from a planning advisory area is certified, the
county legislative body shall hold a public hearing on the proposal to withdraw the area from the
planning advisory area.
6348 (ii) A public hearing under Subsection (3)(f)(i) shall be held:
6349 (A) within the area proposed to be withdrawn from the planning advisory area; or
6350 (B) if holding a public hearing in that area is not practicable, as close to that area as practicable.
6352 (iii) Before holding a public hearing under Subsection (3)(f)(i), the county legislative body shall publish
notice of the petition and the time, date, and place of the public hearing for the area proposed to be
- 203 -

SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
withdrawn, as a class B notice under Section 63G-30-102, for at least three weeks before the date of
the hearing.
6356 (g)
(i) Within 45 days after the public hearing under Subsection (3)(f)(i), the county legislative body shall
make a written decision on the proposal to withdraw the area from the planning advisory area.
6359 (ii) In making its decision as to whether to withdraw the area from the planning advisory area, the
county legislative body shall consider:
6361 (A) whether the withdrawal would leave the remaining planning advisory area in a situation where the
future incorporation of an area within the planning advisory area or the annexation of an area within
the planning advisory area to an adjoining municipality would be economically or practically not
feasible;
6365 (B) if the withdrawal is a precursor to the incorporation or annexation of the withdrawn area:
6367 (I) whether the proposed subsequent incorporation or withdrawal:
6368 (Aa) will leave or create an unincorporated island or peninsula; or
6369 (Bb) will leave the county with an area within its unincorporated area for which the cost, requirements,
or other burdens of providing municipal services would materially increase over previous years; and
6372 (II) whether the municipality to be created or the municipality into which the withdrawn area is
expected to annex would be or is capable, in a cost effective manner, of providing service to the
withdrawn area that the county will no longer provide due to the incorporation or annexation;
6376 (C) the effects of a withdrawal on adjoining property owners, existing or projected county streets or
other public improvements, law enforcement, and zoning and other municipal services provided by
the county; and
6379 (D) whether justice and equity favor the withdrawal.
6380 (h) Upon the written decision of the county legislative body approving the withdrawal of an area from
a planning advisory area, the area is withdrawn from the planning advisory area and the planning
advisory area continues as a planning advisory area with a boundary that excludes the withdrawn
area.
6384 (4)
(a) A planning advisory area may be dissolved as provided in this Subsection (4).
6385 (b) The process to dissolve a planning advisory area is initiated by the filing of a petition with the clerk
of the county in which the planning advisory area is located.
- 204 -

SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
6387 (c) A petition under Subsection (4)(b) shall:
6388 (i) be signed by registered voters within the planning advisory area equal in number to at least 25% of
all votes cast by voters within the planning advisory area at the last congressional election;
6391 (ii) state the reason or reasons for the proposed dissolution;
6392 (iii) indicate the typed or printed name and current residence address of each person signing the
petition;
6394 (iv) designate up to five signers of the petition as petition sponsors, one of whom shall be designated as
the contact sponsor, with the mailing address and telephone number of each petition sponsor;
6397 (v) authorize the petition sponsors to act on behalf of all persons signing the petition for purposes of the
petition; and
6399 (vi) request the county legislative body to provide notice of the petition and of a public hearing, hold a
public hearing, and conduct an election on the proposal to dissolve the planning advisory area.
6402 (d)
(i) Within 45 days after the filing of a petition under Subsection (4)(b), the county clerk shall:
6404 (A) with the assistance of other county officers from whom the clerk requests assistance, determine
whether the petition complies with the requirements of Subsection (4)(c); and
6407 (B)
(I) if the clerk determines that the petition complies with the requirements of Subsection (4)(c):
6409 (Aa) certify the petition and deliver the certified petition to the county legislative body; and
6411 (Bb) mail or deliver written notification of the certification to the contact sponsor; or
6413 (II) if the clerk determines that the petition fails to comply with any of the requirements of Subsection
(4)(c), reject the petition and notify the contact sponsor in writing of the rejection and the reasons
for the rejection.
6416 (ii) If the county clerk rejects a petition under Subsection (4)(d)(i)(B)(II), the petition may be amended
to correct the deficiencies for which it was rejected and then refiled with the county clerk.
6419 (e)
(i) Within 60 days after a petition to dissolve the planning advisory area is certified, the county
legislative body shall hold a public hearing on the proposal to dissolve the planning advisory area.
6422 (ii) A public hearing under Subsection (4)(e)(i) shall be held:
6423 (A) within the boundary of the planning advisory area; or
6424 (B) if holding a public hearing in that area is not practicable, as close to that area as practicable.
- 205 -

SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
6426 (iii) Before holding a public hearing under Subsection (4)(e)(i), the county legislative body shall publish
notice of the petition and the time, date, and place of the public hearing for the county, as a class
A notice under Section 63G-30-102, for three consecutive weeks immediately before the public
hearing.
6430 (f) Following the public hearing under Subsection (4)(e)(i), the county legislative body shall arrange
for the proposal to dissolve the planning advisory area to be submitted to voters residing within the
planning advisory area at the next regular general election that is more than 90 days after the public
hearing.
6434 (g) A planning advisory area is dissolved at the time of the canvass of the results of an election under
Subsection (4)(f) if the canvass indicates that a majority of voters voting on the proposal to dissolve
the planning advisory area voted in favor of the proposal.
6438 (5)
(a) If a portion of an area located within a planning advisory area is annexed by a municipality or
incorporates, that portion is withdrawn from the planning advisory area.
6441 (b) If a planning advisory area in whole is annexed by a municipality or incorporates, the planning
advisory area is dissolved.
6481 Section 176. Section 17-79-304 is renumbered and amended to read:
6483 [17-27a-303] 17-79-304. Entrance upon land.
A county may enter upon any land at reasonable times to make examinations and
surveys pertinent to the:
6448 (1) preparation of its general plan; or
6449 (2) preparation or enforcement of its land use ordinances.
6488 Section 177. Section 17-79-305 is renumbered and amended to read:
6490 [17-27a-305] 17-79-305. Other entities required to conform to county's land use ordinances
-- Exceptions -- School districts, charter schools, home-based microschools, and micro-education
entities -- Submission of development plan and schedule.
6456 (1)
(a) Each county, municipality, school district, charter school, special district, special service district,
and political subdivision of the state shall conform to any applicable land use ordinance of any
county when installing, constructing, operating, or otherwise using any area, land, or building
- 206 -

SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
situated within a mountainous planning district or the unincorporated portion of the county, as
applicable.
6461 (b) In addition to any other remedies provided by law, when a county's land use ordinance is violated
or about to be violated by another political subdivision, that county may institute an injunction,
mandamus, abatement, or other appropriate action or proceeding to prevent, enjoin, abate, or remove
the improper installation, improvement, or use.
6466 (2)
(a) Except as provided in Subsection (3), a school district or charter school is subject to a county's land
use ordinances.
6468 (b)
(i) Notwithstanding Subsection (3), a county may:
6469 (A) subject a charter school to standards within each zone pertaining to setback, height, bulk and
massing regulations, off-site parking, curb cut, traffic circulation, and construction staging; and
6472 (B) impose regulations upon the location of a project that are necessary to avoid unreasonable risks
to health or safety, as provided in Subsection (3)(f).
6474 (ii) The standards to which a county may subject a charter school under Subsection (2)(b)(i) shall be
objective standards only and may not be subjective.
6476 (iii) Except as provided in Subsection (7)(d), the only basis upon which a county may deny or withhold
approval of a charter school's land use application is the charter school's failure to comply with a
standard imposed under Subsection (2)(b)(i).
6479 (iv) Nothing in Subsection (2)(b)(iii) may be construed to relieve a charter school of an obligation
to comply with a requirement of an applicable building or safety code to which it is otherwise
obligated to comply.
6482 (3) A county may not:
6483 (a) impose requirements for landscaping, fencing, aesthetic considerations, construction methods or
materials, additional building inspections, county building codes, building use for educational
purposes, or the placement or use of temporary classroom facilities on school property;
6487 (b) except as otherwise provided in this section, require a school district or charter school to participate
in the cost of any roadway or sidewalk, or a study on the impact of a school on a roadway or
sidewalk, that is not reasonably necessary for the safety of school children and not located on or
- 207 -

SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
contiguous to school property, unless the roadway or sidewalk is required to connect an otherwise
isolated school site to an existing roadway;
6493 (c) require a district or charter school to pay fees not authorized by this section;
6494 (d) provide for inspection of school construction or assess a fee or other charges for inspection, unless
the school district or charter school is unable to provide for inspection by an inspector, other
than the project architect or contractor, who is qualified under criteria established by the state
superintendent;
6498 (e) require a school district or charter school to pay any impact fee for an improvement project unless
the impact fee is imposed as provided in Title 11, Chapter 36a, Impact Fees Act;
6501 (f) impose regulations upon the location of an educational facility except as necessary to avoid
unreasonable risks to health or safety; or
6503 (g) for a land use or a structure owned or operated by a school district or charter school that is not an
educational facility but is used in support of providing instruction to pupils, impose a regulation
that:
6506 (i) is not imposed on a similar land use or structure in the zone in which the land use or structure is
approved; or
6508 (ii) uses the tax exempt status of the school district or charter school as criteria for prohibiting or
regulating the land use or location of the structure.
6510 (4) Subject to Section 53E-3-710, a school district or charter school shall coordinate the siting of a new
school with the county in which the school is to be located, to:
6512 (a) avoid or mitigate existing and potential traffic hazards, including consideration of the impacts
between the new school and future highways; and
6514 (b) maximize school, student, and site safety.
6515 (5) Notwithstanding Subsection (3)(d), a county may, at its discretion:
6516 (a) provide a walk-through of school construction at no cost and at a time convenient to the district or
charter school; and
6518 (b) provide recommendations based upon the walk-through.
6519 (6)
(a) Notwithstanding Subsection (3)(d), a school district or charter school shall use:
6520 (i) a county building inspector;
6521 (ii)
- 208 -

SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
(A) for a school district, a school district building inspector from that school district; or
6523 (B) for a charter school, a school district building inspector from the school district in which the charter
school is located; or
6525 (iii) an independent, certified building inspector who is not an employee of the contractor, licensed
to perform the inspection that the inspector is requested to perform, and approved by a county
building inspector or:
6528 (A) for a school district, a school district building inspector from that school district; or
6530 (B) for a charter school, a school district building inspector from the school district in which the charter
school is located.
6532 (b) The approval under Subsection (6)(a)(iii) may not be unreasonably withheld.
6533 (c) If a school district or charter school uses a school district or independent building inspector
under Subsection (6)(a)(ii) or (iii), the school district or charter school shall submit to the state
superintendent of public instruction and county building official, on a monthly basis during
construction of the school building, a copy of each inspection certificate regarding the school
building.
6538 (7)
(a) A charter school, home-based microschool, or micro-education entity shall be considered a
permitted use in all zoning districts within a county.
6540 (b) Each land use application for any approval required for a charter school, home-based microschool,
or micro-education entity, including an application for a building permit, shall be processed on a
first priority basis.
6543 (c) Parking requirements for a charter school or micro-education entity may not exceed the minimum
parking requirements for schools or other institutional public uses throughout the county.
6546 (d) If a county has designated zones for a sexually oriented business, or a business which sells alcohol,
a charter school or micro-education entity may be prohibited from a location which would otherwise
defeat the purpose for the zone unless the charter school or micro-education entity provides a
waiver.
6550 (e)
(i) A school district , charter school, or micro-education entity may seek a certificate authorizing
permanent occupancy of a school building from:
6552
- 209 -

SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
(A) the state superintendent of public instruction, as provided in Subsection 53E-3-706(3), if the
school district, charter school, or micro-education entity used an independent building inspector
for inspection of the school building; or
6555 (B) a county official with authority to issue the certificate, if the school district, charter school, or
micro-education entity used a county building inspector for inspection of the school building.
6558 (ii) A school district may issue its own certificate authorizing permanent occupancy of a school building
if it used its own building inspector for inspection of the school building, subject to the notification
requirement of Subsection [53E-3-706(3)(a)(ii)] 53E-3-706(3)(d)(ii).
6562 (iii) A charter school or micro-education entity may seek a certificate authorizing permanent occupancy
of a school building from a school district official with authority to issue the certificate, if the
charter school or micro-education entity used a school district building inspector for inspection of
the school building.
6566 (iv) A certificate authorizing permanent occupancy issued by the state superintendent of public
instruction under Subsection 53E-3-706(3) or a school district official with authority to issue the
certificate shall be considered to satisfy any county requirement for an inspection or a certificate of
occupancy.
6570 (f)
(i) A micro-education entity may operate a facility that meets Group E Occupancy requirements as
defined by the International Building Code, as incorporated by Subsection 15A-2-103(1)(a).
6573 (ii) A micro-education entity operating in a facility described in Subsection (7)(f)(i) may have up to 100
students in the facility.
6575 (g) A micro-education entity may operate a facility that is subject to and complies with the same
occupancy requirements as a Class A-1, A-3, B, or M Occupancy as defined by the International
Building Code, as incorporated by Subsection 15A-2-103(1)(a), if:
6579 (i) the facility has a code compliant fire alarm system and carbon monoxide detection system;
6581 (ii)
(A) each classroom in the facility has an exit directly to the outside at the level of exit discharge; or
6583 (B) the structure has a code compliant fire sprinkler system; and
6584 (iii) the facility has an automatic fire sprinkler system in fire areas of the facility that are greater than
12,000 square feet.
6586 (h)
- 210 -

SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
(i) A home-based microschool is not subject to additional occupancy requirements beyond occupancy
requirements that apply to a primary dwelling.
6588 (ii) If a floor that is below grade in a home-based microschool is used for home-based microschool
purposes, the below grade floor of the home-based microschool shall have at least one emergency
escape or rescue window that complies with the requirements for emergency escape and rescue
windows as defined by the International Residential Code, as incorporated in Section 15A-1-210.
6593 (8)
(a) A specified public agency intending to develop its land shall submit to the land use authority a
development plan and schedule:
6595 (i) as early as practicable in the development process, but no later than the commencement of
construction; and
6597 (ii) with sufficient detail to enable the land use authority to assess:
6598 (A) the specified public agency's compliance with applicable land use ordinances;
6599 (B) the demand for public facilities listed in Subsections 11-36a-102(17)(a), (b), (c), (d), (e), and (g)
caused by the development;
6601 (C) the amount of any applicable fee described in Section [17-27a-509] 17-79-804;
6602 (D) any credit against an impact fee; and
6603 (E) the potential for waiving an impact fee.
6604 (b) The land use authority shall respond to a specified public agency's submission under Subsection (8)
(a) with reasonable promptness in order to allow the specified public agency to consider information
the municipality provides under Subsection (8)(a)(ii) in the process of preparing the budget for the
development.
6608 (9) Nothing in this section may be construed to:
6609 (a) modify or supersede Section [17-27a-304] 17-79-306; or
6610 (b) authorize a county to enforce an ordinance in a way, or enact an ordinance, that fails to comply with
Title 57, Chapter 21, Utah Fair Housing Act, the federal Fair Housing Amendments Act of 1988,
42 U.S.C. Sec. 3601 et seq., the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990, 42 U.S.C. 12102, or any
other provision of federal law.
6614 (10) Nothing in Subsection (7) prevents a political subdivision from:
6615 (a) requiring a home-based microschool or micro-education entity to comply with local zoning and land
use regulations that do not conflict with this section, including:
- 211 -

SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
6617 (i) parking;
6618 (ii) traffic; and
6619 (iii) hours of operation;
6620 (b) requiring a home-based microschool or micro-education entity to obtain a business license;
6622 (c) enacting county ordinances and regulations consistent with this section;
6623 (d) subjecting a micro-education entity to standards within each zone pertaining to setback, height, bulk
and massing regulations, off-site parking, curb cut, traffic circulation, and construction staging; and
6626 (e) imposing regulations on the location of a project that are necessary to avoid risks to health or safety.
6628 (11) Notwithstanding any other provision of law, the proximity restrictions that apply to community
locations do not apply to a micro-education entity.
6668 Section 178. Section 17-79-306 is renumbered and amended to read:
6670 [17-27a-304] 17-79-306. State and federal property.
Unless otherwise provided by law, nothing contained in this chapter or Chapter 80,
Counties and Housing Supply, may be construed as giving a county jurisdiction over property
owned by the state or the United States.
6674 Section 179. Section 17-79-401 is renumbered and amended to read:
6638
Part 4. General Plan
6677 [17-27a-401] 17-79-401. General plan required -- Content -- Resource management plan --
Provisions related to radioactive waste facility.
6641 (1) To accomplish the purposes of this chapter, a county shall prepare and adopt a comprehensive, long-
range general plan:
6643 (a) for present and future needs of the county;
6644 (b)
(i) for growth and development of all or any part of the land within the unincorporated portions of the
county; or
6646 (ii) if a county has designated a mountainous planning district, for growth and development of all or any
part of the land within the mountainous planning district; and
6649 (c) as a basis for communicating and coordinating with the federal government on land and resource
management issues.
6651 (2) To promote health, safety, and welfare, the general plan may provide for:
6652
- 212 -

SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
(a) health, general welfare, safety, energy conservation, transportation, prosperity, civic activities,
aesthetics, and recreational, educational, and cultural opportunities;
6654 (b) the reduction of the waste of physical, financial, or human resources that result from either
excessive congestion or excessive scattering of population;
6656 (c) the efficient and economical use, conservation, and production of the supply of:
6657 (i) food and water; and
6658 (ii) drainage, sanitary, and other facilities and resources;
6659 (d) the use of energy conservation and solar and clean energy resources;
6660 (e) the protection of urban development;
6661 (f) the protection and promotion of air quality;
6662 (g) historic preservation;
6663 (h) identifying future uses of land that are likely to require an expansion or significant modification of
services or facilities provided by an affected entity; and
6665 (i) an official map.
6666 [(3)
(a)
(i) The general plan of a specified county, as defined in Section 17-27a-408, shall include a
moderate income housing element that meets the requirements of Subsection 17-27a-403(2)(a)
(iii).]
6669 [(ii)
(A) This Subsection (3)(a)(ii) applies to a county that does not qualify as a specified county as of
January 1, 2023.]
6671 [(B) As of January 1, if a county described in Subsection (3)(a)(ii)(A) changes from one class to another
or grows in population to qualify as a specified county as defined in Section 17-27a-408, the county
shall amend the county's general plan to comply with Subsection (3)(a)(i) on or before August 1 of
the first calendar year beginning on January 1 in which the county qualifies as a specified county.]
6677 [(iii) A county described in Subsection (3)(a)(ii)(B) shall send a copy of the county's amended
general plan to the association of governments, established pursuant to an interlocal agreement
under Title 11, Chapter 13, Interlocal Cooperation Act, of which the county is a member.]
6681 [(b) The general plan shall contain a resource management plan for the public lands, as defined in
Section 63L-6-102, within the county.]
- 213 -

SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
6683 [(c) The resource management plan described in Subsection (3)(b) shall address:]
6684 [(i) mining;]
6685 [(ii) land use;]
6686 [(iii) livestock and grazing;]
6687 [(iv) irrigation;]
6688 [(v) agriculture;]
6689 [(vi) fire management;]
6690 [(vii) noxious weeds;]
6691 [(viii) forest management;]
6692 [(ix) water rights;]
6693 [(x) ditches and canals;]
6694 [(xi) water quality and hydrology;]
6695 [(xii) flood plains and river terraces;]
6696 [(xiii) wetlands;]
6697 [(xiv) riparian areas;]
6698 [(xv) predator control;]
6699 [(xvi) wildlife;]
6700 [(xvii) fisheries;]
6701 [(xviii) recreation and tourism;]
6702 [(xix) energy resources;]
6703 [(xx) mineral resources;]
6704 [(xxi) cultural, historical, geological, and paleontological resources;]
6705 [(xxii) wilderness;]
6706 [(xxiii) wild and scenic rivers;]
6707 [(xxiv) threatened, endangered, and sensitive species;]
6708 [(xxv) land access;]
6709 [(xxvi) law enforcement;]
6710 [(xxvii) economic considerations; and]
6711 [(xxviii) air.]
6712 [(d) For each item listed under Subsection (3)(c), a county's resource management plan shall:]
6714 [(i) establish findings pertaining to the item;]
- 214 -

SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
6715 [(ii) establish defined objectives; and]
6716 [(iii) outline general policies and guidelines on how the objectives described in Subsection (3)(d)(ii) are
to be accomplished.]
6718 [(4)
(a)
(i) The general plan shall include specific provisions related to an area within, or partially within,
the exterior boundaries of the county, or contiguous to the boundaries of a county, which are
proposed for the siting of a storage facility or transfer facility for the placement of high-level
nuclear waste or greater than class C radioactive nuclear waste, as these wastes are defined in
Section 19-3-303.]
6723 [(ii) The provisions described in Subsection (4)(a)(i) shall address the effects of the proposed site
upon the health and general welfare of citizens of the state, and shall provide:]
6726 [(A) the information identified in Section 19-3-305;]
6727 [(B) information supported by credible studies that demonstrates that Subsection 19-3-307(2) has been
satisfied; and]
6729 [(C) specific measures to mitigate the effects of high-level nuclear waste and greater than class C
radioactive waste and guarantee the health and safety of the citizens of the state.]
6732 [(b) A county may, in lieu of complying with Subsection (4)(a), adopt an ordinance indicating that
all proposals for the siting of a storage facility or transfer facility for the placement of high-level
nuclear waste or greater than class C radioactive waste wholly or partially within the county are
rejected.]
6736 [(c) A county may adopt the ordinance listed in Subsection (4)(b) at any time.]
6737 [(d) The county shall send a certified copy of the ordinance described in Subsection (4)(b) to the
executive director of the Department of Environmental Quality by certified mail within 30 days of
enactment.]
6740 [(e) If a county repeals an ordinance adopted under Subsection (4)(b) the county shall:]
6741 [(i) comply with Subsection (4)(a) as soon as reasonably possible; and]
6742 [(ii) send a certified copy of the repeal to the executive director of the Department of Environmental
Quality by certified mail within 30 days after the repeal.]
6744 [(5)] (3) The general plan may define the county's local customs, local culture, and the components
necessary for the county's economic stability.
- 215 -

SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
6746 [(6)] (4) Subject to [Subsection 17-27a-403(2)] Section 17-79-403, the county may determine the
comprehensiveness, extent, and format of the general plan.
6748 [(7) If a county has designated a mountainous planning district, the general plan for the mountainous
planning district is the controlling plan.]
6750 [(8)] (5) Nothing in this part may be construed to limit the authority of the state to manage and protect
wildlife under Title 23A, Wildlife Resources Act.
6752 [(9)] (6) On or before December 31, 2025, a county that has a general plan that does not include a water
use and preservation element that complies with Section [17-27a-403] 17-79-403 shall amend the
county's general plan to comply with Section [17-27a-403] 17-79-403.
6794 Section 180. Section 180 is enacted to read:
6795 17-79-402. Specific provisions for general plan.
6758 (1)
(a) The general plan of a specified county, as defined in Section 17-80-101, shall include a moderate
income housing element that meets the requirements of Section 17-80-201.
6761 (b)
(i) This Subsection (1)(b) applies to a county that does not qualify as a specified county as of January 1,
2023.
6763 (ii) As of January 1, if a county changes from one class to another or grows in population to qualify as
a specified county, the county shall amend the county's general plan to include a moderate income
housing element that meets the requirements of Section 17-80-201 on or before August 1 of the first
calendar year beginning on January 1 in which the county qualifies as a specified county.
6768 (iii) A county described in Subsection (1)(b)(ii) shall send a copy of the county's amended general plan
to the association of governments, established in accordance with an interlocal agreement under
Title 11, Chapter 13, Interlocal Cooperation Act, of which the county is a member.
6772 (2)
(a) All county general plans shall contain a resource management plan for the public lands, as defined
in Section 63L-6-102, within the county.
6774 (b) The resource management plan described in Subsection (2)(a) shall address:
6775 (i) mining;
6776 (ii) land use;
6777 (iii) livestock and grazing;
- 216 -

SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
6778 (iv) irrigation;
6779 (v) agriculture;
6780 (vi) fire management;
6781 (vii) noxious weeds;
6782 (viii) forest management;
6783 (ix) water rights;
6784 (x) ditches and canals;
6785 (xi) water quality and hydrology;
6786 (xii) flood plains and river terraces;
6787 (xiii) wetlands;
6788 (xiv) riparian areas;
6789 (xv) predator control;
6790 (xvi) wildlife;
6791 (xvii) fisheries;
6792 (xviii) recreation and tourism;
6793 (xix) energy resources;
6794 (xx) mineral resources;
6795 (xxi) cultural, historical, geological, and paleontological resources;
6796 (xxii) wilderness;
6797 (xxiii) wild and scenic rivers;
6798 (xxiv) threatened, endangered, and sensitive species;
6799 (xxv) land access;
6800 (xxvi) law enforcement;
6801 (xxvii) economic considerations; and
6802 (xxviii) air.
6803 (c) For each item listed under Subsection (2)(b), a county's resource management plan shall:
6805 (i) establish findings pertaining to the item;
6806 (ii) establish defined objectives; and
6807 (iii) outline general policies and guidelines on how the objectives described in Subsection (2)(c)(ii) are
to be accomplished.
6809 (3)
- 217 -

SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
(a)
(i) All county general plans shall include specific provisions related to an area within, or partially
within, the exterior boundaries of the county, or contiguous to the boundaries of a county, which
are proposed for the siting of a storage facility or transfer facility for the placement of high-level
nuclear waste or greater than class C radioactive nuclear waste, as these wastes are defined in
Section 19-3-303.
6814 (ii) The provisions described in Subsection (3)(a)(i) shall address the effects of the proposed site
upon the health and general welfare of citizens of the state, and shall provide:
6817 (A) the information identified in Section 19-3-305;
6818 (B) information supported by credible studies that demonstrates that Subsection 19-3-307(2) has been
satisfied; and
6820 (C) specific measures to mitigate the effects of high-level nuclear waste and greater than class C
radioactive waste and guarantee the health and safety of the citizens of the state.
6823 (b) A county may, in lieu of complying with Subsection (3)(a), adopt an ordinance indicating that
all proposals for the siting of a storage facility or transfer facility for the placement of high-level
nuclear waste or greater than class C radioactive waste wholly or partially within the county are
rejected.
6827 (c) A county may adopt the ordinance listed in Subsection (3)(b) at any time.
6828 (d) The county shall send a certified copy of the ordinance described in Subsection (3)(b) to the
executive director of the Department of Environmental Quality by certified mail within 30 days of
enactment.
6831 (e) If a county repeals an ordinance adopted under Subsection (3)(b), the county shall:
6832 (i) comply with Subsection (3)(a) as soon as reasonably possible; and
6833 (ii) send a certified copy of the repeal to the executive director of the Department of Environmental
Quality by certified mail within 30 days after the repeal.
6835 (4) If a county has designated a mountainous planning district, the general plan for the mountainous
planning district is the controlling plan.
6875 Section 181. Section 17-79-403 is renumbered and amended to read:
6877 [17-27a-403] 17-79-403. General plan preparation.
6840 (1)
- 218 -

SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
(a) The planning commission shall provide notice, as provided in Section [17-27a-203] 17-79-203, of
the planning commission's intent to make a recommendation to the county legislative body for a
general plan or a comprehensive general plan amendment when the planning commission initiates
the process of preparing the planning commission's recommendation.
6845 (b) The planning commission shall make and recommend to the legislative body a proposed general
plan for:
6847 (i) the unincorporated area within the county; or
6848 (ii) if the planning commission is a planning commission for a mountainous planning district, the
mountainous planning district.
6850 (c)
(i) The plan may include planning for incorporated areas if, in the planning commission's judgment,
they are related to the planning of the unincorporated territory or of the county as a whole.
6853 (ii) Elements of the county plan that address incorporated areas are not an official plan or part of a
municipal plan for any municipality, unless the county plan is recommended by the municipal
planning commission and adopted by the governing body of the municipality.
6857 (2)
(a) At a minimum, the proposed general plan, with the accompanying maps, charts, and descriptive and
explanatory matter, shall include the planning commission's recommendations for the following
plan elements:
6860 (i) a land use element that:
6861 (A) designates the long-term goals and the proposed extent, general distribution, and location of land
for housing for residents of various income levels, business, industry, agriculture, recreation,
education, public buildings and grounds, open space, and other categories of public and private uses
of land as appropriate;
6866 (B) includes a statement of the projections for and standards of population density and building
intensity recommended for the various land use categories covered by the plan;
6869 (C) is coordinated to integrate the land use element with the water use and preservation element; and
6871 (D) accounts for the effect of land use categories and land uses on water demand;
6872 (ii) a transportation and traffic circulation element that:
6873
- 219 -

SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
(A) provides the general location and extent of existing and proposed freeways, arterial and collector
streets, public transit, active transportation facilities, and other modes of transportation that the
planning commission considers appropriate;
6877 (B) addresses the county's plan for residential and commercial development around major transit
investment corridors to maintain and improve the connections between housing, employment,
education, recreation, and commerce; and
6881 (C) correlates with the population projections, the employment projections, and the proposed land use
element of the general plan;
6883 (iii) for a specified county as defined in Section [17-27a-408] 17-80-101, a moderate income
housing element that[:] meets the requirements of Section 17-80-202;
6885 [(A) provides a realistic opportunity to meet the need for additional moderate income housing within
the next five years;]
6887 [(B) selects three or more moderate income housing strategies described in Subsections (2)(b)(ii)
(A) through (V), or one moderate income housing strategy described in Subsections (2)(b)(ii)(W)
through (BB), for implementation; and]
6891 [(C) includes an implementation plan as provided in Subsection (2)(f);]
6892 (iv) a resource management plan detailing the findings, objectives, and policies required by
[Subsection 17-27a-401(3)] Section 17-79-402; and
6894 (v) a water use and preservation element that addresses:
6895 (A) the effect of permitted development or patterns of development on water demand and water
infrastructure;
6897 (B) methods of reducing water demand and per capita consumption for future development;
6899 (C) methods of reducing water demand and per capita consumption for existing development; and
6901 (D) opportunities for the county to modify the county's operations to eliminate practices or conditions
that waste water.
6903 [(b) In drafting the moderate income housing element, the planning commission:]
6904 [(i) shall consider the Legislature's determination that counties should facilitate a reasonable
opportunity for a variety of housing, including moderate income housing:]
6907 [(A) to meet the needs of people of various income levels living, working, or desiring to live or work in
the community; and]
6909
- 220 -

SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
[(B) to allow people with various incomes to benefit from and fully participate in all aspects of
neighborhood and community life; and]
6911 [(ii) shall include an analysis of how the county will provide a realistic opportunity for the development
of moderate income housing within the planning horizon, including a recommendation to implement
three or more of the following moderate income housing strategies:]
6915 [(A) rezone for densities necessary to facilitate the production of moderate income housing;]
6917 [(B) demonstrate investment in the rehabilitation or expansion of infrastructure that facilitates the
construction of moderate income housing;]
6919 [(C) demonstrate investment in the rehabilitation of existing uninhabitable housing stock into moderate
income housing;]
6921 [(D) identify and utilize county general fund subsidies or other sources of revenue to waive construction
related fees that are otherwise generally imposed by the county for the construction or rehabilitation
of moderate income housing;]
6924 [(E) create or allow for, and reduce regulations related to, internal or detached accessory dwelling units
in residential zones;]
6926 [(F) zone or rezone for higher density or moderate income residential development in commercial or
mixed-use zones, commercial centers, or employment centers;]
6929 [(G) amend land use regulations to allow for higher density or new moderate income residential
development in commercial or mixed-use zones near major transit investment corridors;]
6932 [(H) amend land use regulations to eliminate or reduce parking requirements for residential
development where a resident is less likely to rely on the resident's own vehicle, such as residential
development near major transit investment corridors or senior living facilities;]
6936 [(I) amend land use regulations to allow for single room occupancy developments;]
6937 [(J) implement zoning incentives for moderate income units in new developments;]
6938 [(K) preserve existing and new moderate income housing and subsidized units by utilizing a landlord
incentive program, providing for deed restricted units through a grant program, or establishing a
housing loss mitigation fund;]
6941 [(L) reduce, waive, or eliminate impact fees related to moderate income housing;]
6942 [(M) demonstrate creation of, or participation in, a community land trust program for moderate income
housing;]
6944
- 221 -

SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
[(N) implement a mortgage assistance program for employees of the county, an employer that provides
contracted services for the county, or any other public employer that operates within the county;]
6947 [(O) apply for or partner with an entity that applies for state or federal funds or tax incentives to
promote the construction of moderate income housing, an entity that applies for programs offered
by the Utah Housing Corporation within that agency's funding capacity, an entity that applies for
affordable housing programs administered by the Department of Workforce Services, an entity that
applies for services provided by a public housing authority to preserve and create moderate income
housing, or any other entity that applies for programs or services that promote the construction or
preservation of moderate income housing;]
6956 [(P) demonstrate utilization of a moderate income housing set aside from a community reinvestment
agency, redevelopment agency, or community development and renewal agency to create or
subsidize moderate income housing;]
6960 [(Q) eliminate impact fees for any accessory dwelling unit that is not an internal accessory dwelling unit
as defined in Section 10-9a-530;]
6962 [(R) create a program to transfer development rights for moderate income housing;]
6963 [(S) ratify a joint acquisition agreement with another local political subdivision for the purpose of
combining resources to acquire property for moderate income housing;]
6966 [(T) develop a moderate income housing project for residents who are disabled or 55 years old or
older;]
6968 [(U) create or allow for, and reduce regulations related to, multifamily residential dwellings compatible
in scale and form with detached single-family residential dwellings and located in walkable
communities within residential or mixed-use zones;]
6972 [(V) demonstrate implementation of any other program or strategy to address the housing needs of
residents of the county who earn less than 80% of the area median income, including the dedication
of a local funding source to moderate income housing or the adoption of a land use ordinance that
requires 10% or more of new residential development in a residential zone be dedicated to moderate
income housing;]
6978 [(W) create a housing and transit reinvestment zone pursuant to Title 63N, Chapter 3, Part 6, Housing
and Transit Reinvestment Zone Act;]
6980 [(X) create a home ownership investment zone in accordance with Part 12, Home Ownership Promotion
Zone for Counties;]
- 222 -

SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
6982 [(Y) create a first home investment zone in accordance with Title 63N, Chapter 3, Part 16, First Home
Investment Zone Act;]
6984 [(Z) approve a project that receives funding from, or qualifies to receive funding from, the Utah Homes
Investment Program created in Title 51, Chapter 12, Utah Homes Investment Program;]
6987 [(AA) adopt or approve an affordable home ownership density bonus for single-family residential units,
as described in Section 17-27a-403.1; and]
6989 [(BB) adopt or approve an affordable home ownership density bonus for multi-family residential units,
as described in Section 17-27a-403.2.]
6991 [(c) The planning commission shall identify each moderate income housing strategy recommended to
the legislative body for implementation by restating the exact language used to describe the strategy
in Subsection (2)(b)(ii).]
6994 [(d)] (b) In drafting the land use element, the planning commission shall:
6995 (i) identify and consider each agriculture protection area within the unincorporated area of the county or
mountainous planning district;
6997 (ii) avoid proposing a use of land within an agriculture protection area that is inconsistent with or
detrimental to the use of the land for agriculture; and
6999 (iii) consider and coordinate with any station area plans adopted by municipalities located within the
county under Section 10-9a-403.1.
7001 [(e)] (c) In drafting the transportation and traffic circulation element, the planning commission shall:
7003 (i)
(A) consider and coordinate with the regional transportation plan developed by the county's region's
metropolitan planning organization, if the relevant areas of the county are within the boundaries of a
metropolitan planning organization; or
7007 (B) consider and coordinate with the long-range transportation plan developed by the Department of
Transportation, if the relevant areas of the county are not within the boundaries of a metropolitan
planning organization; and
7010 (ii) consider and coordinate with any station area plans adopted by municipalities located within the
county under Section 10-9a-403.1.
7012 [(f)
(i) In drafting the implementation plan portion of the moderate income housing element as described
in Subsection (2)(a)(iii)(C), the planning commission shall recommend to the legislative body

SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
the establishment of a five-year timeline for implementing each of the moderate income housing
strategies selected by the county for implementation.]
7017 [(ii) The timeline described in Subsection (2)(f)(i) shall:]
7018 [(A) identify specific measures and benchmarks for implementing each moderate income housing
strategy selected by the county; and]
7020 [(B) provide flexibility for the county to make adjustments as needed.]
7021 [(g)] (d) In drafting the water use and preservation element, the planning commission:
7022 (i) shall consider applicable regional water conservation goals recommended by the Division of Water
Resources;
7024 (ii) shall consult with the Division of Water Resources for information and technical resources
regarding regional water conservation goals, including how implementation of the land use element
and water use and preservation element may affect the Great Salt Lake;
7028 (iii) shall notify the community water systems serving drinking water within the unincorporated portion
of the county and request feedback from the community water systems about how implementation
of the land use element and water use and preservation element may affect:
7032 (A) water supply planning, including drinking water source and storage capacity consistent with Section
19-4-114; and
7034 (B) water distribution planning, including master plans, infrastructure asset management programs and
plans, infrastructure replacement plans, and impact fee facilities plans;
7037 (iv) shall consider the potential opportunities and benefits of planning for regionalization of public
water systems;
7039 (v) shall consult with the Department of Agriculture and Food for information and technical resources
regarding the potential benefits of agriculture conservation easements and potential implementation
of agriculture water optimization projects that would support regional water conservation goals;
7043 (vi) shall notify an irrigation or canal company located in the county so that the irrigation or canal
company can be involved in the protection and integrity of the irrigation or canal company's
delivery systems;
7046 (vii) shall include a recommendation for:
7047 (A) water conservation policies to be determined by the county; and
7048 (B) landscaping options within a public street for current and future development that do not require the
use of lawn or turf in a parkstrip;
- 224 -

SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
7050 (viii) shall review the county's land use ordinances and include a recommendation for changes to an
ordinance that promotes the inefficient use of water;
7052 (ix) shall consider principles of sustainable landscaping, including the:
7053 (A) reduction or limitation of the use of lawn or turf;
7054 (B) promotion of site-specific landscape design that decreases stormwater runoff or runoff of water
used for irrigation;
7056 (C) preservation and use of healthy trees that have a reasonable water requirement or are resistant to dry
soil conditions;
7058 (D) elimination or regulation of ponds, pools, and other features that promote unnecessary water
evaporation;
7060 (E) reduction of yard waste; and
7061 (F) use of an irrigation system, including drip irrigation, best adapted to provide the optimal amount of
water to the plants being irrigated;
7063 (x) may include recommendations for additional water demand reduction strategies, including:
7065 (A) creating a water budget associated with a particular type of development;
7066 (B) adopting new or modified lot size, configuration, and landscaping standards that will reduce water
demand for new single family development;
7068 (C) providing one or more water reduction incentives for existing landscapes and irrigation systems and
installation of water fixtures or systems that minimize water demand;
7071 (D) discouraging incentives for economic development activities that do not adequately account for
water use or do not include strategies for reducing water demand; and
7074 (E) adopting water concurrency standards requiring that adequate water supplies and facilities are or
will be in place for new development; and
7076 (xi) shall include a recommendation for low water use landscaping standards for a new:
7078 (A) commercial, industrial, or institutional development;
7079 (B) common interest community, as defined in Section 57-25-102; or
7080 (C) multifamily housing project.
7081 (3) The proposed general plan may include:
7082 (a) an environmental element that addresses:
7083 (i) to the extent not covered by the county's resource management plan, the protection, conservation,
development, and use of natural resources, including the quality of:

SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
7086 (A) air;
7087 (B) forests;
7088 (C) soils;
7089 (D) rivers;
7090 (E) groundwater and other waters;
7091 (F) harbors;
7092 (G) fisheries;
7093 (H) wildlife;
7094 (I) minerals; and
7095 (J) other natural resources; and
7096 (ii)
(A) the reclamation of land, flood control, prevention and control of the pollution of streams and other
waters;
7098 (B) the regulation of the use of land on hillsides, stream channels and other environmentally sensitive
areas;
7100 (C) the prevention, control, and correction of the erosion of soils;
7101 (D) the preservation and enhancement of watersheds and wetlands; and
7102 (E) the mapping of known geologic hazards;
7103 (b) a public services and facilities element showing general plans for sewage, water, waste disposal,
drainage, public utilities, rights-of-way, easements, and facilities for them, police and fire
protection, and other public services;
7106 (c) a rehabilitation, redevelopment, and conservation element consisting of plans and programs for:
7108 (i) historic preservation;
7109 (ii) the diminution or elimination of a development impediment as defined in Section 17C-1-102; and
7111 (iii) redevelopment of land, including housing sites, business and industrial sites, and public building
sites;
7113 (d) an economic element composed of appropriate studies and forecasts, as well as an economic
development plan, which may include review of existing and projected county revenue and
expenditures, revenue sources, identification of basic and secondary industry, primary and
secondary market areas, employment, and retail sales activity;
7118
- 226 -

SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
(e) recommendations for implementing all or any portion of the general plan, including the adoption of
land and water use ordinances, capital improvement plans, community development and promotion,
and any other appropriate action;
7121 (f) provisions addressing any of the matters listed in Subsection [17-27a-401(2)] 17-79-401(2) or [(3)(a)
(i)] 17-79-402(1); and
7123 (g) any other element the county considers appropriate.
7162 Section 182. Section 17-79-404 is renumbered and amended to read:
7164 [17-27a-404] 17-79-404. Public hearing by planning commission on proposed general plan
or amendment -- Notice -- Revisions to general plan or amendment -- Adoption or rejection by
legislative body.
7129 (1)
(a) After completing the planning commission's recommendation for a proposed general plan, or
proposal to amend the general plan, the planning commission shall schedule and hold a public
hearing on the proposed plan or amendment.
7132 (b) The planning commission shall provide notice of the public hearing for the county, as a class A
notice under Section 63G-30-102, for at least 10 calendar days before the day of the public hearing.
7135 (c) After the public hearing, the planning commission may modify the proposed general plan or
amendment.
7137 (2) The planning commission shall forward the proposed general plan or amendment to the legislative
body.
7139 (3)
(a) As provided by local ordinance and by Section [17-27a-204] 17-79-204, the legislative body shall
provide notice of the legislative body's intent to consider the general plan proposal.
7142 (b)
(i)
(A) In addition to the requirements of Subsections (1), (2), and (3)(a), the legislative body shall
hold a public hearing in Salt Lake City on provisions of the proposed county plan regarding
Subsection [17-27a-401(4)] 17-79-402(3).
7145 (B) The public hearing procedure shall comply with this Subsection (3)(b).
7146 (ii) The public hearing format shall allow:
7147 (A) adequate time for public comment at the actual public hearing[,] ; and[ shall also allow]
- 227 -

SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
7149 (B) for public comment in writing to be submitted to the legislative body for not fewer than 90 days
after the date of the public hearing.
7151 (c)
(i) The legislative body shall give notice of the hearing in accordance with this Subsection (3) when the
proposed plan provisions required by Subsection [17-27a-401(4)] 17-79-402(3) are complete.
7154 (ii) Direct notice of the public hearing shall be given, in writing, to:
7155 (A) the governor[,] ;
7156 (B) members of the state Legislature[,] ;
7157 (C) the executive director of the Department of Environmental Quality[,] ;
7158 (D) the state planning coordinator[,] ;
7159 (E) the Resource Development Coordinating Committee[,] created in Section 63L-11-401; and
7161 (F) any other citizens or entities who specifically request notice of the public hearing in writing.
7163 (iii) Public notice shall be given for the county, as a class A notice under Section 63G-30-102, for at
least 180 days.
7165 (iv) The notice shall be published to allow reasonable time for interested parties and the state to
evaluate the information regarding Subsection [17-27a-401(4)] 17-79-402(3), including publication
described in Subsection (3)(c)(iii) for 180 days before the date of the hearing to be held under this
Subsection (3).
7169 (4)
(a) After the public hearing required under this section, the legislative body may adopt, reject, or make
any revisions to the proposed general plan that the legislative body considers appropriate.
7172 (b) The legislative body shall respond in writing and in a substantive manner to all those providing
comments as a result of the hearing required by Subsection (3).
7174 (c) If the county legislative body rejects the proposed general plan or amendment, the legislative body
may provide suggestions to the planning commission for the planning commission's review and
recommendation.
7177 (5) The legislative body shall adopt the following elements and plans in conformity with the
requirements of Section 17-79-403:
7179 (a) a land use element[ as provided in Subsection 17-27a-403(2)(a)(i)];
7180 (b) a transportation and traffic circulation element[ as provided in Subsection 17-27a-403(2)(a)(ii)];
7182
- 228 -

SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
(c) for a specified county as defined in Section [17-27a-408] 17-80-101, a moderate income housing
element[ as provided in Subsection 17-27a-403(2)(a)(iii)];
7184 (d) a resource management plan[ as provided by Subsection 17-27a-403(2)(a)(iv)]; and
7185 (e) on or before December 31, 2025, a water use and preservation element[ as provided in Subsection
17-27a-403(2)(a)(v)].
7225 Section 183. Section 17-79-405 is renumbered and amended to read:
7227 [17-27a-405] 17-79-405. Effect of general plan -- Coordination with federal government.
7191 (1) Except for the mandatory provisions in Subsection [17-27a-401(4)(b)] 17-79-402(3)(b) and Section
[17-27a-406] 17-79-406, and except as provided in Subsection (3), the general plan is an advisory
guide for land use decisions, the impact of which shall be determined by ordinance.
7195 (2) The legislative body may adopt an ordinance mandating compliance with the general plan, and
shall adopt an ordinance requiring compliance with all provisions of Subsection [17-27a-401(4)
(b)] 17-79-402(3)(b).
7198 (3)
(a) As used in this Subsection (3), "coordinate with" means an action taken by the federal government
on a given matter, [pursuant to] in accordance with a federal law, rule, policy, or regulation, to:
7201 (i) work with a county on the matter to achieve a consistent outcome;
7202 (ii) make resource management plans in conjunction with a county on the matter;
7203 (iii) make resource management plans consistent with a county's plans on the matter;
7204 (iv) integrate a county's plans on the matter into the federal government's plans; or
7205 (v) follow a county's plans when contemplating any action on the matter.
7206 (b) If the federal government is required to coordinate with a county or a local government on a matter,
the county's general plan is the principle document through which the coordination shall take place.
7209 (c) The federal government is not considered to have coordinated with a county or a local government
on a matter unless the federal government has:
7211 (i) kept the county apprised of the federal government's proposed plans, amendments, policy changes,
and management actions with regard to the matter;
7213 (ii) worked with the county in developing and implementing plans, policies, and management actions
on the matter;
7215 (iii) treated the county as an equal partner in negotiations related to the matter;
7216
- 229 -

SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
(iv) listened to and understood the county's position on the matter to determine whether a conflict exists
between the federal government's proposed plan, policy, rule, or action and the county's general
plan;
7219 (v) worked with the county in an amicable manner to reconcile any differences or disagreements, to
the greatest extent possible under federal law, between the federal government and the county with
regards to plans, policies, rules, or proposed management actions that relate to the matter;
7223 (vi) engaged in a good-faith effort to reconcile any conflicts discovered under Subsection (3)(c)(iv)
to achieve, to the greatest extent possible under federal law, consistency between the federal
government's proposed plan, policy, rule, or action and the county's general plan; and
7227 (vii) given full consideration to a county's general plan to the extent that the general plan addresses the
matter.
7267 Section 184. Section 17-79-406 is renumbered and amended to read:
7269 [17-27a-406] 17-79-406. Public uses to conform to general plan.
After the legislative body has adopted a general plan, the following public properties
may not be constructed or authorized unless the public property conforms to the current county
general plan:
7236 (1) [no] a street, park, or other public way, ground, place, or space[, no] ;
7237 (2) a publicly owned building or structure[,] ; and [no]
7238 (3) a public utility, whether publicly or privately owned[, may be constructed or authorized until and
unless it conforms to the current general plan].
7278 Section 185. Section 17-79-407 is renumbered and amended to read:
7280 [17-27a-407] 17-79-407. Effect of official maps.
7243 (1) Counties may adopt an official map.
7244 (2)
(a) An official map does not:
7245 (i) require a landowner to dedicate and construct a street as a condition of development approval,
except under circumstances provided in Subsection (2)(b)(iii); or
7248 (ii) require a county to immediately acquire property it has designated for eventual use as a public
street.
7250 (b) This section does not prohibit a county from:
7251
- 230 -

SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
(i) recommending that an applicant consider and accommodate the location of the proposed
streets in the planning of a development proposal in a manner that is consistent with Section
[17-27a-507] 17-79-812;
7254 (ii) acquiring the property through purchase, gift, voluntary dedication, or eminent domain; or
7256 (iii) requiring the dedication and improvement of a street if the street is found necessary by the county
because of a proposed development and if the dedication and improvement is consistent with

7297 Section 186. Section 17-79-408 is renumbered and amended to read:
7299 [17-27a-901] 17-79-408. Mountainous planning district.
7262 (1)
(a) The legislative body of a county of the first class may adopt an ordinance designating an area
located within the county as a mountainous planning district if the legislative body determines that:
7265 (i) the area is primarily used for recreational purposes, including canyons, foothills, ski resorts,
wilderness areas, lakes and reservoirs, campgrounds, or picnic areas within the Wasatch Range;
7268 (ii) the area is used by residents of the county who live inside and outside the limits of a
municipality;
7270 (iii) the total resident population in the proposed mountainous planning district is equal to or less
than 5% of the population of the county;
7272 (iv) the area is within the unincorporated area of the county or was within the unincorporated area
of the county before May 12, 2015; and
7274 (v) the area includes land designated as part of a national forest on or before May 9, 2017.
7276 (b) The population figure under Subsection (1)(a)(iii) shall be derived from a population estimate by the
Utah Population Committee created in Section 63C-20-103.
7278 (2)
(a) A county may adopt a general plan and adopt a zoning or subdivision ordinance for a property that is
located within a mountainous planning district.
7280 (b) A county plan or zoning or subdivision ordinance governs a property described in Subsection (2)(a).
7320 Section 187. Section 17-79-501 is renumbered and amended to read:
7284
Part 5. Land Use Regulations - General Processes
7323 [17-27a-501] 17-79-501. Enactment of land use regulation.
7286
- 231 -

SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
(1) Only a legislative body, as the body authorized to weigh policy considerations, may enact a land use
regulation.
7288 (2)
(a) Except as provided in Subsection (2)(b), a legislative body may enact a land use regulation only by
ordinance.
7290 (b) A legislative body may, by ordinance or resolution, enact a land use regulation that imposes a fee.
7292 (3) A land use regulation shall be consistent with the purposes set forth in this chapter.
7293 (4)
(a) A legislative body shall adopt a land use regulation to:
7294 (i) create or amend a zoning district under Subsection [17-27a-503(1)(a)] 17-79-503(1)(a); and
7296 (ii) designate general uses allowed in each zoning district.
7297 (b) A land use authority may establish or modify other restrictions or requirements other than those
described in Subsection (4)(a), including the configuration or modification of uses or density,
through a land use decision that applies criteria or policy elements that a land use regulation
establishes or describes.
7301 (5) A county may not adopt a land use regulation, development agreement, or land use decision that
restricts the type of crop that may be grown in an area that is:
7303 (a) zoned agricultural; or
7304 (b) assessed under Title 59, Chapter 2, Part 5, Farmland Assessment Act.
7305 (6) A county land use regulation pertaining to an airport or an airport influence area, as that term is
defined in Section 72-10-401, is subject to Title 72, Chapter 10, Part 4, Airport Zoning Act.
