9616 (1) As used in this section:
9617
- 299 -

SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
(a) "Business day" means Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday, or Friday, unless the day falls on a
federal, state, or county holiday.
9619 (b) "Nonidentical plan" means a plan that does not meet the definition of an identical plan in Section
[17-27a-103] 17-79-102.
9621 (c) "Original plan" means the same as that term is defined in Section 10-9a-541.
9622 (2) An applicant may submit, and a county shall review, an identical plan as described in this section.
9624 (3) At the time of submitting an identical plan for review to a county, an applicant shall:
9625 (a) mark the floor plan as "identical plans";
9626 (b) identify in writing:
9627 (i) the building permit number the county issued for the original plan:
9628 (A) that was previously approved by the county; and
9629 (B) to which the submitted floor plan qualifies as an identical plan; or
9630 (ii) the identifying index number assigned by the county to the original plan, as described in Subsection
(5)(b); and
9632 (c) identify the site on which the applicant intends to implement the identical plan.
9633 (4) Beginning May 7, 2025, an applicant that intends to submit an identical plan for review to a county
shall:
9635 (a) indicate, at the time of submitting an original plan to the county for review and approval, that the
applicant intends to use the original plan as the basis for submitting a future identical plan if the
original plan is approved by the county; and
9638 (b) identify:
9639 (i) the name or other identifier of the original plan; and
9640 (ii) the zone the building will be located in, if the county approves the original plan.
9641 (5) Upon approving an original plan and receiving the information described in Subsection (4), a county
shall:
9643 (a) file and index the original plan for future reference against an identical plan later submitted under
Subsection (2); and
9645 (b) provide the applicant with an identifying index number for the original plan.
9646 (6) A county that receives a submission under Subsection (2) shall review and compare the submitted
identical plan to the original plan to ensure:
9648 (a) the identical plan and original plan are substantially identical; and
- 300 -

SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
9649 (b) no structural changes have been made from the original plan.
9650 (7) Nothing in this section prohibits a county from conducting a site review and requiring geological
analysis of the proposed site identified by the applicant under Subsection (3)(c).
9653 (8) A county shall:
9654 (a) review a submitted identical plan for compliance with this section; and
9655 (b) approve or reject the identical plan within five business days after the day on which the identical
plan was submitted under Subsection (2).
9657 (9) An applicant that submits a nonidentical plan to a county as an identical plan, with knowledge that
the nonidentical plan does not qualify as an identical plan and with intent to deceive the county:
9660 (a) may be fined by the county receiving the submission of the nonidentical plan:
9661 (i) in an amount not to exceed three times the building permit fee, if the county approved the
nonidentical plan as an identical plan before discovering the submission did not qualify as an
identical plan; or
9664 (ii) in an amount equal to the building permit fee that would have been issued for the nonidentical plan,
if the county did not approve the nonidentical plan before discovering the submission did not qualify
as an identical plan; and
9667 (b) is prohibited from submitting an identical plan for review and approval under this section for a
period of two years from the day on which the county discovers the nonidentical plan identified as
an identical plan in the applicant's submission did not qualify as an identical plan.
9671 (10) A county may impose a criminal penalty, as described in Section [17-53-223] 17-64-501, for an
applicant that knowingly violates the prohibition described in Subsection (9)(b).
9712 Section 240. Section 17-79-810 is renumbered and amended to read:
9714 [17-27a-537] 17-79-810. Fees collected for construction approval -- Approval of plans.
9678 (1) As used in this section:

regulation, or ordinance to ensure that a plan meets all of a county's required criteria for approval.

SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
(ii) any work requiring a permit for construction of or on a one- or two-family dwelling, a townhome, or

public, including any of the following:
9692 (i) a bed and breakfast establishment;
9693 (ii) a boarding house;
9694 (iii) a dormitory;

9699 (viii) a resort; or
9700 (ix) a rooming house.
9701 (e)
(i) "Plan review" means all of the reviews and approvals of a plan that a county, including all relevant
divisions or departments within a county, requires before issuing a building permit, with a scope that
may not exceed a review to verify:
9704 (A) that the construction project complies with the provisions of the State Construction Code under
Title 15A, State Construction and Fire Codes Act;
9706 (B) that the construction project complies with the energy code adopted under Section 15A-2-103;
9708 (C) that the construction project complies with local ordinances;
9709 (D) that the applicant paid any required fees;
9710 (E) that the applicant obtained final approvals from any other required reviewing agencies;

9715 (H) that the plans include a printed statement indicating that, before the disturbance of land and

laws and ordinances, including any storm water protection laws and ordinances.

- 302 -

SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
(A) a document required to be re-submitted for a construction project other than a construction project

by the building official;

9733 (h) "State Fire Code" means the same as that term is defined in Section 15A-1-102.

9740 (D) nailing patterns;

9743 (G) sheathing; or
9744 (ii) if the review exceeds the scope of the review described in Subsection (1)(j)(i), a review that a
licensed engineer conducts.
9746 (k) "Technical nature" means a characteristic that places an item outside the training and expertise of an
individual who regularly performs plan reviews.
9748 (2)
(a) If a county collects a fee for the inspection of a construction project, the county shall ensure that the
construction project receives a prompt inspection.
9750 (b) If a county cannot provide a building inspection within three business days after the day on which
the county receives the request for the inspection, the applicant may engage an inspection with

a third-party inspection firm from the third-party inspection firm list, as described in Section

(a)

9766 (ii) If the county determines an application for a plan review is complete, as described in Subsection
(12), within the screening period, the county shall begin the plan review process described in
Subsection (4).
9769 (b) If the county determines that an application for a plan review is not complete as described in
Subsection (12), and if the county notifies the applicant of the county's determination:
9772 (i) before 5 p.m. on the last day of the screening period, the county may:
9773 (A) pause the screening period until the applicant ensures the application meets the requirements of
Subsection (12); or
9775 (B) reject the incomplete application; or
9776 (ii) after 5 p.m. on the last day of the screening period, the county may not pause the screening period
and shall begin the plan review process described in Subsection (4).
9779 (c) If an application is rejected as described in Subsection (3)(b)(i)(B) and an applicant resubmits the
application, the resubmission begins a new screening period in which the county shall review the
resubmitted application to determine if the application is complete as described in Subsection (12).
9783 (d) If the county gives notice of an incomplete application after 5 p.m. on the last day of the screening
period, the county:

(i) shall immediately notify the applicant that the county has determined the application is not complete
and the basis for the determination;

application complete; and

the information described in Subsection (4)(c)(ii) to consider whether the application meets the
requirements for a building permit, even if the five additional days extend beyond the relevant time
period described in Subsection 4(a) or (b).

adopted under Section 15A-2-103; and

9956 Section 242. Section 17-79-812 is renumbered and amended to read:
9958 [17-27a-507] 17-79-812. Exactions -- Exaction for water interest -- Requirement to offer to
original owner property acquired by exaction.
9922 (1) A county may impose an exaction or exactions on development proposed in a land use application,
including, subject to Subsection (3), an exaction for a water interest, if:
9924 (a) an essential link exists between a legitimate governmental interest and each exaction; and
9926 (b) each exaction is roughly proportionate, both in nature and extent, to the impact of the proposed
development.
9928 (2) If a land use authority imposes an exaction for another governmental entity:
9929 (a) the governmental entity shall request the exaction; and
9930 (b) the land use authority shall transfer the exaction to the governmental entity for which it was exacted.
9932 (3)
(a)
(i) Subject to the requirements of this Subsection (3), a county or, if applicable, the county's
culinary water authority shall base any exaction for a water interest on the culinary water
authority's established calculations of projected water interest requirements.
9936 (ii) Except as described in Subsection (3)(a)(iii), a culinary water authority shall base an exaction
for a culinary water interest on:
9938 (A) consideration of the system-wide minimum sizing standards established for the culinary water
authority by the Division of Drinking Water [pursuant to] in accordance with Section 19-4-114; and
9941 (B) the number of equivalent residential connections associated with the culinary water demand for
each specific development proposed in the development's land use application, applying lower
exactions for developments with lower equivalent residential connections as demonstrated by at
least five years of usage data for like land uses within the county.
9946 (iii) A county or culinary water authority may impose an exaction for a culinary water interest that
results in less water being exacted than would otherwise be exacted under Subsection (3)(a)
(ii) if the county or culinary water authority, at the county's or culinary water authority's sole
discretion, determines there is good cause to do so.
9951
- 309 -

SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
(iv) A county shall make public the methodology used to comply with Subsection (3)(a)(ii)(B).
A land use applicant may appeal to the county's governing body an exaction calculation used
by the county or the county's culinary water authority under Subsection (3)(a)(ii). A land
use applicant may present data and other information that illustrates a need for an exaction
recalculation and the county's governing body shall respond with due process.
9957 (v) Upon an applicant's request, the culinary water authority shall provide the applicant with the
basis for the culinary water authority's calculations under Subsection (3)(a)(i) on which an
exaction for a water interest is based.
9960 (b) A county or [its] the county's culinary water authority may not impose an exaction for a water
interest if the culinary water authority's existing available water interests exceed the water interests
needed to meet the reasonable future water requirement of the public, as determined under
Subsection 73-1-4(2)(f).
9964 (4)
(a) If a county plans to dispose of surplus real property under Section [17-50-312] 17-78-103 that was
acquired under this section and has been owned by the county for less than 15 years, the county
shall first offer to reconvey the property, without receiving additional consideration, to the person
who granted the property to the county.
9969 (b) A person to whom a county offers to reconvey property under Subsection (4)(a) has 90 days to
accept or reject the county's offer.
9971 (c) If a person to whom a county offers to reconvey property declines the offer, the county may offer
the property for sale.
9973 (d) Subsection (4)(a) does not apply to the disposal of property acquired by exaction by a community
development or urban renewal agency.
9975 (5)
(a) A county may not, as part of an infrastructure improvement, require the installation of pavement on
a residential roadway at a width in excess of 32 feet.
9977 (b) Subsection (5)(a) does not apply if a county requires the installation of pavement in excess of 32
feet:
9979 (i) in a vehicle turnaround area;
9980 (ii) in a cul-de-sac;
9981 (iii) to address specific traffic flow constraints at an intersection, mid-block crossings, or other areas;
- 310 -

SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
9983 (iv) to address an applicable general or master plan improvement, including transportation, bicycle
lanes, trails, or other similar improvements that are not included within an impact fee area;
9986 (v) to address traffic flow constraints for service to or abutting higher density developments or uses that
generate higher traffic volumes, including community centers, schools, and other similar uses;
9989 (vi) as needed for the installation or location of a utility which is maintained by the county and is
considered a transmission line or requires additional roadway width;
9991 (vii) for third-party utility lines that have an easement preventing the installation of utilities maintained
by the county within the roadway;
9993 (viii) for utilities over 12 feet in depth;
9994 (ix) for roadways with a design speed that exceeds 25 miles per hour;
9995 (x) as needed for flood and stormwater routing;
9996 (xi) as needed to meet fire code requirements for parking and hydrants; or
9997 (xii) as needed to accommodate street parking.
9998 (c) Nothing in this section shall be construed to prevent a county from approving a road cross section
with a pavement width less than 32 feet.
1 0000 (d)
(i) A land use applicant may appeal a municipal requirement for pavement in excess of 32 feet on a
residential roadway.
1 0002 (ii) A land use applicant that has appealed a municipal specification for a residential roadway pavement
width in excess of 32 feet may request that the county assemble a panel of qualified experts to serve
as the appeal authority for purposes of determining the technical aspects of the appeal.
1 0006 (iii) Unless otherwise agreed by the applicant and the county, the panel described in Subsection (5)(d)
(ii) shall consist of the following three experts:
1 0008 (A) one licensed engineer, designated by the county;
1 0009 (B) one licensed engineer, designated by the land use applicant; and
1 0010 (C) one licensed engineer, agreed upon and designated by the two designated engineers under
Subsections (5)(d)(iii)(A) and (B).
1 0012 (iv) A member of the panel assembled by the county under Subsection (5)(d)(ii) may not have an
interest in the application that is the subject of the appeal.
1 0014 (v) The land use applicant shall pay:
1 0015 (A) 50% of the cost of the panel; and
- 311 -

SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
1 0016 (B) the county's published appeal fee.
1 0017 (vi) The decision of the panel is a final decision, subject to a petition for review under Subsection (5)(d)
(vii).
1 0019 (vii) [Pursuant to] In accordance with Section [17-27a-801] 17-79-1009, a land use applicant or the
county may file a petition for review of the decision with the district court within 30 days after the
date that the decision is final.
1 0060 Section 243. Section 17-79-901 is renumbered and amended to read:
1 0024
Part 9. Enforcement
1 0063 [17-27a-802] 17-79-901. Enforcement -- Limitations on a county's ability to enforce an
ordinance by withholding a permit or certificate.
1 0027 (1)
(a) A county or an adversely affected party may, in addition to other remedies provided by law,
institute:
1 0029 (i) injunctions, mandamus, abatement, or any other appropriate actions; or
1 0030 (ii) proceedings to prevent, enjoin, abate, or remove the unlawful building, use, or act.
1 0031 (b) A county need only establish the violation to obtain the injunction.
1 0032 (2)
(a) Except as provided in Subsections (3) through (6), a county may enforce the county's ordinance by
withholding a building permit or certificate of occupancy.
1 0034 (b) It is unlawful to erect, construct, reconstruct, alter, or change the use of any building or other
structure within a county without approval of a building permit.
1 0036 (c) The county may not issue a building permit unless the plans of and for the proposed erection,
construction, reconstruction, alteration, or use fully conform to all regulations then in effect.
1 0039 (d) A county may require an applicant to install a permanent road, cover a temporary road with asphalt
or concrete, or create another method for servicing a structure that is consistent with Appendix D of
the International Fire Code, before receiving a certificate of occupancy for that structure.
1 0043 (e) A county may require an applicant to maintain and repair a temporary fire apparatus road during
the construction of a structure accessed by the temporary fire apparatus road in accordance with the
county's adopted standards.
1 0046 (f) A county may require temporary signs to be installed at each street intersection once construction of
new roadway allows passage by a motor vehicle.
- 312 -

SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
1 0048 (g) A county may adopt and enforce any appendix of the International Fire Code, 2021 Edition.
1 0050 (3)
(a) A county may not deny an applicant a building permit or certificate of occupancy because the
applicant has not completed an infrastructure improvement:
1 0052 (i) unless the infrastructure improvement is essential to meet the requirements for the issuance of a
building permit or certificate of occupancy under Title 15A, State Construction and Fire Codes
Act; and
1 0055 (ii) for which the county has accepted an improvement completion assurance for a public
landscaping improvement, as defined in Section [17-27a-604.5] 17-79-707, or an infrastructure
improvement for the development.
1 0058 (b) For purposes of Subsection (3)(a)(i), notwithstanding Section 15A-5-205.6, infrastructure
improvement that is essential means:
1 0060 (i) operable fire hydrants installed in a manner that is consistent with the county's adopted engineering
standards; and
1 0062 (ii) for temporary roads used during construction, a properly compacted road base installed in a manner
consistent with the county's adopted engineering standards.
1 0064 (c) A county may not adopt an engineering standard that requires an applicant to install a permanent
road or a temporary road with asphalt or concrete before receiving a building permit.
1 0067 (4) A county may not deny an applicant a building permit or certificate of occupancy for failure to:
1 0069 (a) submit a private landscaping plan, as defined in Section [17-27a-604.5] 17-79-707; or
1 0070 (b) complete a landscaping improvement that is not a public landscaping improvement, as defined in
Section [17-27a-604.5] 17-79-707.
1 0072 (5) A county may not withhold a building permit based on the lack of completion of a portion of a
public sidewalk to be constructed within a public right-of-way serving a lot where a single-family or
two-family residence or town home is proposed in a building permit application if an improvement
completion assurance has been posted for the incomplete portion of the public sidewalk.
1 0077 (6) A county may not prohibit the construction of a single-family or two-family residence or town
home, withhold recording a plat, or withhold acceptance of a public landscaping improvement, as
defined in Section [17-27a-604.5] 17-79-707, or an infrastructure improvement based on the lack
of installation of a public sidewalk if an improvement completion assurance has been posted for the
public sidewalk.
- 313 -

SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
1 0082 (7) A county may not redeem an improvement completion assurance securing the installation of a
public sidewalk sooner than 18 months after the date the improvement completion assurance is
posted.
1 0085 (8) A county shall allow an applicant to post an improvement completion assurance for a public
sidewalk separate from an improvement completion assurance for:
1 0087 (a) another infrastructure improvement; or
1 0088 (b) a public landscaping improvement, as defined in Section [17-27a-604.5] 17-79-707.
1 0089 (9) A county may withhold a certificate of occupancy for a single-family or two-family residence or
town home until the portion of the public sidewalk to be constructed within a public right-of-way
and located immediately adjacent to the single-family or two-family residence or town home is
completed and accepted by the county.
1 0131 Section 244. Section 17-79-902 is renumbered and amended to read:
1 0133 [17-27a-803] 17-79-902. Penalties -- Notice.
1 0096 (1) The county may, by ordinance, establish civil penalties for violations of any of the provisions of this
chapter or of any ordinances adopted under the authority of this chapter.
1 0099 (2) Violation of any of the provisions of this chapter or of any ordinances adopted under the authority of
this chapter is punishable as a class C misdemeanor upon conviction either:
1 0101 (a) as a class C misdemeanor; or
1 0102 (b) by imposing the appropriate civil penalty adopted under the authority of this section.
1 0103 (3) [Prior to ] Before imposing upon an owner of record a civil penalty established by ordinance under
authority of this chapter, a county shall provide:
1 0105 (a) written notice, by mail or hand delivery, of each ordinance violation to the address of the:
1 0107 (i) owner of record on file in the office of the county recorder; or
1 0108 (ii) person designated, in writing, by the owner of record as the owner's agent for the purpose of
receiving notice of an ordinance violation;
1 0110 (b) the owner of record a reasonable opportunity to cure a noticed violation; and
1 0111 (c) a schedule of the civil penalties that may be imposed upon the expiration of a time certain.
1 0151 Section 245. Section 17-79-903 is renumbered and amended to read:
1 0153 [17-27a-510] 17-79-903. Nonconforming uses and noncomplying structures.
1 0117 (1)
- 314 -

SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
(a) Except as provided in this section, a nonconforming use or a noncomplying structure may be
continued by the present or a future property owner.
1 0119 (b) A nonconforming use may be extended through the same building, provided no structural alteration
of the building is proposed or made for the purpose of the extension.
1 0122 (c) For purposes of this Subsection (1), the addition of a solar energy device to a building is not a
structural alteration.
1 0124 (2) The legislative body may provide for:
1 0125 (a) the establishment, restoration, reconstruction, extension, alteration, expansion, or substitution of
nonconforming uses upon the terms and conditions set forth in the land use ordinance;
1 0128 (b) the termination of all nonconforming uses, except billboards, by providing a formula establishing
a reasonable time period during which the owner can recover or amortize the amount of his
investment in the nonconforming use, if any; and
1 0131 (c) the termination of a nonconforming use due to its abandonment.
1 0132 (3)
(a) A county may not prohibit the reconstruction or restoration of a noncomplying structure or terminate
the nonconforming use of a structure that is involuntarily destroyed in whole or in part due to fire or
other calamity unless the structure or use has been abandoned.
1 0136 (b) A county may prohibit the reconstruction or restoration of a noncomplying structure or terminate the
nonconforming use of a structure if:
1 0138 (i) the structure is allowed to deteriorate to a condition that the structure is rendered uninhabitable
and is not repaired or restored within six months after the day on which written notice is served
to the property owner that the structure is uninhabitable and that the noncomplying structure or
nonconforming use will be lost if the structure is not repaired or restored within six months; or
1 0143 (ii) the property owner has voluntarily demolished a majority of the noncomplying structure or the
building that houses the nonconforming use.
1 0145 (c)
(i) Notwithstanding a prohibition in the county's zoning ordinance, a county may permit a billboard
owner to relocate the billboard within the county's unincorporated area to a location that is mutually
acceptable to the county and the billboard owner.
1 0149
- 315 -

SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
(ii) If the county and billboard owner cannot agree to a mutually acceptable location within 180 days
after the day on which the owner submits a written request to relocate the billboard, the billboard
owner may relocate the billboard in accordance with Subsection [17-27a-512(2)] 17-79-605(2).
1 0153 (4)
(a) Unless the county establishes, by ordinance, a uniform presumption of legal existence for
nonconforming uses, the property owner shall have the burden of establishing the legal existence
of a noncomplying structure or nonconforming use through substantial evidence, which may not be
limited to municipal or county records.
1 0158 (b) Any party claiming that a nonconforming use has been abandoned shall have the burden of
establishing the abandonment.
1 0160 (c) Abandonment may be presumed to have occurred if:
1 0161 (i) a majority of the primary structure associated with the nonconforming use has been voluntarily
demolished without prior written agreement with the county regarding an extension of the
nonconforming use;
1 0164 (ii) the use has been discontinued for a minimum of one year; or
1 0165 (iii) the primary structure associated with the nonconforming use remains vacant for a period of one
year.
1 0167 (d) The property owner may rebut the presumption of abandonment under Subsection (4)(c), and has
the burden of establishing that any claimed abandonment under Subsection (4)(c) has not occurred.
1 0170 (5) A county may terminate the nonconforming status of a school district or charter school use or
structure when the property associated with the school district or charter school use or structure
ceases to be used for school district or charter school purposes for a period established by ordinance.
1 0212 Section 246. Section 17-79-1001 is renumbered and amended to read:
1 0176
Part 10. Appeal Authority, Variances, and District Court Review
1 0215 [17-27a-701] 17-79-1001. Appeal authority required -- Condition precedent to judicial
review -- Appeal authority duties.
1 0179 (1)
(a) Each county adopting a land use ordinance shall, by ordinance, establish one or more appeal
authorities.
1 0181 (b) An appeal authority shall hear and decide:
1 0182 (i) requests for variances from the terms of land use ordinances;
- 316 -

SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
1 0183 (ii) appeals from land use decisions applying land use ordinances; and
1 0184 (iii) appeals from a fee charged in accordance with Section [17-27a-509] 17-79-802.
1 0185 (c) An appeal authority may not hear an appeal from the enactment of a land use regulation.
1 0187 (2) As a condition precedent to judicial review, each adversely affected party shall timely and
specifically challenge a land use authority's land use decision, in accordance with local ordinance.
1 0190 (3) An appeal authority described in Subsection (1)(a):
1 0191 (a) shall:
1 0192 (i) act in a quasi-judicial manner; and
1 0193 (ii) serve as the final arbiter of issues involving the interpretation or application of land use ordinances;
and
1 0195 (b) may not entertain an appeal of a matter in which the appeal authority, or any participating member,
had first acted as the land use authority.
1 0197 (4) By ordinance, a county may:
1 0198 (a) designate a separate appeal authority to hear requests for variances than the appeal authority the
county designates to hear appeals;
1 0200 (b) designate one or more separate appeal authorities to hear distinct types of appeals of land use
authority decisions;
1 0202 (c) require an adversely affected party to present to an appeal authority every theory of relief that the
adversely affected party can raise in district court;
1 0204 (d) not require a land use applicant or adversely affected party to pursue duplicate or successive appeals
before the same or separate appeal authorities as a condition of an appealing party's duty to exhaust
administrative remedies; and
1 0207 (e) provide that specified types of land use decisions may be appealed directly to the district court.
1 0209 (5) A county may not require a public hearing for a request for a variance or land use appeal.
1 0210 (6) If the county establishes or, [prior to the effective date of this chapter] before May 2, 2005, has
established a multiperson board, body, or panel to act as an appeal authority, at a minimum the
board, body, or panel shall:
1 0213 (a) notify each of the members of the board, body, or panel of any meeting or hearing of the board,
body, or panel;
1 0215 (b) provide each of the members of the board, body, or panel with the same information and access to
municipal resources as any other member;
- 317 -

SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
1 0217 (c) convene only if a quorum of the members of the board, body, or panel is present; and
1 0218 (d) act only upon the vote of a majority of the convened members of the board, body, or panel.
1 0258 Section 247. Section 17-79-1002 is renumbered and amended to read:
1 0260 [17-27a-702] 17-79-1002. Variances.
1 0223 (1) Any person or entity desiring a waiver or modification of the requirements of a land use ordinance
as applied to a parcel of property that [he] the person or entity owns, leases, or in which [he] the
person or entity holds some other beneficial interest may apply to the applicable appeal authority for
a variance from the terms of the ordinance.
1 0227 (2)
(a) The appeal authority may grant a variance only if:
1 0228 (i) literal enforcement of the ordinance would cause an unreasonable hardship for the applicant that
is not necessary to carry out the general purpose of the land use ordinances;
1 0231 (ii) there are special circumstances attached to the property that do not generally apply to other
properties in the same zone;
1 0233 (iii) granting the variance is essential to the enjoyment of a substantial property right possessed by
other property in the same zone;
1 0235 (iv) the variance will not substantially affect the general plan and will not be contrary to the public
interest; and
1 0237 (v) the spirit of the land use ordinance is observed and substantial justice done.
1 0238 (b)
(i) In determining whether or not enforcement of the land use ordinance would cause unreasonable
hardship under Subsection (2)(a), the appeal authority may not find an unreasonable hardship unless
the alleged hardship:
1 0241 (A) is located on or associated with the property for which the variance is sought; and
1 0243 (B) comes from circumstances peculiar to the property, not from conditions that are general to the
neighborhood.
1 0245 (ii) In determining whether or not enforcement of the land use ordinance would cause unreasonable
hardship under Subsection (2)(a), the appeal authority may not find an unreasonable hardship if the
hardship is self-imposed or economic.
1 0248
- 318 -

SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
(c) In determining whether or not there are special circumstances attached to the property under
Subsection (2)(a), the appeal authority may find that special circumstances exist only if the special
circumstances:
1 0251 (i) relate to the hardship complained of; and
1 0252 (ii) deprive the property of privileges granted to other properties in the same zone.
1 0253 (3) The applicant shall bear the burden of proving that all of the conditions justifying a variance have
been met.
1 0255 (4) Variances run with the land.
1 0256 (5) The appeal authority may not grant a use variance.
1 0257 (6) In granting a variance, the appeal authority may impose additional requirements on the applicant
that will:
1 0259 (a) mitigate any harmful affects of the variance; or
1 0260 (b) serve the purpose of the standard or requirement that is waived or modified.
1 0299 Section 248. Section 17-79-1003 is renumbered and amended to read:
1 0301 [17-27a-703] 17-79-1003. Appealing a land use authority's decision -- Panel of experts for
appeals of geologic hazard decisions.
1 0265 (1) The land use applicant, a board or officer of the county, or an adversely affected party may, within
the time period provided by ordinance, appeal that decision to the appeal authority by alleging that
there is error in any order, requirement, decision, or determination made by the land use authority in
the administration or interpretation of the land use ordinance.
1 0270 (2)
(a) A land use applicant who has appealed a decision of the land use authority administering or
interpreting the county's geologic hazard ordinance may request the county to assemble a panel of
qualified experts to serve as the appeal authority for purposes of determining the technical aspects of
the appeal.
1 0274 (b) If a land use applicant makes a request under Subsection (2)(a), the county shall assemble the panel
described in Subsection (2)(a) consisting of, unless otherwise agreed by the land use applicant and
county:
1 0277 (i) one expert designated by the county;
1 0278 (ii) one expert designated by the land use applicant; and
1 0279
- 319 -

SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
(iii) one expert chosen jointly by the county's designated expert and the applicant's land use designated
expert.
1 0281 (c) A member of the panel assembled by the county under Subsection (2)(b) may not be associated with
the application that is the subject of the appeal.
1 0283 (d) The land use applicant shall pay:
1 0284 (i) 1/2 of the cost of the panel; and
1 0285 (ii) the county's published appeal fee.
1 0324 Section 249. Section 17-79-1004 is renumbered and amended to read:
1 0326 [17-27a-704] 17-79-1004. Time to appeal.
1 0289 (1) The county shall enact an ordinance establishing a reasonable time of not less than 10 days to appeal
to an appeal authority a written decision issued by a land use authority.
1 0291 (2) In the absence of an ordinance establishing a reasonable time to appeal, a land use applicant or
adversely affected party shall have 10 calendar days to appeal to an appeal authority a written
decision issued by a land use authority.
1 0332 Section 250. Section 17-79-1005 is renumbered and amended to read:
1 0334 [17-27a-705] 17-79-1005. Burden of proof.
The appellant has the burden of proving that the land use authority erred.
1 0336 Section 251. Section 17-79-1006 is renumbered and amended to read:
1 0338 [17-27a-706] 17-79-1006. Due process.
1 0301 (1) Each appeal authority shall conduct each appeal and variance request as described by local
ordinance.
1 0303 (2) Each appeal authority shall respect the due process rights of each of the participants.
1 0342 Section 252. Section 17-79-1007 is renumbered and amended to read:
1 0344 [17-27a-707] 17-79-1007. Scope of review of factual matters on appeal -- Appeal authority
requirements.
1 0308 (1) A county may, by ordinance, designate the scope of review of factual matters for appeals of land use
authority decisions.
1 0310 (2) If the county fails to designate a scope of review of factual matters, the appeal authority shall review
the matter de novo, without deference to the land use authority's determination of factual matters.
1 0313 (3) If the scope of review of factual matters is on the record, the appeal authority shall determine
whether the record on appeal includes substantial evidence for each essential finding of fact.
- 320 -

SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
1 0316 (4) The appeal authority shall:
1 0317 (a) determine the correctness of the land use authority's interpretation and application of the plain
meaning of the land use regulations; and
1 0319 (b) interpret and apply a land use regulation to favor a land use application unless the land use
regulation plainly restricts the land use application.
1 0321 (5)
(a) An appeal authority's land use decision is a quasi-judicial act.
1 0322 (b) A legislative body may act as an appeal authority unless both the legislative body and the appealing
party agree to allow a third party to act as the appeal authority.
1 0324 (6) Only a decision in which a land use authority has applied a land use regulation to a particular land
use application, person, or parcel may be appealed to an appeal authority.
1 0364 Section 253. Section 17-79-1008 is renumbered and amended to read:
1 0366 [17-27a-708] 17-79-1008. Final decision.
1 0329 (1) A decision of an appeal authority takes effect on the date when the appeal authority issues a written
decision, or as otherwise provided by local ordinance.
1 0331 (2) A written decision, or other event as provided by ordinance, constitutes a final decision
under Subsection [17-27a-801(2)(a)] 17-79-1009(2)(a) or a final action under Subsection
[17-27a-801(4)] 17-79-1009(4).
1 0372 Section 254. Section 17-79-1009 is renumbered and amended to read:
1 0374 [17-27a-801] 17-79-1009. No district court review until administrative remedies exhausted
-- Time for filing -- Tolling of time -- Standards governing court review -- Record on review --
Staying of decision.
1 0339 (1) No person may challenge in district court a land use decision until that person has exhausted
the person's administrative remedies as provided in Part 7, Appeal Authority and Variances, if
applicable.
1 0342 (2)
(a) Subject to Subsection (1), a land use applicant or adversely affected party may file a petition for
review of a land use decision with the district court within 30 days after the decision is final.
1 0345 (b)
- 321 -

SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
(i) The time under Subsection (2)(a) to file a petition is tolled from the date a property owner files a
request for arbitration of a constitutional taking issue with the property rights ombudsman under
Section 13-43-204 until 30 days after:
1 0348 (A) the arbitrator issues a final award; or
1 0349 (B) the property rights ombudsman issues a written statement under Subsection 13-43-204(3)(b)
declining to arbitrate or to appoint an arbitrator.
1 0351 (ii) A tolling under Subsection (2)(b)(i) operates only as to the specific constitutional taking issue that
is the subject of the request for arbitration filed with the property rights ombudsman by a property
owner.
1 0354 (iii) A request for arbitration filed with the property rights ombudsman after the time under Subsection
(2)(a) to file a petition has expired does not affect the time to file a petition.
1 0357 (3)
(a) A court shall:
1 0358 (i) presume that a land use regulation properly enacted under the authority of this chapter is valid;
and
1 0360 (ii) determine only whether:
1 0361 (A) the land use regulation is expressly preempted by, or was enacted contrary to, state or federal law;
and
1 0363 (B) it is reasonably debatable that the land use regulation is consistent with this chapter.
1 0365 (b) A court shall presume that a final land use decision of a land use authority or an appeal authority is
valid unless the land use decision is:
1 0367 (i) arbitrary and capricious; or
1 0368 (ii) illegal.
1 0369 (c)
(i) A land use decision is arbitrary and capricious if the land use decision is not supported by substantial
evidence in the record.
1 0371 (ii) A land use decision is illegal if the land use decision:
1 0372 (A) is based on an incorrect interpretation of a land use regulation;
1 0373 (B) conflicts with the authority granted by this title; or
1 0374 (C) is contrary to law.
1 0375 (d)
- 322 -

SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
(i) A court may affirm or reverse a land use decision.
1 0376 (ii) If the court reverses a land use decision, the court shall remand the matter to the land use authority
with instructions to issue a land use decision consistent with the court's decision.
1 0379 (4) The provisions of Subsection (2)(a) apply from the date on which the county takes final action on a
land use application, if the county conformed with the notice provisions of Part 2, Notice, or for any
person who had actual notice of the pending land use decision.
1 0382 (5) If the county has complied with Section [17-27a-205] 17-79-205, a challenge to the enactment of a
land use regulation or general plan may not be filed with the district court more than 30 days after
the enactment.
1 0385 (6) A challenge to a land use decision is barred unless the challenge is filed within 30 days after the
land use decision is final.
1 0387 (7)
(a) The land use authority or appeal authority, as the case may be, shall transmit to the reviewing court
the record of the proceedings of the land use authority or appeal authority, including the minutes,
findings, orders and, if available, a true and correct transcript of the proceedings.
1 0391 (b) If the proceeding was recorded, a transcript of that recording is a true and correct transcript for
purposes of this Subsection (7).
1 0393 (8)
(a)
(i) If there is a record, the district court's review is limited to the record provided by the land use
authority or appeal authority, as the case may be.
1 0395 (ii) The court may not accept or consider any evidence outside the record of the land use authority
or appeal authority, as the case may be, unless that evidence was offered to the land use
authority or appeal authority, respectively, and the court determines that the evidence was
improperly excluded.
1 0399 (b) If there is no record, the court may call witnesses and take evidence.
1 0400 (9)
(a) The filing of a petition does not stay the land use decision of the land use authority or appeal
authority, as the case may be.
1 0402 (b)
- 323 -

SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
(i) Before filing a petition under this section or a request for mediation or arbitration of a constitutional
taking issue under Section 13-43-204, a land use applicant may petition the appeal authority to stay
the appeal authority's decision.
1 0405 (ii) Upon receipt of a petition to stay, the appeal authority may order the appeal authority's decision
stayed pending district court review if the appeal authority finds the order to be in the best interest of
the county.
1 0408 (iii) After a petition is filed under this section or a request for mediation or arbitration of a constitutional
taking issue is filed under Section 13-43-204, the petitioner may seek an injunction staying the
appeal authority's land use decision.
1 0411 (10) If the court determines that a party initiated or pursued a challenge to a land use decision on a land
use application in bad faith, the court may award attorney fees.
1 0451 Section 255. Section 17-79-1010 is renumbered and amended to read:
1 0453 [17-27a-804] 17-79-1010. Consent agreement.
1 0416 (1) A legislative body may, by resolution or ordinance, settle litigation initiated under Section
[17-27a-801] 17-79-1009 regarding a land use decision with a property owner through a consent
agreement.
1 0419 (2) A legislative body shall approve the consent agreement under Subsection (1) in a public meeting in
accordance with Title 52, Chapter 4, Open and Public Meetings Act.
1 0421 (3) A legislative body is not required to present to a planning commission on any matter covered by a
consent agreement.
1 0461 Section 256. Section 17-80-101 is renumbered and amended to read:
1 0425
CHAPTER 80. Counties and Housing Supply
1 0426
Part 1. General Provisions
1 0465 [17-27a-1201] 17-80-101. Definitions.
As used in this part:
1 0429 (1) "Affordable housing" means housing offered for sale at 80% or less of the median county home
price for housing of that type.
1 0431 (2) "Agency" means the same as that term is defined in Section 17C-1-102.
1 0432 (3) "Base taxable value" means a property's taxable value as shown upon the assessment roll last
equalized during the base year.
- 324 -

SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
1 0434 (4) "Base year" means, for a proposed home ownership promotion zone area, a year beginning the first
day of the calendar quarter determined by the last equalized tax roll before the adoption of the home
ownership promotion zone.
1 0437 (5) "Division" means the Housing and Community Development Division within the Department of
Workforce Services.
1 0439 [(5)] (6) "Home ownership promotion zone" means a home ownership promotion zone created
[pursuant to] in accordance with this part.
1 0441 (7) "Implementation plan" means the implementation plan adopted as part of the moderate income
housing element of a specified county's general plan.
1 0443 (8) "Initial report" means the one-time moderate income housing report described in Subsection
17-80-202(1).
1 0445 (9) "Internal accessory dwelling unit" means an accessory dwelling unit created:
1 0446 (a) within a primary dwelling;
1 0447 (b) within the footprint of the detached primary dwelling at the time the internal accessory dwelling unit
is created; and
1 0449 (c) for the purpose of offering a long-term rental of 30 consecutive days or longer.
1 0450 (10) "Moderate income housing strategy" means a strategy described in Section 17-80-201.
1 0451 [(6)] (11) "Participant" means the same as that term is defined in Section 17C-1-102.
1 0452 [(7)] (12) "Participation agreement" means the same as that term is defined in Section 17C-1-102.
1 0454 (13)
(a) "Primary dwelling" means a single-family dwelling that:
1 0455 (i) is detached; and
1 0456 (ii) is occupied as the primary residence of the owner of record.
1 0457 (b) "Primary dwelling" includes a garage if the garage:
1 0458 (i) is a habitable space; and
1 0459 (ii) is connected to the primary dwelling by a common wall.
1 0460 [(8)] (14) "Project improvements" means the same as that term is defined in Section 11-36a-102.
1 0462 (15) "Report" means an initial report or a subsequent report described in Section 17-80-202.
1 0463 (16) "Specified county" means a county of the first, second, or third class, which has a population of
more than 5,000 in the county's unincorporated areas.
1 0465
- 325 -

SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
(17) "Subsequent progress report" means the annual moderate income housing report described in
Section 17-80-202.
1 0467 [(9)] (18) "System improvements" means the same as that term is defined in Section 11-36a-102.
1 0469 [(10)] (19) "Tax commission" means the State Tax Commission created in Section 59-1-201.
1 0470 [(11)] (20)
(a) "Tax increment" means the difference between:
1 0471 (i) the amount of property tax revenue generated each tax year by a taxing entity from the area
within a home ownership promotion zone, using the current assessed value and each taxing
entity's current certified tax rate as defined in Section 59-2-924; and
1 0475 (ii) the amount of property tax revenue that would be generated from that same area using the base
taxable value and each taxing entity's current certified tax rate as defined in Section 59-2-924.
1 0478 (b) "Tax increment" does not include property revenue from:
1 0479 (i) a multicounty assessing and collecting levy described in Subsection 59-2-1602(2); or
1 0481 (ii) a county additional property tax described in Subsection 59-2-1602(4).
1 0482 [(12)] (21) "Taxing entity" means the same as that term is defined in Section 17C-1-102.
1 0521 Section 257. Section 257 is enacted to read:
1 0522 17-80-102. Applicability.
1 0485 (1) The provisions of Chapter 79, County Land Use, Development, and Management Act, apply to this
chapter.
1 0487 (2) The definitions in Section 17-80-101 are in addition to the definitions in Section 17-79-102, except
that if there is any conflict between a definition in this chapter and a definition in Chapter 79,
County Land Use, Development, and Management Act, the definition in this chapter prevails in
regard to the provisions of this chapter.
1 0529 Section 258. Section 258 is enacted to read:
1 0531 17-80-201. Moderate income housing plan required.
2. County Plans for Housing
1 0494 (1) A moderate income housing element of a general plan shall include a moderate income housing
element that meets the requirements of this section.
1 0496 (2) For a specified county, as defined in Section 17-80-101, a moderate income housing element shall:
1 0498 (a) provide a realistic opportunity to meet the need for additional moderate income housing within the
next five years;
- 326 -

SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
1 0500 (b) select three or more moderate income housing strategies described in Subsections (3)(a)(ii)(A)
through (V), or at least one moderate income housing strategy described in Subsections (3)(a)(ii)(W)
through (BB), for implementation; and
1 0503 (c) include an implementation plan as provided in Subsection (4).
1 0504 (3)
(a) In drafting the moderate income housing element, the county planning commission shall:
1 0506 (i) consider the Legislature's determination that counties should facilitate a reasonable opportunity
for a variety of housing, including moderate income housing:
1 0509 (A) to meet the needs of people of various income levels living, working, or desiring to live or work in
the community; and
1 0511 (B) to allow people with various incomes to benefit from and fully participate in all aspects of
neighborhood and community life; and
1 0513 (ii) include an analysis of how the county will provide a realistic opportunity for the development
of moderate income housing within the planning horizon, including a recommendation to
implement three or more of the following moderate income housing strategies:
1 0517 (A) rezone for densities necessary to facilitate the production of moderate income housing;
1 0519 (B) demonstrate investment in the rehabilitation or expansion of infrastructure that facilitates the
construction of moderate income housing;
1 0521 (C) demonstrate investment in the rehabilitation of existing uninhabitable housing stock into moderate
income housing;
1 0523 (D) identify and utilize county general fund subsidies or other sources of revenue to waive construction
related fees that are otherwise generally imposed by the county for the construction or rehabilitation
of moderate income housing;
1 0526 (E) create or allow for, and reduce regulations related to, internal or detached accessory dwelling units
in residential zones;
1 0528 (F) zone or rezone for higher density or moderate income residential development in commercial or
mixed-use zones, commercial centers, or employment centers;
1 0530 (G) amend land use regulations to allow for higher density or new moderate income residential
development in commercial or mixed-use zones near major transit investment corridors;
1 0533
- 327 -

SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
(H) amend land use regulations to eliminate or reduce parking requirements for residential development
where a resident is less likely to rely on the resident's own vehicle, such as residential development
near major transit investment corridors or senior living facilities;
1 0537 (I) amend land use regulations to allow for single room occupancy developments;
1 0538 (J) implement zoning incentives for moderate income units in new developments;
1 0539 (K) preserve existing and new moderate income housing and subsidized units by utilizing a landlord
incentive program, providing for deed restricted units through a grant program, or establishing a
housing loss mitigation fund;
1 0542 (L) reduce, waive, or eliminate impact fees related to moderate income housing;
1 0543 (M) demonstrate creation of, or participation in, a community land trust program for moderate income
housing;
1 0545 (N) implement a mortgage assistance program for employees of the county, an employer that provides
contracted services for the county, or any other public employer that operates within the county;
1 0548 (O) apply for or partner with an entity that applies for state or federal funds or tax incentives to promote
the construction of moderate income housing, an entity that applies for programs offered by
the Utah Housing Corporation within that agency's funding capacity, an entity that applies for
affordable housing programs administered by the Department of Workforce Services, an entity that
applies for services provided by a public housing authority to preserve and create moderate income
housing, or any other entity that applies for programs or services that promote the construction or
preservation of moderate income housing;
1 0557 (P) demonstrate utilization of a moderate income housing set aside from a community reinvestment
agency, redevelopment agency, or community development and renewal agency to create or
subsidize moderate income housing;
1 0561 (Q) eliminate impact fees for any accessory dwelling unit that is not an internal accessory dwelling unit
as defined in Section 17-79-611;
1 0563 (R) create a program to transfer development rights for moderate income housing;
1 0564 (S) ratify a joint acquisition agreement with another local political subdivision for the purpose of
combining resources to acquire property for moderate income housing;
1 0567 (T) develop a moderate income housing project for residents who are disabled or 55 years old or older;
1 0569
- 328 -

SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
(U) create or allow for, and reduce regulations related to, multifamily residential dwellings compatible
in scale and form with detached single-family residential dwellings and located in walkable
communities within residential or mixed-use zones;
1 0573 (V) demonstrate implementation of any other program or strategy to address the housing needs of
residents of the county who earn less than 80% of the area median income, including the dedication
of a local funding source to moderate income housing or the adoption of a land use ordinance that
requires 10% or more of new residential development in a residential zone be dedicated to moderate
income housing;
1 0579 (W) create a housing and transit reinvestment zone in accordance with Title 63N, Chapter 3, Part 6,
Housing and Transit Reinvestment Zone Act;
1 0581 (X) create a home ownership investment zone in accordance with Part 5, Home Ownership Promotion
Zone;
1 0583 (Y) create a first home investment zone in accordance with Title 63N, Chapter 3, Part 16, First Home
Investment Zone Act;
1 0585 (Z) approve a project that receives funding from, or qualifies to receive funding from, the Utah Homes
Investment Program created in Title 51, Chapter 12, Utah Homes Investment Program;
1 0588 (AA) adopt or approve a qualifying affordable home ownership density bonus for single-family
residential units, as described in Section 17-80-401; and
1 0590 (BB) adopt or approve an affordable home ownership density bonus for multi-family residential units,
as described in Section 17-80-402.
1 0592 (b) The planning commission shall identify each moderate income housing strategy recommended to
the legislative body for implementation by restating the exact language used to describe the strategy
in Subsection (3)(a)(ii).
1 0595 (4)
(a) In drafting the implementation plan portion of the moderate income housing element as described
in Subsection (2)(c), the planning commission shall recommend to the legislative body the
establishment of a five-year timeline for implementing each of the moderate income housing
strategies selected by the county for implementation.
1 0600 (b) The timeline described in Subsection (4)(a) shall:
1 0601 (i) identify specific measures and benchmarks for implementing each moderate income housing strategy
selected by the county; and
- 329 -

SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
1 0603 (ii) provide flexibility for the county to make adjustments as needed.

(ii).]
1 0619 [(e) "Report" means an initial report or a subsequent report.]

more than 5,000 in the county's unincorporated areas.]
1 0622 [(g) "Subsequent progress report" means the annual moderate income housing report described in
Subsection (3).]

2023.

qualifies as a specified county.

zoning;

located within the specified county for which the specified county:
