1 0902 Section 260. Section 17-80-301 is renumbered and amended to read:
1 0866
Part 3. Land Use Regulations Unique to Residential Zones and Residential Units
1 0905 [17-27a-531] 17-80-301. Moderate income housing.
1 0868 (1) A county may only require the development of a certain number of moderate income housing units
as a condition of approval of a land use application if:
1 0870 (a) the county and the applicant enter into a written agreement regarding the number of moderate
income housing units;
1 0872 (b) the county provides incentives for an applicant who agrees to include moderate income housing
units in a development; or
- 337 -

SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
1 0874 (c) the county offers or approves, and an applicant accepts, an incentive described in Section
[17-27a-403.1] 17-80-401 or [17-27a-403.2] 17-80-402.
1 0876 (2) If an applicant does not agree to participate in the development of moderate income housing units
under Subsection (1)(a) or (b), a county may not take into consideration the applicant's decision in
the county's determination of whether to approve or deny a land use application.
1 0880 (3) Notwithstanding Subsections (1) and (2), a county of the third class, which has a ski resort located
within the unincorporated area of the county, may require the development of a certain number
of moderate income housing units as a condition of approval of a land use application if the
requirement is in accordance with an ordinance enacted by the county before January 1, 2022.
1 0923 Section 261. Section 17-80-302 is renumbered and amended to read:
1 0925 [17-27a-513] 17-80-302. Manufactured homes.
1 0888 (1) For purposes of this section, a manufactured home [is] means the same as that term is defined in
Section 15A-1-302, except that the manufactured home shall be attached to a permanent foundation
in accordance with plans providing for vertical loads, uplift, and lateral forces and frost protection in
compliance with the applicable building code. All appendages, including carports, garages, storage
buildings, additions, or alterations shall be built in compliance with the applicable building code.
1 0894 (2) A manufactured home may not be excluded from any land use zone or area in which a single-family
residence would be permitted, provided the manufactured home complies with all local land use
ordinances, building codes, and any restrictive covenants, applicable to a single-family residence
within that zone or area.
1 0898 (3) A county may not:
1 0899 (a) adopt or enforce an ordinance or regulation that treats a proposed development that includes
manufactured homes differently than one that does not include manufactured homes; or
1 0902 (b) reject a development plan based on the fact that the development is expected to contain
manufactured homes.
1 0942 Section 262. Section 17-80-303 is renumbered and amended to read:
1 0944 [17-27a-526] 17-80-303. Internal accessory dwelling units.
1 0907 [(1) As used in this section:]
1 0908 [(a) "Internal accessory dwelling unit" means an accessory dwelling unit created:]
1 0909 [(i) within a primary dwelling;]
1 0910
- 338 -

SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
[(ii) within the footprint of the primary dwelling described in Subsection (1)(a)(i) at the time the
internal accessory dwelling unit is created; and]
1 0912 [(iii) for the purpose of offering a long-term rental of 30 consecutive days or longer.]
1 0913 [(b)
(i) "Primary dwelling" means a single-family dwelling that:]
1 0914 [(A) is detached; and]
1 0915 [(B) is occupied as the primary residence of the owner of record.]
1 0916 [(ii) "Primary dwelling" includes a garage if the garage:]
1 0917 [(A) is a habitable space; and]
1 0918 [(B) is connected to the primary dwelling by a common wall.]
1 0919 [(2)] (1) In any area zoned primarily for residential use:
1 0920 (a) the use of an internal accessory dwelling unit is a permitted use;
1 0921 (b) except as provided in Subsections (2) and (3)[ and (4)], a county may not establish any restrictions
or requirements for the construction or use of one internal accessory dwelling unit within a primary
dwelling, including a restriction or requirement governing:
1 0925 (i) the size of the internal accessory dwelling unit in relation to the primary dwelling;
1 0926 (ii) total lot size;
1 0927 (iii) street frontage; or
1 0928 (iv) internal connectivity; and
1 0929 (c) a county's regulation of architectural elements for internal accessory dwelling units shall be
consistent with the regulation of single-family units, including single-family units located in historic
districts.
1 0932 [(3)] (2) An internal accessory dwelling unit shall comply with all applicable building, health, and fire
codes.
1 0934 [(4)] (3) A county may:
1 0935 (a) prohibit the installation of a separate utility meter for an internal accessory dwelling unit;
1 0937 (b) require that an internal accessory dwelling unit be designed in a manner that does not change the
appearance of the primary dwelling as a single-family dwelling;
1 0939 (c) require a primary dwelling:
1 0940 (i) regardless of whether the primary dwelling is existing or new construction, to include one additional
on-site parking space for an internal accessory dwelling unit, in addition to the parking spaces
- 339 -

SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
required under the county's land use ordinance, except that if the county's land use ordinance
requires four off-street parking spaces, the county may not require the additional space contemplated
under this Subsection [(4)(c)(i)] (3)(c)(i); and
1 0946 (ii) to replace any parking spaces contained within a garage or carport if an internal accessory dwelling
unit is created within the garage or carport and is habitable space;
1 0949 (d) prohibit the creation of an internal accessory dwelling unit within a mobile home as defined in
Section 57-16-3;
1 0951 (e) require the owner of a primary dwelling to obtain a permit or license for renting an internal
accessory dwelling unit;
1 0953 (f) prohibit the creation of an internal accessory dwelling unit within a zoning district covering an area
that is equivalent to 25% or less of the total unincorporated area in the county that is zoned primarily
for residential use, except that the county may not prohibit newly constructed internal accessory
dwelling units that:
1 0957 (i) have a final plat approval dated on or after October 1, 2021; and
1 0958 (ii) comply with applicable land use regulations;
1 0959 (g) prohibit the creation of an internal accessory dwelling unit if the primary dwelling is served by a
failing septic tank;
1 0961 (h) prohibit the creation of an internal accessory dwelling unit if the lot containing the primary dwelling
is 6,000 square feet or less in size;
1 0963 (i) prohibit the rental or offering the rental of an internal accessory dwelling unit for a period of less
than 30 consecutive days;
1 0965 (j) prohibit the rental of an internal accessory dwelling unit if the internal accessory dwelling unit is
located in a dwelling that is not occupied as the owner's primary residence;
1 0968 (k) hold a lien against a property that contains an internal accessory dwelling unit in accordance with
Subsection [(5)] (4); and
1 0970 (l) record a notice for an internal accessory dwelling unit in accordance with Subsection [(6)] (5).
1 0972 [(5)] (4)
(a) In addition to any other legal or equitable remedies available to a county, a county may hold a lien
against a property that contains an internal accessory dwelling unit if:
1 0975 (i) the owner of the property violates any of the provisions of this section or any ordinance adopted
under Subsection [(4)] (3);
- 340 -

SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
1 0977 (ii) the county provides a written notice of violation in accordance with Subsection [(5)(b)] (4)(b);
1 0979 (iii) the county holds a hearing and determines that the violation has occurred in accordance with
Subsection [(5)(d)] (4)(d), if the owner files a written objection in accordance with Subsection
[(5)(b)(iv)] (4)(b)(iv);
1 0982 (iv) the owner fails to cure the violation within the time period prescribed in the written notice of
violation under Subsection [(5)(b)] (4)(b);
1 0984 (v) the county provides a written notice of lien in accordance with Subsection [(5)(c)] (4)(c); and
1 0986 (vi) the county records a copy of the written notice of lien described in Subsection [(5)(a)(v)] (4)(a)
(v) with the county recorder of the county in which the property is located.
1 0989 (b) The written notice of violation shall:
1 0990 (i) describe the specific violation;
1 0991 (ii) provide the owner of the internal accessory dwelling unit a reasonable opportunity to cure the
violation that is:
1 0993 (A) no less than 14 days after the day on which the county sends the written notice of violation, if the
violation results from the owner renting or offering to rent the internal accessory dwelling unit for a
period of less than 30 consecutive days; or
1 0997 (B) no less than 30 days after the day on which the county sends the written notice of violation, for any
other violation;
1 0999 (iii) state that if the owner of the property fails to cure the violation within the time period described
in Subsection [(5)(b)(ii)] (4)(b)(ii), the county may hold a lien against the property in an amount
of up to $100 for each day of violation after the day on which the opportunity to cure the violation
expires;
1 1003 (iv) notify the owner of the property:
1 1004 (A) that the owner may file a written objection to the violation within 14 days after the day on which
the written notice of violation is post-marked or posted on the property; and
1 1007 (B) of the name and address of the county office where the owner may file the written objection;
1 1009 (v) be mailed to:
1 1010 (A) the property's owner of record; and
1 1011 (B) any other individual designated to receive notice in the owner's license or permit records; and
1 1013 (vi) be posted on the property.
1 1014 (c) The written notice of lien shall:
- 341 -

SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
1 1015 (i) comply with the requirements of Section 38-12-102;
1 1016 (ii) describe the specific violation;
1 1017 (iii) specify the lien amount, in an amount of up to $100 for each day of violation after the day on which
the opportunity to cure the violation expires;
1 1019 (iv) be mailed to:
1 1020 (A) the property's owner of record; and
1 1021 (B) any other individual designated to receive notice in the owner's license or permit records; and
1 1023 (v) be posted on the property.
1 1024 (d)
(i) If an owner of property files a written objection in accordance with Subsection [(5)(b)(iv)] (4)(b)(iv),
the county shall:
1 1026 (A) hold a hearing in accordance with Title 52, Chapter 4, Open and Public Meetings Act, to
conduct a review and determine whether the specific violation described in the written notice of
violation under Subsection [(5)(b)] (4)(b) has occurred; and
1 1030 (B) notify the owner in writing of the date, time, and location of the hearing described in Subsection
[(5)(d)(i)(A)] (4)(d)(i)(A) no less than 14 days before the day on which the hearing is held.
1 1033 (ii) If an owner of property files a written objection under Subsection [(5)(b)(iv)] (4)(b)(iv), a county
may not record a lien under this Subsection [(5)] (4) until the county holds a hearing and determines
that the specific violation has occurred.
1 1036 (iii) If the county determines at the hearing that the specific violation has occurred, the county may
impose a lien in an amount of up to $100 for each day of violation after the day on which the
opportunity to cure the violation expires, regardless of whether the hearing is held after the day on
which the opportunity to cure the violation has expired.
1 1041 (e) If an owner cures a violation within the time period prescribed in the written notice of violation
under Subsection [(5)(b)] (4)(b), the county may not hold a lien against the property, or impose any
penalty or fee on the owner, in relation to the specific violation described in the written notice of
violation under Subsection [(5)(b)] (4)(b).
1 1045 [(6)] (5)
(a) A county that issues, on or after October 1, 2021, a permit or license to an owner of a primary
dwelling to rent an internal accessory dwelling unit, or a building permit to an owner of a primary
- 342 -

SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
dwelling to create an internal accessory dwelling unit, may record a notice in the office of the
recorder of the county in which the primary dwelling is located.
1 1050 (b) The notice described in Subsection [(6)(a)] (5)(a) shall include:
1 1051 (i) a description of the primary dwelling;
1 1052 (ii) a statement that the primary dwelling contains an internal accessory dwelling unit; and
1 1054 (iii) a statement that the internal accessory dwelling unit may only be used in accordance with the
county's land use regulations.
1 1056 (c) The county shall, upon recording the notice described in Subsection [(6)(a)] (5)(a), deliver a copy of
the notice to the owner of the internal accessory dwelling unit.
1 1096 Section 263. Section 17-80-401 is renumbered and amended to read:
1 1060
Part 4. Optional Tools for Counties to Promote Housing Supply
1 1099 [17-27a-403.1] 17-80-401. Affordable home ownership density bonus for single-family
residential units.
1 1063 (1) As used in this section:
1 1064 (a) "Affordable housing" means the same as that term is defined in Section 10-9a-403.2.
1 1065 (b) "Owner-occupier" means the same as that term is defined in Section 10-9a-403.2.
1 1066 (c) "Qualifying affordable home ownership single-family density bonus" means:
1 1067 (i) for an area with an underlying zoning density of less than six residential units per acre, county
approval of a density at least six residential units per acre; or
1 1069 (ii) for an area with an underlying zoning density of six residential units per acre or more, county
approval of a density at least 0.5 residential units per acre greater than the underlying zoning density
for the area.
1 1072 (2) If a county approves a qualifying affordable home ownership single-family density bonus, either
through a zoning ordinance or a development agreement, the county may adopt requirements for the
qualifying affordable home ownership single-family density bonus area to ensure:
1 1076 (a) at least 60% of the total single-family residential units be deed-restricted to owner-occupancy for at
least five years;
1 1078 (b) at least 25% of the total single-family residential units qualify as affordable housing;
1 1079 (c) at least 25% of the single-family residential units per acre to be no larger than 1,600 square feet; or
1 1081 (d) the applicant creates a preferential qualifying buyer program in which a single-family residential
unit is initially offered for sale, for up to 30 days, to a category of preferred qualifying buyers
- 343 -

SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
established by the county, in accordance with provisions of the Fair Housing Act, 42 U.S.C. Sec.
3601.
1 1085 (3) A county may offer additional incentives in a qualifying affordable home ownership single-
family density bonus area approved for single-family residential units to promote owner-occupied,
affordable housing.
1 1126 Section 264. Section 17-80-402 is renumbered and amended to read:
1 1128 [17-27a-403.2] 17-80-402. Affordable home ownership density bonus for multi-family
residential units.
1 1092 (1) As used in this section:
1 1093 (a) "Affordable housing" means the same as that term is defined in Section 10-9a-403.2.
1 1094 (b) "Owner-occupier" means the same as that term is defined in Section 10-9a-403.2.
1 1095 (c) "Qualifying affordable home ownership multi-family density bonus" means county approval of a
density of at least 20 residential units per acre.
1 1097 (2) If a county approves a qualifying affordable home ownership multi-family density bonus, either
through a zoning ordinance or a development agreement, the county may adopt requirements for the
qualifying affordable home ownership multi-family density bonus area to ensure:
1 1101 (a) at least 20% more residential units per acre than are otherwise allowed in the area;
1 1102 (b) at least 60% of the total units in the multi-family residential building be deed-restricted to owner-
occupancy for at least five years;
1 1104 (c) at least 25% of the total units in the multi-family residential building qualify as affordable housing;
1 1106 (d) at least 25% of the total units in a multi-family residential building to be no larger than 1,600 square
feet; or
1 1108 (e) the applicant creates a preferential qualifying buyer program in which a unit in a multi-family
residential building is initially offered for sale, for up to 30 days, to a category of preferred
qualifying buyers established by the county, in accordance with provisions of the Fair Housing Act,
42 U.S.C. Sec. 3601.
1 1112 (3) A county may offer additional incentives in a qualifying affordable home ownership multi-family
density bonus area for multi-family residential units to promote owner-occupied, affordable
housing.
1 1153 Section 265. Section 17-80-501 is renumbered and amended to read:
1 1117
Part 5. Home Ownership Promotion Zone
- 344 -

SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
1 1156 [17-27a-1202] 17-80-501. County designation of a home ownership promotion zone.
1 1120 (1) Subject to Sections [17-27a-1203] 17-80-502 and [17-27a-1204] 17-80-503, a county may create a
home ownership promotion zone as described in this section.
1 1122 (2) A home ownership promotion zone created under this section:
1 1123 (a) is an area of 10 contiguous unincorporated acres or less located entirely within the boundaries of the
county, zoned for fewer than six housing units per acre before the creation of the home ownership
promotion zone;
1 1126 (b) shall be re-zoned for at least six housing units per acre; and
1 1127 (c) may not be encumbered by any residential building permits as of the day on which the home
ownership promotion zone is created.
1 1129 (3)
(a) The county shall designate the home ownership promotion zone by resolution of the legislative body
of the county following:
1 1131 (i) the recommendation of the county planning commission; and
1 1132 (ii) the notification requirements described in Section [17-27a-1204] 17-80-503.
1 1133 (b) The resolution described in Subsection (3)(a) shall describe how the home ownership promotion
zone created [pursuant to] in accordance with this section meets the objectives and requirements of
Section [17-27a-1203] 17-80-502.
1 1136 (c) The home ownership promotion zone is created on the effective date of the resolution described in
Subsection (3)(a).
1 1138 (4) If a home ownership promotion zone is created as described in this section:
1 1139 (a) affected local taxing entities are required to participate according to the requirements of the home
ownership promotion zone established by the county; and
1 1141 (b) each affected taxing entity is required to participate at the same rate.
1 1142 (5) A home ownership promotion zone may be modified by the same manner it is created as described
in Subsection (3).
1 1144 (6) Within 30 days after the day on which the county creates the home ownership promotion zone as
described in Subsection (3), the county shall:
1 1146 (a) record with the recorder a document containing:
1 1147 (i) a description of the land within the home ownership promotion zone; and
1 1148 (ii) the date of creation of the home ownership promotion zone;
- 345 -

SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
1 1149 (b) transmit a copy of the description of the land within the home ownership promotion zone and an
accurate map or plat indicating the boundaries of the home ownership promotion zone to the Utah
Geospatial Resource Center created under Section 63A-16-505; and
1 1153 (c) transmit a map and description of the land within the home ownership promotion zone to:
1 1155 (i) the auditor, recorder, attorney, surveyor, and assessor of the county in which any part of the home
ownership promotion zone is located;
1 1157 (ii) the officer or officers performing the function of auditor or assessor for each taxing entity that does
not use the county assessment roll or collect the taxing entity's taxes through the county;
1 1160 (iii) the legislative body or governing board of each taxing entity impacted by the home ownership
promotion zone;
1 1162 (iv) the tax commission; and
1 1163 (v) the State Board of Education.
1 1164 (7) A county may receive tax increment and use home ownership promotion zone funds as described in
Section [17-27a-1205] 17-80-504.
1 1204 Section 266. Section 17-80-502 is renumbered and amended to read:
1 1206 [17-27a-1203] 17-80-502. Applicability, requirements, and limitations.
1 1170 (1) A home ownership promotion zone shall promote the following objectives:
1 1171 (a) increasing availability of housing, including affordable housing;
1 1172 (b) promotion of home ownership;
1 1173 (c) overcoming development impediments and market conditions that render an affordable housing
development cost prohibitive absent the incentives resulting from a home ownership promotion
zone; and
1 1176 (d) conservation of water resources through efficient land use.
1 1177 (2) In order to accomplish the objectives described in Subsection (1), a county shall ensure that:
1 1179 (a) land inside the proposed home ownership promotion zone is zoned as residential, with at least six
planned housing units per acre;
1 1181 (b) at least 60% of the proposed housing units within the home ownership promotion zone are
affordable housing units; and
1 1183 (c) all of the proposed housing units within the home ownership promotion zone are deed restricted to
require owner occupation for at least five years.
1 1185 (3) A county may restrict short term rentals in a home ownership promotion zone.
- 346 -

SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
1 1186 (4) A county may not create a home ownership promotion zone if:
1 1187 (a) the proposed home ownership promotion zone would overlap with a school district and:
1 1189 (i)
(A) the school district has more than one municipality within the school district's boundaries; and
1 1191 (B) the school district already has 100 acres designated as home ownership promotion zone within the
school district's boundaries; or
1 1193 (ii)
(A) the school district has one municipality within the school district's boundaries; and
1 1195 (B) the school district already has 50 acres designated as home ownership promotion zone within the
school district's boundaries; or
1 1197 (b) the area in the proposed home ownership promotion zone would overlap with:
1 1198 (i) a project area, as that term is defined in Section 17C-1-102, and created under Title 17C, Chapter
1, Agency Operations, until the project area is dissolved [pursuant to] in accordance with Section
17C-1-702; or
1 1201 (ii) an existing housing and transit reinvestment zone.
1 1240 Section 267. Section 17-80-503 is renumbered and amended to read:
1 1242 [17-27a-1204] 17-80-503. Notification before creation of a home ownership promotion zone.
1 1206 (1)
(a) As used in this section, "hearing" means a public meeting in which the legislative body of a county:
1 1208 (i) considers a resolution creating a home ownership promotion zone; and
1 1209 (ii) takes public comment on a proposed home ownership promotion zone.
1 1210 (b) A hearing under this section may be combined with any other public meeting of a legislative body
of a county.
1 1212 (2) Before a county creates a home ownership promotion zone as described in Section
[17-27a-1202] 17-80-501, [it] the county shall provide notice of a hearing as described in this
section.
1 1215 (3) The notice required by Subsection (2) shall be given by:
1 1216 (a) publishing notice for the county, as a class A notice under Section 63G-30-102, for at least 14 days
before the day on which the legislative body of the county intends to have a hearing;
1 1219 (b) at least 30 days before the hearing, mailing notice to:
1 1220 (i) each record owner of property located within the proposed home ownership promotion zone;
- 347 -

SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
1 1222 (ii) the State Tax Commission; and
1 1223 (iii)
(A) if the proposed home ownership promotion zone is subject to a taxing entity committee, each
member of the taxing entity committee and the State Board of Education; or
1 1226 (B) if the proposed home ownership promotion zone is not subject to a taxing entity committee, the
legislative body or governing board of each taxing entity within the boundaries of the proposed
home ownership promotion zone.
1 1229 (4) The mailing of the notice to record property owners required under Subsection (3)(b) shall be
conclusively considered to have been properly completed if:
1 1231 (a) the county mails the notice to the property owners as shown in the records, including an electronic
database, of the county recorder's office and at the addresses shown in those records; and
1 1234 (b) the county recorder's office records used by the agency in identifying owners to whom the notice
is mailed and their addresses were obtained or accessed from the county recorder's office no earlier
than 30 days before the mailing.
1 1237 (5) The county shall include in each notice required under this section:
1 1238 (a)
(i) a boundary description of the proposed home ownership promotion zone; or
1 1239 (ii)
(A) a mailing address or telephone number where a person may request that a copy of the boundary
description of the proposed home ownership promotion zone be sent at no cost to the person by
mail, email, or facsimile transmission; and
1 1243 (B) if the agency or community has an Internet website, an Internet address where a person may gain
access to an electronic, printable copy of the boundary description of the proposed home ownership
promotion zone;
1 1246 (b) a map of the boundaries of the proposed home ownership promotion zone;
1 1247 (c) an explanation of the purpose of the hearing; and
1 1248 (d) a statement of the date, time, and location of the hearing.
1 1249 (6) The county shall include in each notice under Subsection (3)(b):
1 1250 (a) a statement that property tax revenue resulting from an increase in valuation of property within the
proposed home ownership promotion zone will be paid to the county for proposed home ownership
- 348 -

SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
promotion zone development rather than to the taxing entity to which the tax revenue would
otherwise have been paid; and
1 1254 (b) an invitation to the recipient of the notice to submit to the county comments concerning the subject
matter of the hearing before the date of the hearing.
1 1256 (7) A county may include in a notice under Subsection (2) any other information the county considers
necessary or advisable, including the public purpose achieved by the proposed home ownership
promotion zone.
1 1297 Section 268. Section 17-80-504 is renumbered and amended to read:
1 1299 [17-27a-1205] 17-80-504. Payment, use, and administration of revenue from a home
ownership promotion zone.
1 1263 (1)
(a) A county may receive tax increment and use home ownership promotion zone funds in accordance
with this section.
1 1265 (b) The maximum amount of time that a county may receive and use tax increment [pursuant
to] collected from a home ownership promotion zone is 15 consecutive years.
1 1267 (2) A county that collects property tax on property located within a home ownership promotion zone
shall, in accordance with Section 59-2-1365, retain 60% of the tax increment collected from
property within the home ownership promotion zone to be used as described in this section.
1 1271 (3)
(a) Tax increment retained by a county in accordance with Subsection (2) is not revenue of the taxing
entity or county, but home ownership promotion zone funds.
1 1273 (b) Home ownership promotion zone funds may be administered by an agency created by the county
within which the home ownership promotion zone is located.
1 1275 (c) Before an agency may receive home ownership promotion zone funds from a county, the agency
shall enter into an interlocal agreement with the county.
1 1277 (4)
(a) A county or agency shall use home ownership promotion zone funds within, or for the direct benefit
of, the home ownership promotion zone.
1 1279 (b) If any home ownership promotion zone funds will be used outside of the home ownership
promotion zone, the legislative body of the county shall make a finding that the use of the home
- 349 -

SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
ownership promotion zone funds outside of the home ownership promotion zone will directly
benefit the home ownership promotion zone.
1 1283 (5) A county or agency shall use home ownership promotion zone funds to achieve the purposes
described in Section [17-27a-1203] 17-80-502 by paying all or part of the costs of any of the
following:
1 1286 (a) project improvement costs;
1 1287 (b) systems improvement costs;
1 1288 (c) water exaction costs;
1 1289 (d) street lighting costs;
1 1290 (e) environmental remediation costs; or
1 1291 (f) the costs of the county to create and administer the home ownership promotion zone, which may not
exceed 3% of the total home ownership promotion zone funds.
1 1293 (6) Home ownership promotion zone funds may be paid to a participant, if the county and participant
enter into a participation agreement which requires the participant to utilize the home ownership
promotion zone funds as allowed in this section.
1 1296 (7) Home ownership promotion zone funds may be used to pay all of the costs of bonds issued by the
county in accordance with Title 17C, Chapter 1, Part 5, Agency Bonds, including the cost to issue
and repay the bonds including interest.
1 1299 (8) A county may:
1 1300 (a) create one or more public infrastructure districts within home ownership promotion zone under Title
17D, Chapter 4, Public Infrastructure District Act; and
1 1302 (b) pledge and utilize the home ownership promotion zone funds to guarantee the payment of public
infrastructure bonds issued by a public infrastructure district.

1 1346 Section 270. Section 17-81-101 is renumbered and amended to read:
1 1310
CHAPTER 81. Agriculture, Industrial, and Critical Infrastructrure Materials
1 1311
Part 1. General Provisions
- 350 -

SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
1 1350 [17-41-101] 17-81-101. Definitions.
As used in this chapter:
1 1314 (1) "Advisory board" means:
1 1315 (a) for an agriculture protection area, the agriculture protection area advisory board created as provided
in Section [17-41-201] 17-81-102;
1 1317 (b) for an industrial protection area, the industrial protection area advisory board created as provided in
Section [17-41-201] 17-81-102; and
1 1319 (c) for a critical infrastructure materials protection area, the critical infrastructure materials protection
area advisory board created as provided in Section [17-41-201] 17-81-102.
1 1322 (2) "Agricultural land" means the same as the term "land in agricultural use" is defined in Section
59-2-502.
1 1324 [(2)] (3)
(a) "Agriculture production" means production for commercial purposes of crops, livestock, and
livestock products.
1 1326 (b) "Agriculture production" includes the processing or retail marketing of any crops, livestock, and
livestock products when more than 50% of the processed or merchandised products are produced by
the farm operator.
1 1329 [(3)] (4) "Agriculture protection area" means a geographic area created under the authority of this
chapter that is granted the specific legal protections contained in this chapter.
1 1331 [(4)] (5) "Applicable legislative body" means:
1 1332 (a) with respect to a proposed agriculture protection area, industrial protection area, or critical
infrastructure materials protection area:
1 1334 (i) the legislative body of the county in which the land proposed to be included in the relevant
protection area is located, if the land is within the unincorporated part of the county; or
1 1337 (ii) the legislative body of the city or town in which the land proposed to be included in the relevant
protection area is located; and
1 1339 (b) with respect to an existing agriculture protection area, industrial protection area, or critical
infrastructure materials protection area:
1 1341 (i) the legislative body of the county in which the relevant protection area is located, if the relevant
protection area is within the unincorporated part of the county; or
1 1343 (ii) the legislative body of the city or town in which the relevant protection area is located.
- 351 -

SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
1 1345 [(5)] (6) "Board" means the Board of Oil, Gas, and Mining created in Section 40-6-4.
1 1346 (7) "Commercial quantities" means critical infrastructure materials:
1 1347 (a) extracted or processed by a commercial enterprise in the ordinary course of business; and
1 1349 (b) in a sufficient amount that the critical infrastructure materials introduction into commerce would
create a reasonable expectation of profit.
1 1351 [(6)] (8) "Contiguous land" means surface or subsurface land that shares a common boundary and is not
separated by a highway as defined in Section 41-6a-102.
1 1353 (9) "Critical infrastructure materials" means sand, gravel, or rock aggregate.
1 1354 [(7)] (10) "Critical infrastructure materials operations" means the extraction, excavation, processing, or
reprocessing of critical infrastructure materials.
1 1356 [(8)] (11) "Critical infrastructure materials operator" means a natural person, corporation, association,
partnership, receiver, trustee, executor, administrator, guardian, fiduciary, agent, or other
organization or representative, either public or private, including a successor, assign, affiliate,
subsidiary, and related parent company, that:
1 1360 (a) owns, controls, or manages a critical infrastructure materials operation; and
1 1361 (b) has produced commercial quantities of critical infrastructure materials from the critical
infrastructure materials operations.
1 1363 [(9)] (12) "Critical infrastructure materials protection area" means a geographic area created under
the authority of this chapter on or after May 14, 2019, that is granted the specific legal protections
contained in this chapter.
1 1366 (13) "Critical infrastructure materials use" means the extraction, excavation, processing, or reprocessing
of critical infrastructure materials.
1 1368 [(10)] (14) "Crops, livestock, and livestock products" includes:
1 1369 (a) land devoted to the raising of useful plants and animals with a reasonable expectation of profit,
including:
1 1371 (i) forages and sod crops;
1 1372 (ii) grains and feed crops;
1 1373 (iii) livestock, as that term is defined in Section 59-2-102;
1 1374 (iv) trees and fruits; or
1 1375 (v) vegetables, nursery, floral, and ornamental stock; or
1 1376
- 352 -

SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
(b) land devoted to and meeting the requirements and qualifications for payments or other
compensation under a crop-land retirement program with an agency of the state or federal
government.
1 1379 [(11)] (15) "Division" means the Division of Oil, Gas, and Mining created in Section 40-6-15.
1 1380 (16) "Existing legal use" means a critical infrastructure materials use that has operated in accordance
with:
1 1382 (a) a legal nonconforming use that has not been abandoned for more than 24 consecutive months; or
1 1384 (b) a permit issued by the applicable political subdivision.
1 1385 [(12)] (17) "Industrial protection area" means a geographic area created under the authority of this
chapter that is granted the specific legal protections contained in this chapter.
1 1387 [(13)] (18) "Mine operator" means a natural person, corporation, association, partnership, receiver,
trustee, executor, administrator, guardian, fiduciary, agent, or other organization or representative,
either public or private, including a successor, assign, affiliate, subsidiary, and related parent
company, that, before January 1, 2019:
1 1391 (a) owns, controls, or manages a mining use under a large mine permit issued by the division or the
board; and
1 1393 (b) has produced commercial quantities of a mineral deposit from the mining use.
1 1394 [(14)] (19) "Mineral deposit" means the same as that term is defined in Section 40-8-4.
1 1395 [(15)] (20) "Mining protection area" means land where a vested mining use occurs, including each
surface or subsurface land or mineral estate that a mine operator with a vested mining use owns or
controls on January 1, 2026.
1 1398 [(16)] (21) "Mining use":
1 1399 (a) means:
1 1400 (i) the full range of activities, from prospecting and exploration to reclamation and closure, associated
with the exploitation of a mineral deposit; and
1 1402 (ii) the use of the surface and subsurface and groundwater and surface water of an area in connection
with the activities described in Subsection [(16)(a)(i)] (21)(a)(i) that have been, are being, or will be
conducted; and
1 1405 (b) includes, whether conducted on-site or off-site:
1 1406 (i) any sampling, staking, surveying, exploration, or development activity;
1 1407 (ii) any drilling, blasting, excavating, or tunneling;
- 353 -

SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
1 1408 (iii) the removal, transport, treatment, deposition, and reclamation of overburden, development rock,
tailings, and other waste material;
1 1410 (iv) any removal, transportation, extraction, beneficiation, or processing of ore;
1 1411 (v) any smelting, refining, autoclaving, or other primary or secondary processing operation;
1 1413 (vi) the recovery of any mineral left in residue from a previous extraction or processing operation;
1 1415 (vii) a mining activity that is identified in a work plan or permitting document;
1 1416 (viii) the use, operation, maintenance, repair, replacement, or alteration of a building, structure, facility,
equipment, machine, tool, or other material or property that results from or is used in a surface or
subsurface mining operation or activity;
1 1419 (ix) any accessory, incidental, or ancillary activity or use, both active and passive, including a utility,
private way or road, pipeline, land excavation, working, embankment, pond, gravel excavation,
mining waste, conveyor, power line, trackage, storage, reserve, passive use area, buffer zone, and
power production facility;
1 1424 (x) the construction of a storage, factory, processing, or maintenance facility; and
1 1425 (xi) an activity described in Subsection 40-8-4(19)(a).
1 1426 [(17)] (22)
(a) "Municipal" means of or relating to a city or town.
1 1427 (b) "Municipality" means a city or town.
1 1428 [(18)]
1 1429 (23) "New land" means surface or subsurface land or mineral estate that a mine operator gains
ownership or control of, whether that land or mineral estate is included in the mine operator's large
mine permit.
1 1432 [(19)] (24) "Off-site" means the same as that term is defined in Section 40-8-4.
1 1433 [(20)] (25) "On-site" means the same as that term is defined in Section 40-8-4.
1 1434 (26)
(a) "Open land" means land that is:
1 1435 (i) preserved in or restored to a predominantly natural, open, and undeveloped condition; and
1 1437 (ii) used for:
1 1438 (A) wildlife habitat;
1 1439 (B) cultural or recreational use;
1 1440 (C) watershed protection; or
- 354 -

SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
1 1441 (D) another use consistent with the preservation of the land in, or restoration of the land to, a
predominantly natural, open, and undeveloped condition.
1 1443 (b) "Open land" includes land described in Subsection (26)(a) that contains facilities, including trails,
waterways, and grassy areas, that, in the judgment of the county legislative body:
1 1446 (i) enhance the natural, scenic, or aesthetic qualities of the land; or
1 1447 (ii) facilitate the public's access to, or use of, the land for the enjoyment of the land's natural, scenic, or
aesthetic qualities and for compatible recreational activities.
1 1449 (c) "Open land" does not include land whose predominant use is as a developed facility for active
recreational activities played on fields or courses, including baseball, tennis, soccer, golf, or other
sporting or similar activities.
1 1452 [(21)] (27) "Planning commission" means:
1 1453 (a) a countywide planning commission if the land proposed to be included in the agriculture protection
area, industrial protection area, or critical infrastructure materials protection area is within the
unincorporated part of the county and not within a planning advisory area;
1 1457 (b) a planning advisory area planning commission if the land proposed to be included in the agriculture
protection area, industrial protection area, or critical infrastructure materials protection area is within
a planning advisory area; or
1 1460 (c) a planning commission of a city or town if the land proposed to be included in the agriculture
protection area, industrial protection area, or critical infrastructure materials protection area is within
a city or town.
1 1463 [(22)] (28) "Political subdivision" means a county, city, town, school district, special district, or special
service district.
1 1465 [(23)] (29) "Proposal sponsors" means the owners of land in agricultural production, industrial use,
or critical infrastructure materials operations who are sponsoring the proposal for creating an
agriculture protection area, industrial protection area, or critical infrastructure materials protection
area.
1 1469 (30) "Public land county" means a county in which over 50% of the land area is publicly owned.
1 1471 (31) "Rollback tax funds" means the rollback taxes or in lieu fee payments paid to a county in
accordance with Sections 59-2-506, 59-2-511, 59-2-1705, and 59-2-1710.
1 1473
- 355 -

SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
[(24)] (32) "State agency" means each department, commission, board, council, agency, institution,
officer, corporation, fund, division, office, committee, authority, laboratory, library, unit, bureau,
panel, or other administrative unit of the state.
1 1476 [(25)] (33) "Unincorporated" means not within a city or town.
1 1477 (34) "Vested critical infrastructure materials use" means a critical infrastructure materials operations use
by a critical infrastructure materials operator that is an existing legal use.
1 1479 [(26)] (35) "Vested mining use" means a mining use:
1 1480 (a) by a mine operator; and
1 1481 (b) that existed or was conducted or otherwise engaged in before a political subdivision prohibits,
restricts, or otherwise limits a mining use.
1 1521 Section 271. Section 17-81-102 is renumbered and amended to read:
1 1523 [17-41-201] 17-81-102. Protection area advisory board.
1 1486 (1)
(a)
(i) A county legislative body shall appoint no more than five members from the county's
conservation district board of supervisors to serve as the agriculture protection area advisory
board.
1 1489 (ii) A county legislative body shall appoint an industrial protection area advisory board.
1 1491 (iii) Subject to Subsection (1)(b), a county legislative body shall form a critical infrastructure
materials protection area advisory board that consists of:
1 1493 (A) the executive director of the Department of Transportation, or the executive director's designee;
1 1495 (B) a local government elected official appointed by the county legislative body;
1 1496 (C) a representative of a local highway authority appointed by the county legislative body;
1 1498 (D) a representative of the critical infrastructure materials industry appointed by the county legislative
body; and
1 1500 (E) a representative of the construction industry appointed by the county legislative body.
1 1502 (b)
(i) A county legislative body may appoint an advisory board before or after a proposal to create an
agriculture protection area or industrial protection area is filed.
1 1505 (ii) A county legislative body shall appoint a critical infrastructure materials protection area advisory
board only after a proposal to create a critical infrastructure materials protection area is filed.
- 356 -

SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
1 1508 (2) A member of an advisory board shall serve without salary, but a county legislative body may
reimburse members for expenses incurred in the performance of [their] the member's duties.
1 1511 (3) An advisory board shall:
1 1512 (a) evaluate proposals for the establishment of the relevant protection areas and make recommendations
to the applicable legislative body about whether the proposal should be accepted;
1 1515 (b) provide expert advice to the planning commission and to the applicable legislative body about:
1 1517 (i) the desirability of the proposal;
1 1518 (ii) the nature of agricultural production, industrial use, or critical infrastructure materials operations, as
the case may be, within the proposed area;
1 1520 (iii) the relation of agricultural production, industrial use, or critical infrastructure materials operations,
as the case may be, in the area to the county as a whole; and
1 1522 (iv) which agriculture production, industrial use, or critical infrastructure materials operations, should
be allowed within the relevant protection area; and
1 1524 (c) perform the other duties required by this chapter.

1 1564 17-81-103. Applicability.
1 1527 (1) A person or entity that wishes to propose the creation of a protection area within the boundaries of
a municipality and ensure the subsequent protection and management of a created protection area
shall, in accordance with Section 10-7-88, comply with the following provisions the same as if the
protection area is located on unincorporated county land:
1 1532 (a) Section 17-81-101, Definitions;
1 1533 (b) Part 2, Proposal and Approval of Protection Area;
1 1534 (c) Part 3, Protection of Land in a Protection Area;
1 1535 (d) Part 4, Vested Mining Use; and
1 1536 (e) Part 5, Open Land and Working Agricultural Land Use.
1 1537 (2) In accordance with Section 10-7-88, a municipality shall comply with the following provisions the
same as if the municipality were a county:
1 1539 (a) Section 17-81-101, Definitions;

1 1541 (c) Part 3, Protection of Land in a Protection Area;

1 1585 Section 273. Section 17-81-201 is renumbered and amended to read:
1 1549
Part 2. Proposal and Approval of a Protection Area
1 1588 [17-41-301] 17-81-201. Proposal for creation of a protection area.
1 1552 (1)
(a) A proposal to create an agriculture protection area, an industrial protection area, or critical
infrastructure materials protection area may be filed with[:]
1 1554 [(i)] the legislative body of the county in which the area is located, if the area is within the
unincorporated part of a county[; or] .
1 1556 [(ii) the legislative body of the city or town in which the area is located, if the area is within a city
or town.]
1 1558 (b)
(i) A proposal to create a critical infrastructure protection area can only be initiated by the legislative
body of the municipality or county.
1 1560 (ii) Creation of a critical infrastructure materials protection area is a legislative act.
1 1561 (c)
(i) To be accepted for processing by the [applicable] legislative body, a proposal under Subsection
(1)(a) shall be signed by a majority in number of all owners of real property and the owners of a
majority of the land area in agricultural production, industrial use, or critical infrastructure materials
operations within the proposed relevant protection area.
1 1566 (ii) For purposes of Subsection (1)(c)(i), the owners of real property shall be determined by the records
of the county recorder.
1 1568 (2) The proposal shall identify:
1 1569 (a) the boundaries of the land proposed to become part of the relevant protection area;
1 1570 (b) any limits on the types of agriculture production, industrial use, or critical infrastructure materials
operations to be allowed within the relevant protection area; and
1 1573 (c) for each parcel of land:
1 1574
- 358 -

SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
(i) the names of the owners of record of the land proposed to be included within the relevant protection
area;
1 1576 (ii) the tax parcel number or account number identifying each parcel; and
1 1577 (iii) the number of acres of each parcel.
1 1578 (3) An agriculture protection area, industrial protection area, or critical infrastructure materials
protection area may include within [its] the protection area boundaries land used for a roadway,
dwelling site, park, or other nonagricultural use, in the case of an industrial protection area,
nonindustrial use, or in the case of a critical infrastructure materials protection area, use unrelated
to critical infrastructure materials operations, if that land constitutes a minority of the total acreage
within the relevant protection area.
1 1584 (4) An agricultural protection area may include within the boundaries of the agricultural protection area
an agritourism activity, as defined in Section 78B-4-512.
1 1586 (5) A county[ or municipal] legislative body may establish:
1 1587 (a) the manner and form for submission of proposals for the creation of a protection area; and
1 1589 (b) reasonable fees for accepting and processing the proposal for the creation of a protection area.
1 1591 (6) A [county and municipal ]legislative body shall establish the minimum number of continuous
acres that shall be included in an agriculture protection area, industrial protection area, or critical
infrastructure materials protection area for the legislative body to approve a proposal filed with the
legislative body under this section.
1 1633 Section 274. Section 17-81-202 is renumbered and amended to read:
1 1635 [17-41-302] 17-81-202. Notice of proposal for creation of protection area -- Responses.
1 1599 (1)
(a) An applicable legislative body shall provide notice of the proposal, as a class B notice under Section
63G-30-102, for at least 15 days.
1 1601 (b) A legislative body shall provide the notice described in Subsection (1)(a) for the geographic
boundaries of the proposed agriculture protection area, industrial protection area, or critical
infrastructure materials protection area, and the area that extends 1,000 feet beyond the geographic
boundaries of the proposed agriculture protection area, industrial protection area, or critical
infrastructure materials protection area.
1 1607 (2) The notice shall contain:
1 1608
- 359 -

SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
(a) a statement that a proposal for the creation of an agriculture protection area, industrial protection
area, or critical infrastructure materials protection area has been filed with the applicable legislative
body;
1 1611 (b) a statement that the proposal will be open to public inspection in the office of the applicable
legislative body;
1 1613 (c) a statement that any person affected by the establishment of the area may, within 15 days of the date
of the notice, file with the applicable legislative body:
1 1615 (i) written objections to the proposal; or
1 1616 (ii) a written request to modify the proposal to exclude land from or add land to the proposed protection
area;
1 1618 (d) a statement that the applicable legislative body will submit the proposal to the advisory committee
and to the planning commission for review and recommendations;
1 1621 (e) a statement that the applicable legislative body will hold a public hearing to discuss and hear public
comment on:
1 1623 (i) the proposal to create the agriculture protection area, industrial protection area, or critical
infrastructure materials protection area;
1 1625 (ii) the recommendations of the advisory committee and planning commission; and
1 1626 (iii) any requests for modification of the proposal and any objections to the proposal; and
1 1628 (f) a statement indicating the date, time, and place of the public hearing.
1 1629 (3)
(a) A person wishing to modify the proposal for the creation of the agriculture protection area, industrial
protection area, or critical infrastructure materials protection area shall, within 15 days after the date
of the notice, file a written request for modification of the proposal, which identifies specifically the
land that should be added to or removed from the proposal.
1 1634 (b) A person wishing to object to the proposal for the creation of the agriculture protection area,
industrial protection area, or critical infrastructure materials protection area shall, within 15 days
after the date of the notice, file a written objection to the creation of the relevant protection area.
1 1676 Section 275. Section 17-81-203 is renumbered and amended to read:
1 1678 [17-41-303] 17-81-203. Review of proposal for creation of protection area.
1 1642 (1) After 15 days from the date of the notice, the applicable legislative body shall refer the proposal and
any objections and proposed modifications to the proposal to the:
- 360 -

SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
1 1644 (a) county advisory [committee] board created in accordance with Section 17-81-102; and
1 1646 (b) planning commission[ for their review, comments, and recommendations].
1 1647 (2)
(a) Within 45 days after receipt of the proposal, the planning commission shall submit a written report
to the applicable legislative body that:
1 1649 (i) analyzes and evaluates the effect of the creation of the proposed area on the planning policies
and objectives of the county or municipality, as the case may be;
1 1651 (ii) analyzes and evaluates the proposal by applying the criteria contained in Section
[17-41-305] 17-81-205;

modify, or reject the proposal.

industrial protection area, or critical infrastructure materials protection area;
1 1664 (ii) analyzes and evaluates the proposal by applying the criteria contained in Section 17-41-305;
1 1666 (iii) analyzes and evaluates any objections to the proposal; and
1 1667 (iv) includes a recommendation to the applicable legislative body either to accept, accept and modify, or
reject the proposal.
1 1669 (c) The applicable legislative body shall consider a failure of the planning commission or advisory
committee to submit a written report within the 45 days under Subsection (2)(a) or (b) as a
recommendation of that committee to approve the proposal as submitted.
1 1711 Section 276. Section 17-81-204 is renumbered and amended to read:

1 1677 (1) After receipt of the written reports from the advisory committee and planning commission, or after

1 1680 (a) schedule a public hearing;

- 361 -

(b)] 17-81-202(1)(b), as a class B notice under Section 63G-30-102, for at least seven days; and

committee and planning commission.
1 1695 (2) The applicable legislative body shall:
1 1696 (a) convene the public hearing at the time, date, and place specified in the notice; and
1 1697 (b) take oral or written testimony from interested persons.
1 1698 (3)
(a) Within 120 days of the submission of the proposal, the applicable legislative body shall approve,
modify and approve, or reject the proposal.
1 1700 (b) The creation of an agriculture protection area, industrial protection area, or critical infrastructure
materials protection area is effective at the earlier of:
1 1702 (i) the applicable legislative body's approval of a proposal or modified proposal; or
1 1703 (ii) 120 days after submission of a proposal complying with Subsection 17-41-301(2) if the applicable
legislative body has failed to approve or reject the proposal within that time.
1 1706 (c) Notwithstanding Subsection (3)(b), a critical infrastructure materials protection area is effective only
if the applicable legislative body, at [its] the legislative body's discretion, approves a proposal or
modified proposal.
1 1709 (4)
(a) To give constructive notice of the existence of the agriculture protection area, industrial protection
area, or critical infrastructure materials protection area to all persons who have, may acquire, or
may seek to acquire an interest in land in or adjacent to the relevant protection area within 10 days
- 362 -

SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
of the creation of the relevant protection area, the applicable legislative body shall file an executed
document containing a legal description of the relevant protection area with:
1 1715 (i) the county recorder[ of deeds]; and
1 1716 (ii) the affected planning commission.
1 1717 (b) If the legal description of the property to be included in the relevant protection area is available
through the county recorder's office, the applicable legislative body shall use that legal description
in [its] the executed document required in Subsection (4)(a).
1 1720 (5) Within 10 days of the recording of the agriculture protection area, the applicable legislative body
shall:
1 1722 (a) send written notification to the commissioner of agriculture and food that the agriculture protection
area has been created; and
1 1724 (b) include in the notification:
1 1725 (i) the number of landowners owning land within the agriculture protection area;
1 1726 (ii) the total acreage of the area;
1 1727 (iii) the date of approval of the area; and
1 1728 (iv) the date of recording.
1 1729 (6) The applicable legislative body's failure to record the notice required under Subsection (4) or to
send the written notification under Subsection (5) does not invalidate the creation of an agriculture
protection area.
1 1732 (7) The applicable legislative body may consider the cost of recording notice under Subsection (4)
and the cost of sending notification under Subsection (5) in establishing a fee under Subsection
17-41-301(4)(b).
1 1773 Section 277. Section 17-81-205 is renumbered and amended to read:
1 1775 [17-41-305] 17-81-205. Criteria to be applied in evaluating a proposal for the creation of a
protection area.
In evaluating a proposal and in determining whether or not to create or recommend the
creation of an agriculture protection area, industrial protection area, or critical infrastructure
materials protection area, the advisory committee, planning commission, and applicable
legislative body shall apply the following criteria:
1 1743 (1) whether or not the land is currently being used for agriculture production, industrial use, or critical
infrastructure materials operations, as the case may be;
- 363 -

SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
1 1745 (2) whether or not the land is zoned for agriculture use, industrial use, or critical infrastructure materials
operations, as the case may be;
1 1747 (3) whether or not the land is viable for agriculture production, industrial use, or critical infrastructure
materials operations, as the case may be;
1 1749 (4)
(a) for an agriculture protection area, the extent and nature of existing or proposed farm
improvements[,] ;
1 1751 (b) for an industrial protection area, the extent and nature of existing or proposed improvements to or
expansion of the industrial use[,] ; or
1 1753 (c) for a critical infrastructure materials protection area, the extent and nature of existing or proposed
improvements to or expansion of critical infrastructure materials operations[, as the case may be];
and
1 1756 (5)
(a) in the case of an agriculture protection area, anticipated trends in agricultural and technological
conditions;
1 1758 (b) in the case of an industrial protection area, anticipated trends in technological conditions applicable
to the industrial use of the land in question; or
1 1760 (c) in the case of a critical infrastructure materials protection area, anticipated trends in technological
conditions applicable to the critical infrastructure materials operations of the land in question.
1 1801 Section 278. Section 17-81-206 is renumbered and amended to read:
1 1803 [17-41-306] 17-81-206. Adding land to or removing land from a protection area -- Removing
land from a mining protection area.
1 1767 (1)
(a) Any owner may add land to an existing agriculture protection area, industrial protection area, critical
infrastructure materials protection area, as the case may be, by:
1 1770 (i) filing a proposal with:
1 1771 (A) the county legislative body, if the relevant protection area and the land to be added are within the
unincorporated part of the county; or
1 1773 (B) the municipal legislative body, if the relevant protection area and the land to be added are within a
city or town; and
1 1775
- 364 -

SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
(ii) obtaining the approval of the applicable legislative body for the addition of the land to the
relevant protection area.
1 1777 (b) The applicable legislative body shall:
1 1778 (i) comply with the provisions for creating an agriculture protection area, industrial protection area,
critical infrastructure materials protection area, as the case may be, in determining whether to accept
the proposal; and
1 1781 (ii) for purposes of a critical infrastructure materials protection area, request a copy of the applicable
Division of Air Quality approval order.
1 1783 (c) The applicable legislative body may deny the expansion if [it] expansion is contrary to the Division
of Air Quality's approval order.
1 1785 (2)
(a) An owner of land within an agriculture protection area, industrial protection area, or critical
infrastructure materials protection area may remove any or all of the owner's land from the relevant
protection area, by filing a petition for removal with the applicable legislative body.
1 1789 (b)
(i) The applicable legislative body:
1 1790 (A) shall:
1 1791 (I) grant the petition for removal of land from the relevant protection area, even if removal of the land
would result in an agriculture protection area, industrial protection area, or critical infrastructure
materials protection area of less than the number of acres established by the applicable legislative
body as the minimum under Section 17-41-301; and
1 1796 (II) to give constructive notice of the removal to all persons who have, may acquire, or may seek to
acquire an interest in land in or adjacent to the agriculture protection area, industrial protection area,
or critical infrastructure materials protection area and the land removed from the relevant protection
area, file a legal description of the revised boundaries of the relevant protection area with the county
recorder of deeds and the affected planning commission; and
1 1803 (B) may not charge a fee in connection with a petition to remove land from an agriculture
protection area, an industrial protection area, or critical infrastructure materials protection area.
1 1806 (ii) [The ] If a petition to remove land in a protection area is granted, the remaining land in the
agriculture protection area, industrial protection area, or critical infrastructure materials protection
- 365 -

SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
area is still an agriculture protection area, industrial protection area, or critical infrastructure
materials protection area.
1 1810 (iii)
(A) A critical infrastructure materials operator may abandon some or all of [its] the operator's critical
infrastructure materials operations use only as provided in this Subsection (2)(b)(iii).
1 1813 (B) To abandon some or all of a critical infrastructure materials operations, a critical infrastructure
materials operator shall record a written declaration of abandonment with the county recorder of the
county in which the critical infrastructure materials operations being abandoned is located.
1 1817 (C) The written declaration of abandonment under this Subsection (2)(b)(iii) shall specify the critical
infrastructure materials operations or the portion of the critical infrastructure materials operations
being abandoned.
1 1820 (3)
(a) If a municipality annexes any land that is part of an agriculture protection area, industrial protection
area, or critical infrastructure materials protection area located in the unincorporated part of the
county, the county legislative body shall, within 30 days after the land is annexed, review the
feasibility of that land remaining in the relevant protection area according to the procedures and
requirements of Section [17-41-307] 17-81-207.
1 1826 (b) The county legislative body shall remove the annexed land from the relevant protection area if:
1 1828 (i) the county legislative body concludes, after the review under Section [17-41-307] 17-81-207, that
removal is appropriate; and
1 1830 (ii) the owners of all the annexed land that is within the relevant protection area consent in writing to
the removal.
1 1832 (c) Removal of land from an agriculture protection area, industrial protection area, or critical
infrastructure materials protection area under this Subsection (3) does not affect whether that land
may be:
1 1835 (i) included in a proposal under Section [17-41-301] 17-81-201 to create an agriculture protection area,
industrial protection area, or critical infrastructure materials protection area within the municipality;
or
1 1838 (ii) added to an existing agriculture protection area, industrial protection area, or critical infrastructure
materials protection area within the municipality under Subsection (1).
1 1841
- 366 -

SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
(4) A mine operator that owns or controls land within a mining protection area may remove any or all
of the land from the mining protection area by filing a notice of removal with the legislative body of
the county in which the land is located.
1 1882 Section 279. Section 17-81-207 is renumbered and amended to read:
1 1884 [17-41-307] 17-81-207. Review of protection areas.
1 1847 (1) In the 20th calendar year after [its] the creation of a protection area under this part, an agriculture
protection area, industrial protection area, or critical infrastructure materials protection area, [as the
case may be, ]shall be reviewed, under the provisions of this section, by:
1 1851 (a) the county legislative body, if the relevant protection area is within the unincorporated part of the
county; or
1 1853 (b) the municipal legislative body, if the relevant protection area is within the municipality.
1 1855 (2)
(a) In the 20th year, the applicable legislative body may:
1 1856 (i) request the planning commission and advisory board to submit recommendations about whether
the agriculture protection area, industrial protection area, or critical infrastructure materials
protection area, as the case may be, should be continued, modified, or terminated;
1 1860 (ii) at least 120 days before the end of the calendar year, hold a public hearing to discuss whether
the relevant protection area, should be continued, modified, or terminated;
1 1863 (iii) give notice of the hearing using the same procedures required by Section
[17-41-302] 17-81-202; and
1 1865 (iv) after the public hearing, continue, modify, or terminate the relevant protection area.
1 1867 (b) If the applicable legislative body modifies or terminates the agriculture protection area, industrial
protection area, or critical infrastructure materials protection area, the applicable legislative body
shall file an executed document containing the legal description of the relevant protection area, with
the county recorder[ of deeds].
1 1871 (3) If the applicable legislative body fails affirmatively to continue, modify, or terminate the agriculture
protection area, industrial protection area, or critical infrastructure materials protection area, as the
case may be, in the 20th calendar year, the relevant protection area is considered to be reauthorized
for another 20 years.
1 1913 Section 280. Section 17-81-301 is renumbered and amended to read:
1 1877
Part 3. Protection of Land in a Protection Area
- 367 -

SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
1 1916 [17-41-401] 17-81-301. Farmland Assessment Act benefits not affected.
1 1880 (1) Creation of an agriculture protection area may not impair the ability of land within the area to obtain
the benefits of Title 59, Chapter 2, Part 5, Farmland Assessment Act.
1 1882 (2) The eligibility of land for the benefits of Title 59, Chapter 2, Part 5, Farmland Assessment Act, shall
be determined exclusively by the provisions of that act, notwithstanding the land's location within an
agriculture protection area.
1 1923 Section 281. Section 17-81-302 is renumbered and amended to read:
1 1925 [17-41-402] 17-81-302. Limitations on local regulations.
1 1888 (1)
(a) [A] Except as provided in Subsection (1)(b), a political subdivision within which an agriculture
protection area, industrial protection area, or critical infrastructure materials protection area is
created or with a mining protection area within [its] the political subdivision's boundary shall
encourage the continuity, development, and viability of agriculture use, industrial use, critical
infrastructure materials operations, or mining use, within the relevant protection area by not
enacting a local law, ordinance, or regulation that[, unless the law, ordinance, or regulation bears a
direct relationship to public health or safety, ]would unreasonably restrict:
1 1896 [(a)] (i) in the case of an agriculture protection area, a farm structure or farm practice;
1 1897 [(b)] (ii) in the case of an industrial protection area, an industrial use of the land within the area;
1 1899 [(c)] (iii) in the case of a critical infrastructure materials protection area, critical infrastructure
materials operations; or
1 1901 [(d)] (iv) in the case of a mining protection area, a mining use within the protection area.
1 1903 (b) Subsection (1)(a) does not restrict the ability of a political subdivision to enact a local law,
ordinance, or regulation that bears a direct relationship to public health or safety.
1 1906 (2) A political subdivision may not change the zoning designation of or a zoning regulation affecting
land within an agriculture protection area unless the political subdivision receives written approval
for the change from all the landowners within the agriculture protection area affected by the change.
1 1910 (3) Except as provided by Section 19-4-113, a political subdivision may not change the zoning
designation of or a zoning regulation affecting land within an industrial protection area unless the
political subdivision receives written approval for the change from all the landowners within the
industrial protection area affected by the change.
1 1914
- 368 -

SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
(4) A political subdivision may not change the zoning designation of or a zoning regulation affecting
land within a critical infrastructure materials protection area unless the political subdivision receives
written approval for the change from each critical infrastructure materials operator within the
relevant area.
1 1918 (5) A political subdivision may not change the zoning designation of or a zoning regulation affecting
land within a mining protection area unless the political subdivision receives written approval for
the change from each mine operator within the area.
1 1921 (6) A county, city, or town may not:
1 1922 (a) adopt, enact, or amend an existing land use regulation, ordinance, or regulation that would prohibit,
restrict, regulate, or otherwise limit critical infrastructure materials operations with a vested critical
infrastructure materials use as defined in Section {[10-9a-901 or }[17-27a-1001] 17-81-101; or

ordinance regards the rights of a critical infrastructure materials operator with a vested critical
infrastructure materials use.

1 1990 Section 283. Section 17-81-304 is renumbered and amended to read:
1 1992 [17-41-403] 17-81-304. Nuisances.
1 1955 (1) A political subdivision shall ensure that any of the political subdivision's laws or ordinances that
define or prohibit a public nuisance exclude from the definition or prohibition:
1 1958 (a) for an agriculture protection area, any agricultural activity or operation within an agriculture
protection area conducted using sound agricultural practices unless that activity or operation bears a
direct relationship to public health or safety;
1 1961 (b) for an industrial protection area, any industrial use of the land within the industrial protection area
that is consistent with sound practices applicable to the industrial use, unless that use bears a direct
relationship to public health or safety; or
1 1964 (c) for a critical infrastructure materials protection area, any critical infrastructure materials operations
on the land within the critical infrastructure materials protection area that is consistent with sound
practices applicable to the critical infrastructure materials operations, unless that use bears a direct
relationship to public health or safety.
1 1969 (2) In a civil action for nuisance or a criminal action for public nuisance under Section 76-9-1301, it is a
complete defense if the action involves agricultural activities and:
1 1971 (a) those agricultural activities were:
1 1972 (i) conducted within an agriculture protection area; and
1 1973 (ii) not in violation of any federal, state, or local law or regulation relating to the alleged nuisance or
were conducted according to sound agricultural practices; or
1 1975 (b) a defense under Section 4-44-201 applies.
1 1976 (3)
(a) A vested mining use undertaken in conformity with applicable federal and state law and regulations
is presumed to be operating within sound mining practices.
1 1978 (b) A vested mining use that is consistent with sound mining practices:
1 1979 (i) is presumed to be reasonable; and
1 1980 (ii) may not constitute a private or public nuisance under Section 76-9-1301.
- 370 -

SB1007 compared with SB1007S01
1 1981 (c) A vested mining use in operation for more than three years may not be considered to have become
a private or public nuisance because of a subsequent change in the condition of land within the
vicinity of the vested mining use.
1 1984 (4) The county recorder shall, from time to time, ensure compliance with Section 17-79-716 in regard to
subdivision development near a protection area.
1 1986 [(4)
(a) For any new subdivision development located in whole or in part within 300 feet of the boundary of
an agriculture protection area, the owner of the development shall provide notice on any plat filed
with the county recorder the following notice:
11989 "Agriculture Protection Area
11990 This property is located in the vicinity of an established agriculture protection area in which
normal agricultural uses and activities have been afforded the highest priority use status. It can
be anticipated that such agricultural uses and activities may now or in the future be conducted on
property included in the agriculture protection area. The use and enjoyment of this property is
expressly conditioned on acceptance of any annoyance or inconvenience which may result from
such normal agricultural uses and activities."]
